Body: Although I'm really excited about the closed beta status of our community, I'm currently not the possessor of questions that can be answered in a way that doesn't denote a close by "Opinion based question". Where can we have such discussions? Is the chat the place to go?
Title: A place for opinion based discussions

Body:
Startups has been here before. The site is no longer online, but there was a previous incarnation of a Startups SE site (SE 1.0). However, there were some really great contributions on that site. It seems to me to be a waste to have the same questions asked again on this Startups site without also bringing in some of those great answers. For example, the top-voted question on Startups right at this moment is Dividing profits amongst developers and designers, and IMO the best answer to it was written by our own Joel Spoelsky (reposted here: https://gist.github.com/isaacsanders/1653078).

Obviously, if Joel felt so inclined, he could go find all or any of his old answers and post them here when the questions come up again. But what do we do if he doesn't? Would it be acceptible to find that content and post it as an answer (with attribution, of course)? If not, then is there another way to leverage the really good content that kind of went away when the previous Startups went away?

I'm using Joel as the example here because it was the most immediate and obvious one to me, but there was much great content on Startups 1.0 that would be of value to this new community.
Title: How should we handle questions that were previously answered on a StackExchange "startups" site?

Body: Yes, chat is the preferred medium for lengthy and opinion-based discussions.

I'm guessing that many of the questions asked will have different answers depending in where the asker is. Whilst I don't think questions should be closed if the questioner doesn't explicitly state their locale, perhaps the "how to ask a question" FAQ thingies should strongly encourage people to include these details?
Title: Should we encourage all questioners to include their location?

Body: Most questions will have to be responded differently based on locale. I think that we should ask users to mention their locale while maintaining their privacy, like the name of the city would be enough.

Don't you think I committed to a Startup Q&A site without having a clue on what is that, but I think is a good idea to have a formal definition of this to be sure I'm not going off-topic accidentally. Basically, I need some guidelines to ask more confidently.

So, is all kind of making money without being a wage earner considered a startup?

I'm asking this because I believe that not in all cases you need to own a company to sell products or services. For example to publish an Android app on Google Play.
Title: What is a startup?

Body:
I believe that one should include his/her location only if it is relevant to the question. Not always it will be, so this information will be more like a noise than useful.

IMO, asking to include this information in all questions might be compared to asking for an error log in all StackOverflow questions.

Following the use of Joel as an example. I would copy the Joel's answer, cite him and the cite that your did the copy-paste from. I would also likely do an @-mention to Joel so that it would appear on his notifications. Then it would hopefully encourage Startups 1.0 users to join/participate in the new Startups site.

I think there are two aspects to the Startup concept.

The first is to do with the Agile/Lean nature of the way ideas are developed, tested and taken to market. If you have loads of meetings and require board member or shareholder approval to get things done then most startups will probably not even get off the ground. I don't know if crowdfunded personal projects are included, but many of them do develop into startup companies.

The second is to do with the more organic/non-traditional nature of working relationships between people. There may not be a strict employer-employee relationship, and some people are expected to take on multiple roles beyond what the job description may require. There are also many different types of networking and collaboration models that can co-exist, so people have to be more flexible and willing to give if they want to get something in return.

I think these are the key differences between working in a startup versus being in an established company. In some ways some startups never move away from that original model that they work in (but it means that their size probably can't grow or scale as well), so there are definitely characteristics that we need to establish so that we get the right audience and discussion happening here.

Although Ben Collins has already told about chat, you can also try to mend some of your questions to suit the site needs. Some opinion based questions can make excellent site questions.

For example, a primarily based question like:

Is it a good idea to quit job and start a start-up?

Can be translated to:

I have a job here and here and I would like to start a related start-up. Is it a good idea?

You can this way help increase site quality, and hopefully get some opinions.

A start-up is a new company that is dedicated to solving a current problem where success is not guaranteed. They are normally doing it in a way no one else currently tries to solve that problem.

You can add all kinds of attributes around what a typical start-up does, e.g. Lean Methodologies or gets seed funding etc but all of those factors can be interchanged. Some start-ups are heavily invested in, others are bootstrapped, how they solve the problem varies greatly.

A start-up as compared to a small business is what I think we need to define to differentiate this site. A small business is just servicing a need in the market place but not necessarily solving a problem in a new way. E.g. a newsagent is servicing their local area but it is the same as all others. A start-up would do something different to service this area and disrupt the market in some way.

Not all questions or answers are locale specific. I just answered a question a few minutes ago that didn't require any locale and was generic worldwide, such as what roles are needed in a start-up.

But then getting into Restricted/Stock Options, that is also applicable to a large majority of countries not just one, it works the same or similar in many countries. However mentioning locale in here does help as each country does have slightly differing laws on the subject.

It all depends on whether it is relevant to the answer you require.

Every site has a meta for a reason: things are followed differently at different places.

At startups, what type of questions do we consider "opinion-based". From the very little participation of mine until now, I see that most of the questions are attached with some opinions for sure, and in-fact, that is necessary too.

But still, we have a close reason which is "primarily opinion based". So, upto what limit are opinion based questions allowed here?
Title: Define "opinion-based" for Startups

Body:
In general, I'd vote-close questions which ask for best practices, or many questions like "when should I..."?

The Good Subjective, Bad Subjective blog post is a great read, if you haven't checked it out. I was introduced to this post when I started frequenting the Parenting SE site.

My opinions are:

  1. Startups should have a tag for every country they include, added as needed.

  2. The FAQ should address this matter.

  3. Location should be added all of the time.

My reason for 3 is that some of us are new to Startups and don't know the location based law that goes behind it. Meaning that some of the time, the answerer might need a location, but by the time the location is added the question got old and no one particularly cares about it, anymore. I also think that location is necessary all the times, because someone from the Users that is answering might be familiar with the laws of that area and would therefore be more helpful with helping someone from Peoria, Illinois than someone from China or Australia would be.

Disclaimer:

The only reason I would say don't add your location, is that someone might decide to stalk you or whatever. And it isn't logical to have your information on the internet. But if it isn't your address and just your location like Austin, Texas. Unless people dig they won't know where it came from, unless they hack you.

I believe that the right choice was made in copying and pasting Joel's answer because it so clearly answered the question. However, going forward I think that some of the work of integrating the old material into the new site should be done by migrating the best questions, in their entirety, to the new site. This work could be done by the Community user, and maybe turned into community wiki once it gets here.

From Ben Collins' question about using answers from the old startups site, it seems that it's perfectly fine to use old answers from that site, provided that they cite the source and author. Since the data from the old site is still available, so I was wondering if we should actively reuse some of it or create this site 100% from scratch. The way I see it, there are three options.

Encourage Migration

Actively encourage users to manually migrate some of the best questions and answers from the old site. These posts would probably have to be made community wiki, so users don't spam them for rep.

Allow Migration

Have a neutral policy towards this behavior. Allow users to reuse some canonical questions, but don't encourage it.

Disallow

Continue to allow the reusing of answers when appropriate as is the case currently, but disallow creating canonical question-answer pairs taken from the old site.

I didn't participate in the old site so I'm not really sure what to think. Any thoughts?
Title: Include content from old startups site?

Body:
Are Pros and/or Cons questions on topic at Startups? I think about questions like

What are the disadvantages of involving a business angel in the founding of my startup?

Or has anybody an idea how to refine this question to get quality answers? I think this could give a useful source of information for entrepreneurs.
Title: Are "Pros and Cons" questions on-topic?

Body:
I think that pros and cons should be on topic. The problem with questions centered around the startup world is that, while there are facts, decisions are a very subjective matter. Pros and cons help bring out the facts of a matter while leaving the actual decision up to the asker of the question.

As for your example question, I think that it could be refined by adding specifics. We've seen some questions closed already in these early stages as simply being too broad to fit into the Q&A format that Stack Exchange sites abide by.

What are the disadvantages of involving a business angel in the founding of my startup?

I actually think that this question would be on topic as stated but adding more specifics to the situation will help you make the question more answerable, and also one that ideally will help you more. For example:

In a startup that does [something cool], located in [some place], what disadvantages would there be involving a business angel?

As we all know there was a previous site regarding start-ups. As Joel Spolsky even mentioned

"The last "OnStartups" site filled up with a lot of junk; hope this iteration does better"

What is the junk we need to avoid in this iteration? And what other problems mainly came about with the previous iteration that we can learn from this time around?
Title: What was the problem with the old site?

Body:
The biggest problem was the different approach of the "core users" and the people that just came to ask 1 or 2 questions.

The first group closed a big number of questions as: too broad, too opinion based,...

That was truth in fact. The problem is that the entrepreneurship =/= mathematics and there are lot of "opinion based" questions...

The challenge of this new web is to find a good balance between what people ask for and how the "StackExchange Q/A site" should look like...

I'm not quite sure how to structure topical questions in a way that is conducive to the SE format. For example, I asked about prerequisites to writing off business expenses, but there are likely a number of sub-questions that could address aspects of this topic more completely.

I think that the topical question is more useful starting out because you can see all the relevant pieces, but it might be too broad to get good, specific answers.

Is there a place here for both types of questions, or should we encourage only narrowly-defined questions?
Title: How should questions about a broader topic be structured?

Body:
I am just very surprised by the increasing number of questions about taxes.

First off, I just think this is interesting. Why isn't there more information about taxes easily available to startup founders? It just seems like such a mess.

I suppose it's fine that startups is getting inflated by tax-relevant questions, but I think it's important we, as members of the community who determine its success, keep an eye out that our questions are entrepreneurially relative.

I would argue that I think this is great material-booster (and some of these questions are often hard to answer anyway, especially from the startup perspective).
Title: Are tax-related questions on startups helping the community?

Body: From my perspective, it's a very complicated topic that I don't know very much about. I'm interested in the software and design decisions, and view the tax angle as something that could torpedo a lot of hard work simply due to my ignorance on the subject. It would be helpful (to me at least) to have some beginner-level questions dealing with the pitfalls a startup founder could face due to tax law. That way, I could be mindful of those problems, and know when I need to consult an expert.

I'm going to use one your questions as an example of what I think could be done better. This is all just my opinion though. In it you ask three bullet pointed questions.

  • What paperwork needs to be filed?
  • Does it cost anything up-front?
  • Are there any "gotchas" I should know about before filing?

I'd cut out the last one as being too broad. You could probably start a good discussion in chat about, but I don't think it works for the Q/A format.

The first two, while valid questions, are pretty weak on their own. For those I think you should do some broad research first, and then if you find something you don't understand come here and ask about it. I don't think this site should be a starting point for research, but a last resort if you can't figure something out on your own.

I don't know much at all about goverment contracting but an example question that I think is good may go something like this:

My startup is planning on bidding on government contracts in the future so I've been doing some research on what is required. Skimming through form ABC-1000, there's a section about [some term or topic]. I don't understand the purpose of this section. Could someone explain what it is for?

While these questions may not be broadly applicable, I think that is exactly the point. It's formatted so that it can be clearly and correctly answered. It may not be a post everyone references, but I'm sure someone will find it useful at some point.

This is based off of this question. Stack Overflow (and I believe many other SE sites) have this close reason:

Questions asking us to recommend or find a book, tool, software library, tutorial or other off-site resource are off-topic for Stack Overflow as they tend to attract opinionated answers and spam. Instead, describe the problem and what has been done so far to solve it.

Could we add a similar off-topic close reason to this site? While these questions can spark interesting discussions, I think they are better suited for chat than the Q/A format.
Title: are recommendation questions off-topic?

Body: I think as long as they provide enough details, they have the potential to be great questions. Taxes are incredibly complicated and lead to many questions. In addition, most questions about them have a definitive 'right' answer that doesn't depend on one's opinion. Unless this site suddenly starts turning into taxes.stackexchange.com, I think they should be welcome.

Fairly singular - specific - questions where there are a fairly limited selection of possible answers I think are fine. Broad questions that are just going to end up being a popularity contest for different resources/books/programs etc. suck and should be kept of-topic.

I'm in favour of allowing the very specific and closing as too broad any others.

I agree that this is a great close reason, but I think we'd have to think carefully about how we define it for a site like Startups. This is a time when we get to set a precedent.

Specifically, I'm thinking of the question How B2B startup can massively "cold call" customers. I think that question is perfectly acceptable for our format. "I have a business and I'd like to find creative ways to market it" is an incredibly subjective matter, but I don't think it's subjective in a bad way. It's applicable to many people, and some answers will be indisputably better than others.

As for the question you raised, however, I agree that that's subjective in a bad way. It's broad and mostly unrealistic. That said, I think if the person rephrased it to be something more like, "I own a tech startup that's tight on cash. Are there any solutions to get relatively cheap software (legally) that can help us build our product and generate some cash-flow before we invest in a more permanent solution?" it wouldn't be such a bad question. Phrasing it the way the OP did, it sounds like they're looking for a miracle solution to get free software for life, and that's not very applicable to the real world and is unlikely to help people in the future. But by putting it as a request for resources for startups, I think it's more likely to help people in the future and deter the spam answers that none of us want to deal with.

Like I said, it's time for a precedent. We can choose whether we want those types of subjective, but generally applicable questions on this site. I see you have lots of rep on SO, so I'll put it in terms of Programmers (which allows for far more subjectivity than SO does): a question saying "I need to write an algorithm that will [...]. Would I be best to use R or C#?" might be an acceptable answer. You'd need some more details, but you see my point. There's probably a good answer to that question, but there are undoubtedly people who will disagree based on loyalty to one platform or the other. However, "I'm learning to program. Should I learn R or C#?" is inappropriate by any person's measure.

I personally think the direction we should aim to take Startups in should support questions that are subjective, as long as they can be answered with legitimate logic, reasoning, and experience. So if someone asks a question, even for an off-site resource, that can be answered logically, reasonably, and with experience to back the answer, I don't think that it's an inappropriate question.

In other words, I think we need this close reason, but I also think that our emphasis should be on use of either Too Broad or calling an answer spam.

I have my reservations on this one. Basic tax laws and questions are certainly topics that start-ups need to know, however some of the questions are going which way should I take in this situation. This is tax advice that should be answered by a professional but we are all giving it a go anyway.

So I will say welcome for the moment but cautious that it may get out of hand.

Currently we have questions that are tagged canada, isreal, united-kingdom, united-states.

We had 2 questions tagged usa however I retagged them to be united-states as it has 8 questions already.

I think we should have a scheme for all country tags.
Title: Tagging guidelines - country names

Body:
I think the scheme should be lowercase-country-name-with-spaces-replaced-by-dashes. My reasons:

  • That is already what most were/are.
  • I think it is best for legibility and clarity for all users that may or may not know all short hands for country names.
I'm in favour of allowing migration if and only if the question/answer is sufficiently good. No point in just migrating questions to have more questions if the question isn't high quality.

tl;dr : Tag Synonyms

They are there for a purpose. We use them for that and that only.

When you see questions with tag names as such, kindly mark for marking tag-synonyms. Infact, we can even raise a meta post for marking two tags as synonyms. In private beta, some community mod will take a look at them, and if found reasonable, he/she will commit the change as well.

WHY?

So people searching united-states search for usa can still find the questions.

.

.

.

no need to clap...

I don't have enough rep points on this site to suggest creation of tag synonyms, but I do have enough to have seen at least a couple suggested edits go through of people changing usa to united-states. It seems pretty logical to create a tag synonym between those two.

Does everyone agree that those are, in fact, equal for our purposes? And if so, could a mod create that synonym?
Title: Tag Synonym for USA/united-states

Body:
How do we promote our site? The seventh question from The 7 Essential Meta Questions of Every Beta.

This is rapidly becoming a hot issue across the entire network: how to promote your site and how to reach out to the experts and peers in your industry. We can come up with budgets and promotions but the means and ideas about how to reach your target audience HAS TO come from you and your community. Has to. Has to, has to, has to! We simply are not experts in your field. We don’t have the the connections nor the experience you bring to the table. You are both our evangelist and our ambassador — and sharing links to great questions and answers is the best way to start.

Stack Overflow has been a huge, red-hot success story in the programming arena. But that early success came in large part to the participation of Jeff Atwood and Joel Spolsky, both cult-classic bloggers and celebrities in their field. We want that same success for you and your community. That’s why we need to identify the Jeffs and the Joels of your industry. We need bloggers, pundits, podcasters, publishers, celebrities… anyone who can rally the troops, so to speak.

Meta is the perfect venue reach out and ask around about who knows whom. Ask your friends to ask their friends. The people needed to make your site a huge success are already within your reach.

For more detail see: A Recipe to Promote Your Site

So... here it is, please help promote the site, and try to bring experts on the topic. Unofficial facebook fan pages, blogs etc are a good idea to start with.

Cheers!
Title: How do we promote our site?

Body:
Since it's still in private beta, the best way to do that would be invite people you know that you think would contribute positively towards the community. There's an area on the sidebar that allows to send email invites.

Moving into the public beta stage, there are a few startups communities that we could talk to. The blog OnStartups.com was the host of the original SE startups site. In addition reddit has a strong startups community at /r/startups. I'm sure there are plenty more of these communities that are full of members who could positively contribute to this site.

As some of you may know, StackExchange sites get "Pro Tempore" moderators just before the private beta goes public. These moderators are chosen by the StackExchange Community Team rather than being voted on due to the generally small size when the site moves from private to public beta but still really needing some users who can use all the moderator tools.

How do you become a provisional moderator for this site?

Soon after the site launches into "public beta," the Community Team will appoint provisional moderators from this community until the community is ready to hold its own elections (once it graduates from beta).

Deep engagement in the community's development is required for all temporary moderator candidates. All potential candidates must:

  • Have a reasonably high reputation score to indicate active, consistent participation.
  • Show an interest in their meta’s community-building activities.
  • Lead by example, showing patience and respect for their fellow community members in everything they write.
  • Exhibit those intangible traits discussed in A Theory of Moderation.

Bonus points for:

  • Members with participation in both meta and the parent site (i.e. interest in both community building and expertise in the field).
  • Area 51 participation, social network referrals, or blogging about the site.
  • Members who have already shown an interest or ability to promote their community.

Candidates will be contacted and three of them will be selected to act as provisional Moderators until the community holds formal elections after the Beta period. Besides the normal abilities of a Moderator, they will:

  1. Have access to a special chat room where we will collectively work through the challenges of moderation and community self-policing.
  2. Organize the process of selecting the site’s attributes (domain names, design issues, the [help center], etc.).
  3. Rally community support and drive the mission of getting publicity for the site.

Essentially, they will have the ear of the Stack Exchange team for anything we can do to help their sites succeed!

Nominating users to serve as moderators for the beta

For each user that you would like to nominate,

  • post an answer containing the URLs to both of the user's main and meta profiles on this site
  • optionally, link to the user's Area 51 profile or a profile from another site, or add a reason why you'd like him/her to moderate during beta
  • self-nominations (i.e. posting your own profiles) are allowed and even encouraged
  • post each user as a separate answer, and add multiple answers if you wish to nominate multiple users

Additionally, if someone nominates you, please edit the answer to indicate your approval (or declination). Optionally, add a paragraph or two about yourself.

If you downvote a particular nomination, you are encouraged to share why you did so in the comments, though you are not required to do so. Optionally, you may do the same for upvotes.

For more information, see this blog post.
Title: Nominate "Pro Tempore" moderators to help guide the site through beta

Body:
connor

I will nominate connor. connor has accepted the nomination

profile for connor on Stack Exchange, a network of free, community-driven Q&A sites http://stackexchange.com/users/flair/392995.png

So far he has been one of our most active members in the mainsite, chat and meta with consistently high quality questions, answers, comments and edits. He has also done the most edits to improve those questions that need that little bit of help.

Even in the private beta I have now seen 2 questions that should be more related to freelancing, something this community should be nothing about. https://freelancing.stackexchange.com/

Except people are either answering or closing based on the question is too broad, not the fact that it is off-topic.

How can we discourage freelancing questions. Being on stackoverflow for quite sometime I know that a few get transferred to ServerFault but for one we need the migration to freelancers added into the off-topic (im not sure how that is done).

Also do we need to discourage somehow or just keep migrating? Will it get overwhelming or does it work quite nicely on sites like StackOverflow?
Title: How to discourage freelancing questions

Body:
I'd be careful about putting an explicit ban on questions from freelancers. Yes, questions only relating to freelancing are off-topic, but as eggyval said, one man freelance businesses and other startups face many of the same problems. There are plenty of questions that could come from a freelancer, but be on topic for this site.

For example, many people become freelance coders. In the course of running their business they may have questions that could fall under Stack Overflow, Programmers, Freelancers, Startups and others. It's up to the freelancer to pick the right site to ask on, and up to those communities to define and moderate what is on-topic for their sites.

For dealing with those questions that are off-topic, treat them as any other off-topic question and vote to close. If you do feel it would be a good fit on freelancers, you could flag a moderator and ask them to migrate the question. With enough migrations from here to freelancers, it could become a default option.

jdero

I will not nominate Connor...

I will nominate jdero. JDero has accepted the nomination.

jdero has proven a grasp of starting up companies, and has provided quick and concise answers to questions over this community. Plus Jdero has so many less characters than @connor :)

He makes good top ramen while he works on startups. But I am very active in the community and I am checking this site 50+ times a day, and I always do my best to make the right votes and admit defeat when I'm wrong... but I think I have enough experience and diligence to help this community grow.

Direct quote form Jdero himself.

I've been thinking and yeah I am going to take advantage of that self-nominating option. So without further ado... I nominate myself: Nick Wilde

profile for Nick Wilde on Stack Exchange, a network of free, community-driven Q&A sites http://stackexchange.com/users/flair/454046.png

A bit about me:

I have been minorly active on StackOverflow for the last 3 years. For the last 6 months I've been active with the beta of Software Recommendations - starting from area51 in the commitment phase to now still public beta but with a strong early userbase and fairly good standards set and maintained. I have been one of the most active (3rd) and respected (or at least upvoted - I'm 3rd highest reputation there). Beyond answering questions I've been very active with moderation tasks as a high rep user; for example I have dealt with approximately 41% of the first post reviews. As most users active there have observed by now I'm always quite polite and helpful to new users.

I am currently in my spare time starting up a tech startup. At the same time as building a farm, and having part time paid hourly employment. Also the office manager of a construction company. So I have a fair bit of experience with all Canadian/British Columbia stuff related to startups.

Referencing a discussion I had on Area51

https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/14770/proposal-to-increase-the-scope-from-startup-business-to-business-or-some-oth

Rather than open up to Small Business I suggested focussing down on Tech Start-ups.

As per a comment by rbwhitaker

Limiting it to just tech startups is something that was considered on the old answers.onstartups.com site. There was actually a lot of support for it, though we never got a chance to give it a try. I think "all startups" could work, but I also think "tech startups" might actually give it sharper focus. I'd be in support of either. But I'm not very interested in a broader "general business" proposal, personally

As I can see by questions we are getting a lot of general business questions which while relevant to startups are also relevant to small business. Then we get the issue of are we start-ups or small business?

I personally think that the old startups might have suffered a similar fate. If we continue along the same path and generally become just a "Small Business" Q&A site we are going to lose a lot of people, myself included.

Tech Start-ups are a huge community and I personally vote to actually move to a pure Tech Start-up focus. This is a community site, so the opinions of the majority of users should be where it ends up.

What is everyone else's opinion on this?
Title: Can we focus on Tech Startups?

Body:
Background:

  • Should we encourage all questioners to include their location?

  • Can we focus on Tech Startups?

SE requires that all Meta-site questions be tagged with at least one of bug, feature-request, discussion or support.

I suspect that SE doesn't currently support anything similar for "main" sites, but I propose that Startups be able to require that every question be tagged with at least one:

  • location tag (could include "non-geographic")
  • industry tag (could include "general")
Title: Require that tags provide geographic and industry context

Body:
Now that we've started to have some activity in our chat, we may be able to ponder another one of the The Real Essential Questions of Every Beta, what to name our chat room. (If you haven't visited the chat it's right here. You can also get to it by using the site switcher in the top-left.)

This may not be the most important early meta discussion, but if anyone has a good idea for name, I'd love to hear it. It would be nice to start personalizing our site a bit.
Title: What's an interesting name for the chat room?

Body:
Startups

For the sake of simplicity, and so that people can easily find it out.

Alternatively, we can have it like

Startups : <some text that will change from time to time>

Room owners can change that "some text" from time to time to keep the freshness in the room alive... It can be humorist, related to the buzzing topic of the room, or something.

...And yeah, make me a room owner :P (just kidding)

I've seen this as a problem on a number of SE sites devoted to topics similar to ours here, but when questions are inherently somewhat subjective, how do we pick what answer is best?

As we all know, the general Stack Exchange philosophy is to "pick the answer that best helps you personally," and I'm quoting the help file from memory so I might be a little off on that wording, but that's the gist. But on a site like this, "best helps you" becomes a little more difficult.

When we're speaking in terms of, say, Stack Overflow--the most shocking example, I know--it's a little easier to decide. Generally speaking, the worst case is that multiple people give good or useful answers. In other words, your worst case is having too many right answers to pick from. If someone asks "Why can string that is a reference type be a non-null const while other reference type consts must be null?," they'll receive an answer, or several, that explain why and that's easy enough.

But when we're talking about questions on our site here, that becomes a bit more difficult. We're dealing in the inherently grey area of business decisions and experience. What's the best way of dividing equity among founders? Well, that depends. Adam and I gave what we felt to be good guidelines, and if I may be so immodest I might say I think we both gave good answers, but I'm not sure anyone is in fair position to say "oh, well, of course, the best way is...." It's a subjective question, but of course, as Conner and I have briefly discussed, subjective (within reason) is not a bad thing here, so how should users choose the subjectively best answer?

I only bring this up because I'm seeing a lot of questions with a lot of good, up-voted answers, but no accepted ones. There are also clearly a lot of accepted ones as well, but I think we need a precedent on what an accepted answer means to our site in particular. 31 of our 79 questions at the time of posting this have no accepted answers, however I'm pretty sure a significant majority do have at least one, up-voted answer. I recognize that such behavior could also be an artifact of the site's age, particularly for subjective questions it can be tempting to hold off for a week or two to make sure no clearly beautiful answers roll in late and I have no problem with that waiting period. But I feel like this will become a problem if it hasn't yet.

So how do we want to view it? Is an accepted answer the most complete? The most eloquently written? The most up-voted? Is it the one that expresses the ideas the original poster most agrees with? Or is there some other metric--either quantifiable or otherwise--that could help an asker pick?

Or, maybe, is it okay to just not accept answers on some types of questions? Are there side-effects to not accepting answers, aside from the fact that they aren't, obviously, marked as accepted in the question list or on search result pages? Admittedly I've yet to utilize our asking abilities myself and I've stuck to answering other people's questions, but looking at some of those questions, I'm hard-pressed to pick which answer I would choose even if it were my call. If I'm wrong and this isn't a big deal, that would be a--ha--acceptable answer as well.
Title: What Does an "Accepted Answer" mean to us?

Body:
My name is Robert Cartaino and I am a member of the Stack Exchange Community Team whose task is to evaluate this private beta to see if we can launch it to the public. First, congratulations on rallying the troops. This relaunch of Startups SE has certainly captured the energy, enthusiasm, and quantity of activity we like to see in the raw numbers.

Unfortunately, we also have some grave concerns about the scope and direction this site has taken.

The vast majority of questions seem to be very narrowly focused on the mechanics of STARTING a business rather than the meatier challenges of actually running a start-up. There's nothing inherently wrong with a few how-to-get-started questions, but right now the front page reads more like any chapter-book on "How to Start Your Small Business" rather than something that captures the insightful day-to-day problem-solving of actually running a small enterprise.

Maybe this is a labeling problem. You see "start-up" and think "how to start a business." But focusing on such a small (and transient) aspect of entrepreneurship will make it exceedingly difficult to keep the "do-ers" in this space. This site has to be interesting to those with the hard-earned expertise to build this community, and I'm afraid this primer on how to launch your new business isn't terribly compelling.

I'd like to float a personal observation —

Small business management and the challenges we face is certainly a compelling subject. But I'm wondering if we're (inadvertently) encouraging the wrong audience to build this site. Certainly we're not trying to send anyone away… but rather how to attract the missing chunk of expertise that seems to be missing here — the active entrepreneurs with the intriguing questions (and insightful answers) that will make this site worth building at all.

We need to figure this out NOW. Unfortunately, we've found over and over that if we don't get the site off to a really strong start (by nailing the target audience and asking lots of high-quality, intriguing questions), the site doesn't simply self-correct after opening it up to a wider audience. That's why we're extending the private beta another week or so.

I don't know if a simple name change or a renewed focus can "fix" this site, but I'm starting the conversation here. This is a well-deserved extension, so let's hear your thoughts about if/how/where we missed the mark… and what we can do to make a better run of it.
Title: Is this site viable? We're extending the private beta

Body:
This isn't really a definitive answer - which I much prefer - but it is much too long for a comment so I'll abuse the answer slot.

  • In regards to focus: yes I was understanding it to be focused primarily for the starting phases. I thought that was a bit limiting but I thought that was what SE/the community had decided on. If I change my mental slot to small business then there is a lot more than can/should be asked to my mind.
  • In regards to activity levels: yes they are a bit low and I'll work on that a bit - as much as one busy person can anyways.

So yes I think a renewed focus would definitely help and to encourage that how does everyone feel about this as a new focus statement:

"Startups.SE the place to go to ask and answer all your questions about starting, running and troubleshooting problems with your small business from conception to IPO".

I'm thinking that that should help with at least some of the problems you've brought up.

Most of these questions are applicable to the case of the original asker. In which case for the majority of those there is any easy way to choose which to accept; what route/method did the questioner take? Not perfect but a simple method of choosing. Of course upvotes don't have to be spent on the accepted answer - for example say you feel x was a better quality of answer but y was better for your particular situation due to factors that you may or may not have delineated in your question then accept y and upvote x.

Yes, there are these problems... But we can, and we will fix!

1) Narrow view?

I completely agree that this site is focusing on getting started, and not to maintain the start. I think the reason is that people who have already started, don't get enough time to contribute. We have people here who are yet to start, and that is how the site is shaping!

How can we resolve this? While the course of further expanding of the site, new users getting in, this will automatically get blurred. And we can see that difference from the first day till here... We are, and we will mature. This is no time to take our chips down. Please don't get discouraged by this.

2) Activity level?

That again will rise up substantially in coming future. I have seen a great leap in the activity levels once the site switches from private to public, specially due to HNQs. I understand you have some marks which a private beta is expected to reach, but I sincerely hope that we will do great with this extension period.

3) The name?

No, please. Lets not change the name. Not even if it is expected to "fix" the site. People need to understand that "Start-up" is not just a "start" up. It is just an immature form of a big business. If someone can't understand that, the site will make sure they do. Maybe the site description can be adjusted to suit that a bit.

Thank you :)

Boiler Room? ;)

reference

I vote no, because a startup is not always a Tech startup. Granted, that recent years, tech startups have been in the limelight, but there are innovations and disruptions happening in all industries, not just Tech.

Being part of StackExchange, there are more than enough techies here already, without having to chop out the non-tech startups.

I'm also not in favor of "general business". I personally want to discuss Startup issues, not general business issues.

Nick, not sure about having all countries, and I'm not going to comment on that, but I think we should definitely have all region related tags:

  • North America (US, Canada)
  • South America
  • Asia Pacific (Australia, New Zealand)
  • South East Asia (Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam etc)
  • South Asia (India, Sri Lanka etc)
  • East Asia (Japan, Korea, China etc)

etc

Startup:

Definition 1: "A startup company or startup is a company, a partnership or temporary organization designed to search for a repeatable and scalable business model. These companies, generally newly created, are in a phase of development and research for markets." - Wikipedia

Definition 2: "A newly established business" - Google definition

Definition 3: "A 'startup' is a company that is confused about:

  • What its product is.
  • Who its customers are.
  • How to make money.

As soon as it figures out all 3 things, it ceases being a startup and becomes a real business.

Except most times, that doesn't happen." -Dave McClure, Quora

So basically, a startup is trying to figure out the People, Product & Processes needed to make money, and once it has them figured out, it stops being a start up and is a proper business.

Recommendation questions are on topic - simply because business is built by personal recommendations and trust more than anything else.

When I ask this community of business people to recommend me a book, or hiring advice, I do it because I trust the community.

People here should think of themselves as business owners and potential business owners helping others, rather than admins of a stackoverflow clone site.

My opinion is this site isn't viable as the right audience isn't here as suggested by Robert.

Unfortunately, we've found over and over that if we don't get the site off to a really strong start (by nailing the target audience and asking lots of high-quality, intriguing questions), the site doesn't simply self-correct after opening it up to a wider audience. That's why we're extending the private beta another week or so.

The fact that most people keep saying it will recorrect itself after it goes public and that people are only recommending minor changes shows I don't think it can be changed to make it viable.

The Name Change

Focussing on New Business to IPO also doesn't quite work as more people are New Business to Acquisition or Failure than an IPO. IPO's also don't come about until a very late stage in business but agreed you do need to have your exit strategy planned at the very beginning of your business. However mentioning a single exit strategy is very limiting.

Final Thoughts

Considering that we don't have the majority of the most active members on this site commenting here as well, its unfortunate as for the site to change we would need the core members here to set the new direction. It needs a new direction or as mentioned it will be closed.

Since I'm not in agreeance with the members who have commented on the direction they want to take the site in, I can see it's not the place for me. So unfortunately I'm going to move on. Best of luck, hopefully you can all make the site into what the majority of the members want.

Maybe this is a labeling problem. You see "start-up" and think "how to start a business." But focusing on such a small (and transient) aspect of entrepreneurship will make it exceedingly difficult to keep the "do-ers" in this space. This site has to be interesting to those with the hard-earned expertise to build this community, and I'm afraid this primer on how to launch your new business isn't terribly compelling.

I disagree: I think that some people who work with startup business, including advisers (lawyers/accountants/consultants/bankers) and investors (business "angels"/venture capitalists), may see some value to contributing to this site even if it is merely a "a primer on how to launch your business".

However, I don't think that's a very fair analysis of the site to date. Of the 87 questions that have been asked so far, I count just 38 that are relevant only to businesses that have not yet begun: the remaining 49 are, to some degree, applicable to established businesses.

Therefore I reject the premise that underlies your concerns.

Small business management and the challenges we face is certainly a compelling subject. But I'm wondering if we're (inadvertently) encouraging the wrong audience to build this site. Certainly we're not trying to send anyone away… but rather how to attract the missing chunk of expertise that seems to be missing here — the active entrepreneurs with the intriguing questions (and insightful answers) that will make this site worth building at all.

I don't dispute that broadening the site's remit to small business generally might indeed appeal to/retain a larger number of "active entrepreneurs with intriguing questions (and insightful answers)". As detailed above, I do dispute that not doing so will make the site not "worth building at all".

But I do have my own concerns that a remit such as "small business generally" is so broad that the site might end up with no focus whatsoever. If it is SE's view that the site really cannot survive in its current form, then I agree that the site's objectives and target audience must be urgently decided.

Interesting enough, I came to the same conclusion as Robert all by myself and was just digging into meta to ask just that.

I think that all the really interesting questions and answers don't relate to startups only, but to running a business in general. And I think broadening the focus would invite more people to ask questions (as many sole traders or craftsmen don't consider themselves to be fancy startups) and invite more professionals of any field into the discussion. I for one would certainly enjoy an answer from an MBA, financial analyst, marketeer or something the like. But unless they are in the process of starting their own business, they might not be interested to answer questions of startups. But they might answer questions of their general field. And I would also like to find out if grown businesses sometimes struggle with the same problems as a one-man-startup. Also individual departments sometimes have the same problems as startups, but the person in charge might not come to a startup QA site to look for help. Sometimes I want an answer from a person that has already successfully started a business and is still running it. But after some time she may not consider herself running a startup.

To cut a long story short, I vote for renaming startups to business.

Edit: I am not a native English speaker, so maybe there is a better term that describes running a business. Other things that come to mind are ceo, management, leadership, ... what do you suggest?

Edit 2: After giving my thoughts on the question of the definition of a startup here, there are two central problems with the startup theme: People who could give insightful answers because they solved the problems are not running startups anymore, by means of the very definition of a startup.

All that differentiates a startup from any other business is the search for product, customers and money-making-ways. When I skim through the questions so far, very few fit into that narrow focus. So we should either have even fewer questions as we exclude non-startup questions, or we should accept that a startup faces many problems any ordinary business faces every day.

Edit 3: The same topic is discussed in Area 51!

I think that this question is very related to the currently pending public beta and the discussion on Area 51.

I think focusing on startups only (and even only on technical startups) is too narrow. Stackoverflow didn't start with only Perl as a programming language to pose questions for. If you are a C++ or Java programmer, you can simply skim through the Perl only questions via tags and filters. But some other and more general questions might apply to both Perl and Java.

Same here. Most of the problems young startups face are the same problems as anyone faces who runs a business (and not necessarily a small business either): How do you decide on your target market? How do you talk to investors? How do you lead employees? How do you shape your product or service? How do you fire up a WebSite? How do you settle dispute in a team? How do you use social media? How do you engage with your customers? How do you make a viral marketing campaign or become a growth hacker? How do you expand into a new country or create a new local branch? How do you make sales via phone? How do you get your first customer?

All of this are valid questions for a startup, but for any other business leader as well. Why should we exclude all those interesting views and questions and answers upfront instead of just skim over them if we are not interested (as in Perl vs Java)? Currently the problem is not too many questions and answers, but too few as well as how to attract the missing chunk of expertise that seems to be missing here.

The best business advice I didn't learn from fellow entrepreneurs who struggle the same way as I do, but from people who actually solved those problems and thus do not consider themselves startups anymore.

Given that the search for product, customers and money-making is all that differentiates a startup from any other business: Is this really all we want to talk about here? Because if I skim through the questions that were asked so far, not many do qualify to fit into that narrow focus.

Matthew Haugen

I would like to nominate Matthew Haugen. Matthew has accepted the nomination.

http://meta.startups.stackexchange.com/users/flair/59.png http://stackexchange.com/users/flair/1325646.png

As an avid member of the community and a member that has valuable experience that he is willing to share, I feel that Matthew would prove to be an exceptional moderator. Matthew is always willing to help and provides useful, intelligent and quick answers to questions.

I've recently posted a number of questions that may or may not have some relevance to real issues at my company.

I get that reputation is important for verifying the legitimacy of a question or answer, but I have to ask--

Is there a good way to ask questions without worrying that someone involved might see it someday?

I get the whole community wiki thing, but shouldn't there be a way that's easier than that? Maybe just check a box and it hides your name?

What are the advantages and disadvantages to such an implementation? I know that this was never an issue for me (except for embarrassing myself or ruining future employment opportunities on SO, but that's different).
Title: Should anonymous posting be a thing?

Body:
My name is Robert Cartaino and I am a member of the Stack Exchange Community Team, whose task is to evaluate this private beta to see if we can launch it to the public.

We're at a bit of a crossroads about what to do with this private beta. On the one hand, we have amassed the energy and enthusiasm of a community raring to go. On the other hand, the breadth of what is being built here seems only a small fraction of what a decent site on "start-ups" should be about. (Please see my post about the narrow focus here — Is this site viable?)

We fully recognize that this is a very limited private beta, and we don't yet have the breadth of people we'll have after opening to the public. So we are trying to determine if the purpose/definition of this site should be expanded and clarified prior to launch… or if the current focus of this site was done with purpose and conviction, and we are simply attempting to force-fit this site into something the founding members simply have no desire to build.

Here's the plan:

I would like to propose a basic foundation for a faq and site description of what I believe this site should be about. This isn't to quibble over the actual copy; it's just to set up some basic tenets of where/if to point this site and how to proceed.

What do you think? Critique, omissions, misconceptions? This is to to see if we are on the same basic page. Please discuss:

Startups

A Q&A site for entrepreneurs starting and running a small business

What topics can I ask about here?

Startups Stack Exchange is for entrepreneurs faced with starting and running a small business under conditions of significant uncertainty.

If your question is about…

  • Starting a small business including partnership and corporate structures, business plans, finance, legal or IP issues
  • Operational issues such as attracting and hiring talent, compensation, employee relationships, training and development
  • Strategies for successfully bringing a product or service to market

and it's not about…

  • Evaluating your ideas ("Please review my business", "Will this product sell?")
  • General brainstorming ("I have this idea... what now?", "How can I market this?", "Help me find a name", "Make my website better")

… then you’re in the right place to ask your question!

<etc...>
Title: Can we build a solid foundation? (3rd week of private beta)

Body:
I agree completely. I wrote a personal question for myself that turns out many others had as well; first I was happy to get a few good answers, then I got 8 lengthy, meaty answers that all added value in one way or another to the whole.

I let it sit for about 2 weeks and actually started to dread seeing another red "1" of another great answer at the top of my SE bar. I would try to read the new answers and considered their overtly distinct value from the rest of the answers, but then I'd have to go back to the earlier, higher rated answers for a refresher.

Eventually, it all became confused and I considered for a while letting the community decide and just accepting the highest-voted answer.

I didn't tho, instead I remembered that same help section you're quoting, "the accepted answer is what worked best for the question-asker personally, not what the community votes to be the best answer" or something. So, I chose what worked for me personally. The help section really helped me make a decision there actually, I know it's rude to leave an answer unaccepted.

I certainly agree that this would be a great feature, I've thought about it myself as well actually, particularly since a lot of good questions on here and other SE sites (Stack Overflow notwithstanding) have a lot to do with ethical dilemmas. However, that said, I don't expect it to go to status-completed any time soon, for a couple reasons.

Priorities

Supporting a site the magnitude of the Stack Exchange network is inherently, well, hard, and there are other things going on that need more urgent addressing. Realistically, if you're concerned about your identity getting out there and an involved party becoming aware of your stance, you could either create another account with a separate email or clear your real account of any personally identifiable information. Now, of course, neither of those are as nice as having the feature implemented. And again, I'm in support of your idea. I just don't think that "syntactic sugar," to use a coding metaphor, is at the top of the list to the SE team right now.

Risk-Reward

Speaking in terms, again, of the network as a whole, we have to look at the philosophy: do we want good questions, or do we not want bad questions? Allowing for anonymous posting would lead to a lot of bad questions and straight-up spam. Now, I recognize, of course, that that's easy to combat post-facto. We can easily require authentication, then just hide the user information on the post. Then we'd follow the exact same rules as we do now, with close votes leading to blocked posting abilities and all that good stuff.

But unfortunately, and this is really just a guess, I'd expect us to have to close a lot more questions, because people wouldn't feel accountable. I see a lot more bad questions posted by @user0000000 than I do by someone with their full name listed, and I'm virtually positive that that problem would just increase if we allowed for true anonymity.

Of course, to combat my own point, we could require a minimum reputation--have it as a privilege. That would inherently reduce some of the anonymity, but it would work. But I've still seen some pretty embarrassingly bad questions asked by users on Stack Overflow with over ten thousand rep points.

Reputation

Much of the brilliance of the Stack Exchange system lies in the accountability we all experience when posting something, because--less on Meta sites--it has a lasting effect on a score that is always displayed near our name. It seems a little weird, then, that someone could write an awesome question or answer (that link isn't really relevant, since it'd never be posted anonymously, but I still think it's cool--call me a Stack Exchange nerd, I can take it), get almost thirteen thousand up-votes that add up to (200-point cap permitting) 130,000 points, but when you go to the person's profile it only shows a couple mediocre answers adding up to a couple hundred points. Obviously that's an extreme example, but you see my point. Something like that could happen if someone posted anonymously a lot, even just a few good posts (which I imagine many anonymous ones would be, since they'd be inherently "meaty") could lead to a thousand rep points, that would then be left unaccounted for on a profile page.

Now, my immediate retort to that is "well then, you just don't get rep points for an anonymous post!" Fair enough, but does that give us an excuse to just go on and post not-so-hot questions on the long-shot that someone will answer, comfortable that we won't get penalized? This speaks somewhat to the idea, again, of letting only higher-rep users post anonymously, but it doesn't solve it.

It isn't such a big deal, but badges follow the same issues: what if you get a "Famous Question" badge? Does the info page for that just say it can't display what the question was? Again, not such a big deal, but that's just another aspect of the site that would have to be adjusted to prepare for anonymous posting.

Long Story Short

I like the idea, and I think it would be super useful for those of us who wouldn't abuse it, but I think there are a lot of risks with implementing that sort of system, and it fundamentally opposes some of the philosophies of the site. So even though it'd be doable, and even though it'd be useful, I just don't see it happening any time soon. It's better just to anonymize your account, or create a separate one for more sensitive questions.
Stones for the song.

Just after some research, I've found a lovely site that seemed to have taken the majority of onstartup's following.

Chances are, I would think neither of us knows the other exact. I wouldn't know how to turn this into a poll, but what are your guys' thoughts on this? I wish there was a way to import their data and put it alongside ours or something.

They have a lot of good questions that would benefit our community, and we have ones that aren't on theirs.

But they've been around for a while and they still get 100+ views on every question.

Just something worth looking into. Thoughts about a course of action, if needed?
Title: Are we competing without knowing it?

Body: Are legal questions regarding formation of a business entity (e.g. LLC, INC, LTD) off-topic? Assuming the unspoken disclaimer that should go without saying: "I'm not a lawyer, but [insert plausible solution]". I would be interested in asking a few questions regarding the ideal business entity formation, given my circumstances and details regarding my type of service. Thank you.
Title: Are legal questions regarding formation of a business entity (e.g. LLC, INC, LTD) off-topic?

Body: I would say as a required and possibly most important part of a start up legal questions are a great help and should be as narrow as can be useful. State specific is helpful.

I've got to say, you folks have done a nice job in your private beta. It looks like we have, or at least have a consensus on a solid foundation for the site to proceed, and there's no reason to delay letting the rest of the world in to participate in and grow this community.

We've got plenty of people that have a lot of good ideas about the direction this site should take, and, most importantly - I see people getting real help with real-life problems that they brought to the private beta to ask questions about. We're a tad concerned about the level of activity, but we're confident that some delay in leaving private beta is the cause, and opening the site should be all that's needed to get a steady stream of new questions going.

Startups SE now has as long as it takes to work through the public beta phase, provided that the site doesn't become a deserted ghost town of run-down buildings full of broken windows. Put simply, unless we see the site overrun with extremely poor quality questions and spam, and no one doing anything about it, you've got a site.

We feel that this community has the best shot of any to make a much better place on the Internet for folks starting a new business to get good answers to their questions from people that have real experience, and that's what we're all about.

We're offering the following advice, just for consideration, for the road ahead:

  • Be as friendly as you can be, but there are such things as questions that just won't work well here. We talked about this in the meta post I also linked at the top, and we'll be updating your description and help center accordingly. While we didn't see answers on that discussion, the votes on it speak pretty clearly.
  • Encourage a culture of editing - that's a great way to teach folks how to more efficiently get the help that they need.
  • This is your site, something you're proud of. Encourage new contributors to stick around and help curate and maintain it, let them know there's a community here. A great way to do this is not forgetting to put an up-vote on a great post, you'd be amazed at how engaged people can get when they see their score increase.

But, you folks seem to get this, and we're excited to see where the site goes. Just remember, we're here if you need us, if you feel moved enough to feel concern about something, bring it up on Meta - don't let active discussion about this community gather dust for too long :)

Congratulations again - you've done a great job - now keep going!
Title: Startups SE - Advancing To Public Beta

Body:
If this site is how Answers.OnStartups was run, you can see why they closed it. There's only a handful of questions per month, half of which should be closed. The purpose of this beta was to get a fresh start, so I don't think it's a good idea too tie ourselves to closely to this site.

That being said, I think there are some good questions over there. Depending on the licensing, we may want to manually bring over a few of the better ones.

I'm not sure if an ad for our directly competing site would be appropiate on their site. I'd imagine there is some bitterness towards how SE closed their site, but maybe some would still be interested if we reached out.

Referencing your previous post here ..

The vast majority of questions seem to be very narrowly focused on the mechanics of STARTING a business rather than the meatier challenges of actually running a start-up. There's nothing inherently wrong with a few how-to-get-started questions, but right now the front page reads more like any chapter-book on "How to Start Your Small Business" rather than something that captures the insightful day-to-day problem-solving of actually running a small enterprise.

I generally agree with your previous post that including more (startup related) focus areas would be great for making the site more useful.

While I also agree we should have some exclusion guidelines, I disagree on both of the suggested exclusions.

Business people with experience can definitely help others with questions like "How can I market X with limited budget" etc. Definitely these questions would be excellent reference for other entrepreneurs.

The community as a whole has been very accommodating to all kinds of questions, and seldom any have been closed or voted down harshly. The reason is because in business & entreprenuership there is no 100% right or wrong answer. Uncertainty is the norm. We are still in the process of accumulating the critical mass of this site, and nowhere near to the need for "cutting down" anything.

While we want to block overly spammy abuse of the site, I think most of us want to support other business owners, and we would be keen to help them review their site, idea, plan etc. I think after a while the community will figure out what are reasonable and necessary limits, and at that point we will decide on sensible guidelines. Right now what you're suggesting will completely (100%) block anything of that kind, and I don't think we want to do that yet.

Basically as I see it, the site is growing in content. You have suggested "spreading the focus" and "cutting down the focus[exclusions]".

While agreeing that we should evolve anti-spam measures, I disagree that we need exclusions right now. My concern is only that we would "throw the baby out with the bathwater". I'm sure we will recognise overtly spam content and propose measures at those points.

In fact, I propose that we add both the example exclusions (or parts of them) to "if your question is about" section, this would definitely invite more participation and dynamic activity.
The Incubator. It's not that bad! :)

I've successfully submitted a proposal for this synonym, as well as a couple others. Now hurry up and get 1250 rep so you can vote guys ;)

It's nice to go ahead and edit posts, but we can't expect every new user to innately know this, so I believe the tag synonym is appropriate.

Thanks to a tag wiki proposed by Connor, I realized that we currently don't have a system in place to differentiate the state of Georgia and the country of the same name for tags. Given that it seems that we consider geography pretty important around here (rightfully so, I might add), should we care about this?

It wouldn't be overly surprising to me if we went forever without need for such differentiation, so perhaps we shouldn't worry about it.

As far as options are concerned, I see three viable ones: we rename georgia to georgia-state (and consequently risk people using the wrong one, and have to rename all of the states to append "-state," which sounds tedious and frustrating in the long-run), we add a tag for georgia-country (or something to that effect), or we do nothing and let things play their course.

This just seems like something that should be discussed, even if that discussion leads to "we shouldn't bother thinking about it."
Title: Georgia the State vs. Georgia the Country

Body: This came to mind when I was editing the tag. For now at least, we have more questions about the state then the country (1-0) and the state is more populous, so I think the tag fits. I'd hold off on creating a tag for country until the need arises. Tags without a question are automatically deleted anyway. I think georgia-country or something similar would work fine though.

One of the reasons that Stack Overflow is so valuable is that it has built up a community of people who are willing to (for instance) look at someone else's code and fix it, or recommend a library that would help them progress.

In my experience, what people want the most is exactly what you're proposing to rule out of bounds - which is, to look at what they're trying to do in business terms and help them fix it. And also in my experience, entrepreneurs can be extremely generous in sharing their experience.

The proto-FAQ above does seem to me to throw out the baby with the bathwater. I think you need a better way to describe the behaviors that are unwanted, so that moderators can deal sharply with truly spammy questions and answers, and gently with questions that are too broad to be answerable compactly.

Is it just me, or is it incoherent to rule that asking about

Strategies for successfully bringing a product or service to market

is OK, but asking for help

Evaluating your ideas ("Please review my business", "Will this product sell?")

isn't? Surely a Stack Exchange site should be open to someone:

  1. Describing what they are trying to achieve, both enough, and little enough detail about the specifics for context

  2. Stating their problem - something not working, or a key decision they don't know how to make, for instance

If spam is resolved, the only obviously missing piece is the problem that if someone wants to reference a screenshot or a snapshot of a website, there needs to be some kind of guidance about how to do that. In the answers.onstartups days, the (non-spammy) questions that referenced a website weren't frustrating because they were asking for specific help, they were frustrating because if you clicked the link the site had (presumably) changed and the question made no sense. That made life frustrating for someone trying to answer a question, and for someone reviewing a question that interested them for insight for their own problem.

Currently, we have app-development, mobile-apps, web-development, android-development and software tags.

I think app-development is a duplicate of mobile-apps and can be merged with it. For the cases of web apps, web-development could be used instead. For general software products, there is the software tag.

Right now there are only five app-development questions, so it would be a pretty quick merge/ burnination. Any thoughts?
Title: Burninate app-development tag

Body: Having used all three sites (OnStartups, Bright Journey, Startups.SE) my take is that they're really not comparable. If you're looking for a real competitor, I'd look elsewhere.

Since the whole site's scope is startups, do we need a specific startup tag? I think it's redundant, but I thought it would be a good idea to bring it up on meta before taking any action. There are currently six questions tagged with startup.
Title: Do we need the startup tag?

Body:
Tags that describe the entire subject of the site are generally blocked by default. The startup tag is simply a minor variation that got through that block.

We need a tag cleanup.

The tag was blocked, but I left the current instances so you can find those questions to clean them up. Remove the tag and please make sure those questions will be properly tagged in its absence. Any questions without a tag will become untagged.

Update: The questions seem cleaned up nicely (thank you for doing that). Now that the tag is unused, it will be removed automatically in the next maintenance cycle.

I found that many of start-up require field-sales.
Now a days, it's very much important part of any kind of start-up.
As an example Linkedin having field-sales channel to sale premium plans.
I feel that most of start-up will look forward to have discussion about field-sales. That's why, I am proposing field-sales tag to community.
Title: Should start-up community have field-sales tag?

Body:
Make a question that clearly wants the field-sales tag - though I would suggest sales-field instead.

Given that any tags with no questions tagged are automatically scrubbed we aren't going to make a tag without a question. If there is a question that should have a tag but you don't have edit/create tag privs then just give the link here or in chat and someone with higher rep/access will do it.

Please link to examples of the question you reference as already existing.

Also, I agree that field-sales is a common sales term, just like inside-sales is too. Only suggestion I might have is to make outside-sales and field-sales some linked to avoid duplication.

Lastly, might be worth posting an inside-sales question just to create a tag so that both inside and outside tags are present in the system.

Further to our earlier nominations, I have just noticed that we have some folks who have been appointed to be our moderators pro tempore on Startups SE.

Congratulations to all three—SE have rightly recognised their excellent contributions to the community.

With their help, I look forward to seeing Startups continue to thrive and grow.
Title: Congratulations to pro-tempore moderators

Body:
Aye t'this! Congratulations to connor, Nick Wilde, and Matthew Haugen! They've stepped up and generously volunteered their time to help us assure that each community’s issues are properly addressed.

We want to make this site a huge success, and these members are great examples of exactly the type of people we need to make this site succeed. Please welcome them for the hard work and time they contribute.

Don't forget to be respectful and understanding of the Moderators Pro Tem. Members of your community are volunteering their time and learning on the job. It’s a learning experience for everyone.

During the private beta, we came up with this scope for our site:

Startups Stack Exchange is for entrepreneurs faced with starting and running a small business under conditions of significant uncertainty.

We encourage questions about both startups and running a small business, but there is no consensus about what a startup is. We’re worried that some potential users would be put off by the name Startups. Earlier in the private beta, we had a discussion about how our labeling may have been affecting our audience.

Given that, we’d like to bring up the possibility of a rename.

We’d like to hear your thoughts. Do you think our name fits our purpose, or do you have any ideas for a better name?

Keep in mind that Stack Exchange is not required to honor a name change if we decide on one. Also, it might be useful to review this meta post.

Remember: Although we'd probably want them to be, we are not bound in any way to having our title and URL be the same. For example, Amateur Radio uses the URL ham.stackexchange.com.

Just to be 100% clear, in light of some recent confusion: the title shows up in the following places:

The Top of Site Pages

The Sites List Dropdown

The List of Sites on http://stackexchange.com/sites

The Accounts List on User Profile Pages

And a few other, similar places.
Title: Is our name appropriate?

Body:
Startups.stackexchange.com

My position is supported by real-world data: Google Ngram Viewer & Google Trends.

Yes, our name is appropriate in my opinion, and all this wishy-washy semantic analysis needs to stop, since not all startups are small, huge amounts of massive corporations use startup-based practices, etc.; in fact, not all startup ventures are profit-based businesses.

There's never going to be a single-phrase that will make everyone happy, and I personally signed on because I love startups; this is not to say I don't see the need to have a wide array of questions as being on-topic.

The sooner we focus on not being everything to everyone, the better off we'll be; again, my opinion, and expect that some won't agree. Simply put, I do not believe we should change the name.

UPDATES:

It's good that these issues are raised, but in this case I think startups is a great name. If anything, the only people who don't know what a startup is (in terms of getting an "in-the-ballpark" definition) are probably the ones who never would be able to contribute to this site. I think it's quite perfect. Short, easily pronounced, and has amazing potential to attract enough curiosity to provoke growth :D

jdero

Proposition: Startups and Small Businesses

Pros:

  • Attracts both audiences.
  • Accurately reflects the focus of the site.

Cons:

  • The length (remember that URL is independent, but all the same).
  • The Stack Exchange team is generally opposed to names that include the word "and," but only because it tends to lead to too wide of scopes. They might be able to be convinced otherwise, since this name doesn't change our scope and merely clarifies it.

General Note:

We'd probably keep the same url of startups.stackexchange.com with this option.

Proposition: Entrepreneurs

Pros:

  • It's unambiguous.
  • It's an attractive name, like "Startups" already is, but without limiting scope.

Cons:

  • It might give the impression of a managerially-focused site, which we are not.
  • There's a major legal risk that we could probably overcome, but not at no cost to SE, so it's unlikely to get approved.

Think Big

(I'd probably leave the site at https://startups.stackexchange.com/, just like Ask Different is at https://apple.stackexchange.com/).

Pros:

  • Captures the essence of what (I think) differentiates a "startup" from other small businesses;

  • Quirky rather than literal (just like "Stack Overflow", "Cross Validated", "Seasoned Advice", etc.);
