  • It references Donald Trump: "As long as you’re going to be thinking anyway, think big."

Cons:

  • It might not convey sufficient clarity over the site's purpose or scope;

  • It might not fit within SE's naming rules.

I was wondering how should we handle answers which include a hidden or obvious advertisement of answerer company, like the newest answer to this question.

Even though I really like this answer, I am unsure of how should I react as this is an obvious ad for a company linked in it. I would not have any problem with an answer stating there are companies offering this, look them up in google, which would be satisfactory answer in this case as well.

In short, should those answer be flagged for moderator attention or treated as a perfectly valid answers?

Matthew Haugen's edit:

In case this answer gets edited or destroyed at any point in the future, I've attached an anonymized screenshot of it for the record.
Title: Advertising answers

Body:
Well that is a bit hard to give a solid rule. In a lot of questions and answers it is unavoidable that we will end up mentioning those companies that we have experience with and they will often be our own. That particular answer I don't like how it is written. So some vague guidelines on what I'm thinking:

  • That is certainly a somewhat valid answer.
  • That is clearing advertisement with (potential) for fiscal gain.
  • It does have clear disclosure so I would say it is not spam.
  • Therefore the answer should be re-written to focus on the type of service with a link as an example rather than the only one.

However my desired editing would be a bit beyond normal editing scope. So I'm going to discuss it with the other mods and harden up those rules a bit. I'll also bring it up with the answerer.

This answer looks fine to me. The user answered the question and disclosed his affiliation with the company.

Jeff Atwood, in the post eggyal linked summarized it well.

Post good, relevant answers, and if they happen to be about your product, so be it. However, you must disclose your affiliation with the product in your answers. Also, if a huge percentage of your posts include a mention of your product, you're clearly here for the wrong reasons.

You should be careful with self-promotion. Many users on the stack exchange network frown upon using the site for any personal gain beyond reputation points. If you self-promote in your answer and especially if you show a pattern of self-promotion, they may downvote you. With the exception of serial downvoting and gaming the site, users are free to downvote as they please.

If you think a user is self-promoting too much and not providing much value in their answers, you can flag for moderator attention. We don't want self-promotion to decrease the quality of the site. Be careful with the spam flag though. It should be used for posts that are not an attempt to answer the post at all but solely advertise a product. They carry severe repercussions beyond a regular flag.

On the previous site answers.onstartups.com that was closed after 1176 days in beta, there were a couple of posts that I made. I believe that the information there is still useful and would like them archived on this site.

How can I migrate these posts back into the site?

Also, since there is a data dump of the previous posts, why are they not being migrated back into this site?
Title: How can I migrate my previous questions back into the site?

Body:
I don't believe we have any automated way of doing this, so there are a couple options.

  1. Just manually copy over whatever you want. For answers (or questions, for that matter) that weren't yours originally, mark them as Community Wiki. They'll get re-voted on and re-answered, and perhaps some exciting new information will come up.
  2. If there are a ton that you want, compile a list and get them to a moderator (perhaps through editing your post here). We'll look over them and can talk to the SE team and see about doing it. But make sure you handpick each one, because we definitely don't want to copy the whole old site over.

In part of our continued effort to define the scope of Startups and begin to set rules of what kinds of questions are or are not on-topic here, we have just released a new close-vote reason. The idea was initially brought to attention in a meta post about these very types of questions.

Questions asking us to recommend or find a book, tool, software, tutorial or other off-site resource are off-topic for Startups as they tend to attract opinionated answers and spam. Instead, describe your problem or need and the steps, if any, you've taken to solve it.

Many of you will recognize some of the wording from Stack Overflow's similar reason, and there's good reason for that. We agree with it.

Fortunately for askers here, however, many questions closed with this could probably be rephrased to be good questions.

Now it's your turn. What do you think? We're looking for any holes that can be poked in this close reason, especially good questions that might get improperly closed with it.

Unless and until we come across any show-stoppers, you'll find this close reason sitting under Close -> off-topic because....

We'll be posting another featured request in the weeks to come, looking for suggestions of others to add. But feel free to suggest any other ideas you have here as well.
Title: Vote to Close Recommendation Posts

Body: To me, Ask Patents seems like a better fit for most patent related questions on Startups SE and it's unclear how we're deciding to keep or move questions. How are we deciding where to put patent questions?
Title: When are patent questions a better fit for Patents SE?

Body:
I'm not active on Ask Patents, so I don't know exactly what questions go on their site. but just because a question would fit on one Stack Exchange site, does not make it off-topic on all other sites. Ask Ubuntu and Unix & Linux are an example of two sites that have a lot more crossover than we do with Ask Patents. There's a blog post about it here.

In general, if a question is about how patents work, or the specifics of one patent in particular it is definitely off-topic here. On the other hand, if the question is about using patents in your business, then it could definitely work well here.

As long as the question fits the scope of our site, it's allowed regardless of whether or not it would also fit the scope of another stack exchange site.

Clearly, given my tendency to respond, I think those questions are okay here. I'm not sure where it was, but I've seen a quote by an SE employee saying something along the lines of "just because something is on-topic on one site, doesn't mean it's off-topic for another." There can be some overlap in topics, and patents can be an important part (for better or worse) to starting a business.

Questions about IP tend to receive positive votes, and as far as I'm concerned, they aren't hurting anyone, so for the time being, I personally have no objection to keeping them around.

If people started asking questions about specific patents, that would become a worthy candidate for migration. But so far, that hasn't been an issue.

Edit: Poking around meta, I found this post, which points to this blog post, which says it nicely.

As members of a community, your first loyalty should be to that community. When evaluating a question, you shouldn’t be looking to push it off on some other site; instead, ask if it could be appropriate and on-topic for you, the experts who the author decided to ask. Be a bit jealous of your site – don’t blithely turn askers away simply because their question could be asked somewhere else. Don’t hit them over the head with your scope, help them tailor their question to fit into it – and if that means your site’s scope overlaps a bit with another site’s, so be it.
Bit puzzled by both the voting patterns and themes of what is good content, what is not, and looking for any thoughts on the topic.
Title: What content is good content?

Body:
It's hard to completely answer this question without seeing some examples of what you mean by confusing voting patterns, but you can find some general tips for how to make a good question in the help center.

In terms of good content, there are a two different things you can look at. Its open/ closed status and its votes. Questions are closed when they don't fit the scope of the site, which is defined here. We're still in beta, so there are still some grey areas. If you're not sure if a question is on topic, you should bring it up on meta so the community can work do refine our definition of on topic.

Popular questions are voted up. With the exceptions of manipulating the site or targeting a specific user, users are free to have their own opinion and vote accordingly. This means that a question could be upvoted, but still be considered off-topic for this site and closed.

Hope this helps.

I'm asking because these kind of questions tend to have no right answer if the questions fall into a gray area.

Questions like:

"Is it ethical to bill hours when learning new stuff that you plan to use with other clients?"

or:

"Is it ethical to bill a client for software that you plan to use for other clients' projects?"

Are these questions off-topic in startups?
Title: Are "Is it ethical...." questions off-topic?

Body:
In an attempt to get the ball rolling, the only related meta question I was able to find, doesn't appear to have much traction; possible there are more, but that's what I found.

Further, it might be of use to attempt to clearly define ethics:

Ethics and morals both relate to “right” and “wrong” conduct. However, ethics refer to the series of rules provided to an individual by an external source, e.g. their profession or religion. Morals refer to an individual’s own principles regarding right and wrong. source

Point is that ethical questions require an "official" source, and as such, my position would be that if the source of the rules of ethics merits reference, then the topic is not subjective, but if not, it is. Meaning any question on ethics must cite a source, that source must pass some filter to be a valid question on ethics; no idea what that filter might be.

Questions about moral choices are in my opinion subjective, and should not be allowed. As such, the examples you provided as stated currently appear to be moral, not ethical, in nature, and in my opinion, should be closed if presented as is.

TL;DR - The name is very appropriate, and made me sign up in the first place.

I think the name is very appropriate. I signed up yesterday at StackExchange, only because I stumbled upon this exact forum. The name 'Startup' is very broad, which I believe is good to attract a broad audience. However, I think it is questionable as to whether or not this forum only attracts people dealing with 'small businesses' as many startups can be quite big. Again, this depends on the definition of a startup (some people say you are a startup until you validate a repeatable and scalable business model, some say you are a startup until an exit strategy is executed).

I think it's sometimes impossible to divide things along strict lines. We may see someone post a question about the impact obtaining a patent has on a business plan and decide that since it is tagged with the word "patent" it should be passed over to Ask Patents. But if the question had been asked there originally, they might see it and think it has too much focus on business implications and pass it over here. Who was right? Well, it depends on the question being asked.

Depending on the specifics of that theoretical question, it's possible the people on either site could have answered it and it would have fit in (though they almost certainly would have given different answers) with the rest of the content on the respective sites.

On the other hand it's certainly possible that the question belonged one place more than the other.

I asked one of the patent questions on Startups. I considered posting it to Ask Patents, but felt it was a better fit here because it focused more on the business aspects of it. Could I have gotten an answer on Ask Patents? Yeah, probably so. Do I still think it fits better here? Yep.

On the other hand, when Matthew Haugen answered my question, I asked a follow-up question in the comments because he seemed knowledgeable. I think because I tried to condense it to fit in a comment it wasn't all that clear. And in retro-spect, that secondary question probably should have gone directly to Ask Patents rather than even trying to fit it in a comment.

But even though the second question about patents was a direct follow up to the first for my given situation, I think the first fits better here and the second fits better there.

If examples are required, I'd be happy to provide them, but the "give me feedback on a secret" questions are at least for me a problem that needs a solution. In real-life, if someone pulled this on me, I would not spend any time on them, and increasingly wish that there was a way to tag (and block) questions like this.

Currently, my solution is to post this comment to questions like this:

Would it be possible to just link to the product, or clearly state what service/product you're providing? If not, please consider visiting this meta-question to share your thoughts on the topic of “Give me feedback on a secret."

And here are examples of response I've received:

How to approach solving a chicken and egg customer problem?

I'm looking for generic examples of how previous customers have solved chicken-and-egg style problems, nothing too specific and including the actual service in the question would make it very narrow.

Questions like these on any other SE site would be met with a [hold] (aka [closed]) based on the question being "Too Broad" in my experience.

Meaning of "Too Broad"

There are either too many possible answers, or good answers would be too long for this format. Please add details to narrow the answer set or to isolate an issue that can be answered in a few paragraphs.
Title: "Give me feedback on a secret"

Body:
The poster of a question should provide enough detail to make sure the question is answerable and on-topic. Not enough specificity may mean the question is difficult to accurately answer, but adding too many details in the post is just fluff that clutters up the question.

The amount of detail required for a question varies for each question, so we can't come up with a strict rule like you must link to your company. If you believe a question doesn't have enough details to be answerable, comment and ask for some specifics. On the other hand, if a poster spends too much of the post babbling about their company, feel free to suggest an edit to clean up the extra fluff.

In order to help make the closing process clearer for voters and askers, we've started customizing the off-topic reasons on the site. Hopefully, these will give posters a better idea of why their question was closed, so they can more easily improve it and have it be reopened.

This newest reason comes almost directly from what not to ask in the help center.

Questions seeking general brainstorming or review ("What do you think of this idea?") are off-topic because questions here are expected to be relevant for a variety of people in the same situation. Reviewing an idea or product only helps one person at a specific time. Instead, try asking about a specific business approach and cite yours as an example.

To give credit where credit is due, this was inspired by the following reason on UX.SE.

Questions about Site Reviews are off-topic because questions here are expected to be relevant for a variety of people in the same situation. Reviewing a site, flow or interface only helps one person at a specific time. Instead try to ask a focused question about a particular aspect of the design that solicits solutions, not opinions.

Feedback, of course, is welcome. If you disagree with this reason, have any questions or think the wording should be improved, leave a comment or answer here.

Along with the recommendation reason this will appear under Close -> off-topic because.... when casting a close vote. If none of these reasons fit, you can still create your own off-topic message.
Title: New Vote to Close Reason

Body:
We all want more users. More questions, more answers, better content. So we, your moderating staff, have begun to think it's high time to start running some community promotion ads to start reaching out on other Stack Exchange network sites for new users.

Code Review and Programming Puzzles & Code Golf have each had success with these sorts of promotions, and we're in a good position now with a solid user base and high-quality content to start attracting some more eyes.

Basically, a community ad is just what it sounds like, and this is where you guys come in. Hop in your favorite image manipulation application and build an ad for Startups Stack Exchange, vote on which ones you like best, and in a bit (probably a week or two) we'll pull out the highest-voted ones and put them on another site or two. The rest is pretty much up to you!

There are, however, a couple guidelines that must be followed:

  • The image that you create must be 220 x 250 pixels
  • Must be hosted through our standard image uploader
  • Must be GIF or PNG
  • No animated GIFs
  • Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB

Also, give your ad a border.

But beyond that, it's up to you what the content is, as long as it drives users back to our site and follows the typical community guidelines of what constitutes appropriate content here. So get those creative juices flowing! Also, if you have several ideas, great! But please limit them to one per answer, since that makes voting easier for everyone.

Be sure to include with your submission where the ad should point to. Yes, it has to be on Startups. But it can be our homepage, a specific question, or any other page here that you think will draw new users in.

Whether you've created an ad candidate or not, we have another question to answer. Where should our ads run? So far, we're thinking The Workplace would be a nice target, but we're open to other suggestions too. And it doesn't have to be just one site. So if you know of a site on the Stack Exchange network that you think would be open to having our ads present, let us know in the comments below and we will speak with their moderators for the go-ahead to post there. If your ad is designed with a specific target site in mind, just be sure to mention that.

And finally, if you have a great idea but not the artistic talent to back it, we'd love to hear that too. Just bring it up in the comments and hopefully someone else will bring it to life.

Update: We've launched one ad on The Workplace! Thanks, blunders, for the design.

Update 2: We've added another on Game Development. Thanks, Matthew Haugen.
Title: Ads to help promote this site?

Body:
UPDATE: Vote Now! This AD has been posted to Workplace.SE's 2014 Community Promotion ADs list; more votes = more traffic for Startups.SE.

Version 001

Version 002

Version 003

(If it's not clear, selected this based on the theme of "programmers + startups = traffic" for us.)

Version 001

Version 002

INSPIRATION: Startup Metrics for Pirates: AARRR!

You can see how the site is performing against key metrics here. At time of writing, the three volume metrics (questions, avid users, daily visits) all sit below 25% of "healthy," with the first 90 day milestone fast approaching.

If we're going to get from here to viability, we need to do some things very differently, and we need to do some very different things.

One approach is community ads across the network, covered in this question. At @connor's suggestion, I've posted this question to prompt other ideas and other directions.

As a comparison, the previous site hit an "excellent" on all measures except questions per day, which at 4.9 was higher than we stand now but nowhere near the 15 viability target. Content from that site was cloned elsewhere, but the resulting non-SE site doesn't have strong vital signs, and few of the 449 avid users of the SE original have followed through (we have 44 at time of writing).

It's tempting to suggest that if you try the experiment twice, with different people, and it doesn't work out, then you're done. Only where I live, I'm seeing more people than ever before getting into the startup world, and with questions that need answering. So while I don't believe the Stack Exchange Q&A model is right for every context, I think we should at least push for scale.

What are your ideas? It's not quite the usual etiquette, but I suggest that some of the most fruitful answers could themselves be questions, leaving the comments thread for people to suggest ways. For instance, "how could we get traction with Startup Weekend and similar event attendees?" Upvote what excites you, and if some directions emerge, let's get busy!
Title: What can we do to double the site's utility, then double it again?

Body:
I don't think it's fair to compare this site to the Answers.OnStartups beta. We're still in our initial 90 day period, while the previous site had been going for a few years. The other site is going to beat us in all counting stats.

I'm not trying to make excuses for our metrics, they definitely are lower than where they should be, but they aren't the end-all be-all. What Stack Exchange looks for is a community they think can be self-sustaining. It can't be captured in a few metrics, and they felt that after a few years the previous proposal had deteriorated too much to ever be viable.

It's worth looking to see where how we compare to our peers.

Startups (80 days)

  • 3.1 questions per day
  • 93% answered
  • 44 avid users
  • 1,127 total users -2.3 answer ratio
  • 116 visits/day

5 most recent beta sites:

Emacs (25 days)

  • 14.3 questions per day
  • 95% answered
  • 74 avid users
  • 1,147 total users
  • 2.1 answer ratio
  • 817 visits/day

Worldbuilding (32 days)

  • 10 questions per day
  • 99% answered
  • 104 avid users
  • 1,234 total users
  • 3.9 answer ratio
  • 2,975 visits/day

Moderators (81 days)

  • 1.1 questions per day
  • 100% answered
  • 62 avid users
  • 648 total users
  • 2.8 answer ratio
  • 49 visits/day

Hinduism (122 days)

  • 3.7 questions per day
  • 82% answered
  • 72 avid users
  • 930 total users
  • 1.9 answer ratio
  • 1,182 visits/day

Business Betas

Quantative Finance (1356 days)

  • 3.6 questions per day
  • 80% answered
  • 317 avid users
  • 7,055 total users
  • 2.0 answer ratio
  • 3,073 visits/day

Bitcoin (1144 days)

  • 5.1 questions per day
  • 87% answered
  • 385 avid users
  • 13,158 total users
  • 1.8 answer ratio
  • 5,458 visits/day

Project Management (1348 days)

  • 1.4 questions per day
  • 99% answered
  • 278 avid users
  • 9,222 total users
  • 3.7 answer ratio
  • 3,517 visits/day

While Emacs and Worldbuilding are off to great starts, those aren't the norm. Emacs had a very active and quick startup process which helps alot, while the startups proposal took a few months to pick up steam, so many of our committers (93.9%) have not followed through on their commitment.

One of the advantages Worldbuilding has over us, is that it produces hot questions. Questions with funny titles like How do I drug a population in the most efficient way? bring a lot of curious traffic to the site. I think I've only seen one or two startups questions appear as hot network questions. Better to learn programming, or hire a programmer? was probably an interesting hot question, because much of the Stack Exchange network is about programming.

It looks like all of the business proposals can build up a large mass of users and do well with views per day, but even after years of beta still struggle with questions per day. If we continue at this pace, we'd likely end up like one of those sites.

I don't have a specific plan for improving our sites metrics, but a few general ideas.

Increase Site Scope

We've had some discussions dating back the the initial proposal on whether the startsups definition was too strict and vague. Is our name appropriate? never really gained much traction though. We allow questions from all businesses, regardless of whether or not they consider themselves a startup, as long as it's on-topic for the site. The site name may disuade potential users though.

Attract New Users

This is what the advertising post is trying to achieve. Even if we don't appear on the hot network questions, we can still have sidebar ads on other sites.

Some other ideas may be promoting this site with other startup communities.

Community Building Events

As we get new users, how do we keep them involved? Right now our chat room is pretty quiet most days. One idea could be to have some sort of "Show Startups" event, where everyone gets a chance to show off what they've been working on.

Sorry if this is all jumbled, I just wanted to get some thoughts out there.

Before focusing on volume, I personally would like to make sure that SE and the community agrees that we're heading down the right path in terms of where we are at with the community and it's content; meaning my understanding this is currently the only issue we need to worry about via Tim Post's public beta announcement "Put simply, unless we see the site overrun with extremely poor quality questions and spam, and no one doing anything about it, you've got a site."

Simply put, it is my understanding that the stats you're referencing are meaningless as far as SE is concerned. What matters to SE is high quality content and an active community that at is inline with SE's views of how to mod a Q&A site. Until we've got sign-off on the content and community, it does not make sense to focus on anything else in my opinion.

Last time I checked SE does not have a way for a community member to setup a number of different URLs, track the clicks and conversions from them, get a list of the users that converted for a given URL, etc. Is this correct?

If so, what if any resources are available for the community to track their marketing campaigns for the community, both within and outside of SE.

For example, I could use a URL redirection service with real-time link tracking, but that's only going to give me clicks, not conversions, nor would it allow me to do down-stream analysis on the quality of users a given approach was generating.
Title: Options for tracking community marketing campaigns

Body:
You are correct. There's no way to gather that information, even for moderators. The best you'd be able to do is your CTR tracking, but of course I understand the pitfalls of that.

The only way users or moderators have of knowing results of promotions is through the Announcer, Booster, and Publicist badges, and of course they say nothing more than click-throughs, and only in huge, non-useful increments.

I imagine the data is collected, and thus I imagine Community Managers or other Stack Exchange employees can review it, but in general they're pretty secretive about on-site analytics.

You could always try posting a feature-request over on Meta Stack Exchange and see if you get any bites, but I wouldn't really expect it to go through, because I imagine you're dealing with a small enough crowd of people who want to promote the site and know how to utilize such analytics, and as I said, SE probably wouldn't be too down for it. But you never know. It could be useful.

Jeremy Parsons requested I post my comment to his question as a new question, so I am:

I'm interested, have an idea too; email the users directly from the old Startup.SE site requesting they join this site.

General gist is that in theory it's possible to get all the emails of users on the old Startup.SE send them a single email letting them know about the new site; meaning SE might be willing to do this for us, and if they are not it is possible to get the emails by brute force from the Gravatar email hash.

As for SE's position on the topic, might or might not be a good idea to ask them before investing to much time, either since they'd see the campaign as better left undone or might be in the position to help. That said, there are existing comments that lead me to believe that it is possible SE might be okay with this approach:

"this is probably the one GOOD use for that email hash"

Source: Shog9 ♦ (SE Community Manager) on Feb 19, 2014 at 2:47

Please note that the use of Shog9's is not meant to be an endorsement, but intended to provide potential insight and background, nothing more.

Worth noting that it appears Bright Journey did this with some success, and that they also use the Gravatar email hash, so in theory we could reach out to their users too.
Title: Campaign: Directly Engaging Existing Community

Body:
I'm definitely for this idea, though I also wonder if this happened before. (For instance, I think I found out about startups.se from exactly that kind of email.)

To prepare for that, I think some kind of clear and positive statement needs to be available on meta, to avoid the potential scepticism, or worse, from people who may feel they were let down last time round.
Are question relating to payments topical? I'm especially thinking about non-standard currencies such as bitcoin.
Title: Are questions related to payments on topic?

Body: I would say so; income and specifically the receiving of payment is of paramount importance to any business.

I think that this is a bad idea.

SE felt (for whatever reason) that OnStartups was unsalvageable and had to be closed.

If its community was to arrive here (potentially en-masse), wouldn't their culture/expectations/etc. inevitably lead to this site becoming "OnStartups 2" and thereby falling victim to the same problems that led to the original site's closure?

I think that a far better suggestion (and one that I have made a number of times before) would be to target those who committed to the Area51 proposal for this site and incentivise them to participate!

Per Shog9:

Just to clarify (since it's a bit hard to extract the context of that quote): the "one GOOD use" I was referring to was the use of the email hash to demonstrate ownership and thus allow authors to claim their posts. NOT the folks who spammed uninterested users. Please don't do that! – Shog9♦

Honestly feel as it related to growing communities that the community is in a blackbox when it comes to understanding and working with SE to grow the communities.

How is SE investing in growing communities? What are SE expections related to communities growth? Does SE expect communities to grow communities?
Title: What are SE expections related to community growth?

Body:
Without calling anyone out specifically (though I can link examples if that's helpful), I've seen a number of instances both on my own questions and others where people have provided answers which actually seem like decent answers on the surface... until you realize they don't actually address the question asked.

For example:

Q: How do I do "X"?

I am aware of solutions "Y" and "Z" but have determined that my business needs to do "X" - how do I do that?

A: "X" has a lot of issues with it that you must be prepared for, it will be easier to do "Y" because...

The person may provide a very convincing argument for their point (in this case all the ways that "Y" is better/easier than "X"), but it still doesn't answer the original question of how to do "X".

What is the appropriate way to handle this?
Down vote? Flag? Comment explaining the issue?
Click the back button and forget it ever happened?

Edit for clarity: I am not referring to instances which may occur where someone is asking how to do something which would be illegal or even necessarily against best practices. Those instances may require a different approach.
Title: What is the appropriate response to an answer that answers a question you weren't asking?

Body:
I think it's best to comment first and explain why the answer doesn't work for you. It could be a misunderstanding or maybe "X" is actually impossible and you must try an alternative.

If the answer is off-topic, but still valuable, you could suggest the answerer ask a similar question and answer it themselves. Answering your own questions is allowed and encouraged as long as it's a quality post.

Flags shouldn't be used for wrong answers. See How do I properly use the “Not an Answer” flag? on Meta Stack Exchange.

You can feel free to downvote whatever you like as long as you aren't gaming the system. Some people may immediately downvote an answer they think is harmful, while others don't want to spend the reputation point. Personally, I'd give the answerer a chance to edit their answer before downvoting.

Avoids temptation to ironically answer this with an explanation of why those types of answers are bad.

Connor beat me to the punch on most of this, but there were a few things I wanted to throw in as well.

I think the best approach is to down-vote and comment (not necessarily in that order). If you see a single user doing that a lot (a few times, anyway), you could custom-flag one of their posts and let us know. Just be sure to include whatever supporting evidence you can--other posts, comment threads, chat conversations, meta posts, etc..

As you may be aware, there're tons and tons of meta discussions out there about what a "Not an Answer" flag actually means. It's primarily an issue on bigger sites, but basically, over-worked moderators with thousands of pending flags don't want to be bothered (with good reason) by having to read through every single answer anyone ever disagrees with (whether it's obvious or not why they do). The precedent we currently work under seems to be that "not an answer" is used for "Thanks!" or "Did you ever get this working?" If an answer makes an honest attempt to answer a question, NAA probably isn't appropriate for that.

In certain circumstances, flagging as Very Low Quality might be appropriate. That's a tough one, of course, because not all posts like that actually are very low quality, as you've said, but that's appropriate for relatively short or obvious cases that you're talking about. It's really more a subjective matter there than anything, but it depends on how clear the post will be to reviewers.

I started out writing this as a comment but I think making it it's own answer makes more sense:

I just want to point out that even doing the email by hand (as you said you were planning in a comment on @eggyal's answer) rather than bulk can violate CAN-SPAM and similar laws if not done properly. This could get both you and SE into hot water if you are perceived to be doing it on their behalf - though ultimately, I would assume most (or all) of the responsibility would end up landing on you since you don't officially have their support. I don't know if SE legally has those old users' permission to email at this point, but you certainly don't, so it would almost certainly be illegal for you to grab those emails and send invites.

Whether it would actually end up being a legal issue, I don't know (who knows, maybe no one will complain at all - maybe they'll all be excited to hear from you), but I certainly wouldn't recommend going down that path.

Based on this question: What can we do to double the site's utility, then double it again? , we've been trying to come up with ideas such as Campaign: Directly Engaging Existing Community and Ads to help promote this site? to promote Startups.SE.

What do you think about a Show your Startup event? It would likely be a featured meta post. You could answer the post to tell us about what your startup has been working on and get feedback (and maybe a few customers) from other users. Do you think this would be a good community-building event?
Title: What do you think of a show your startup event?

Body:
Guessing that everyone here is aware of the need to reach consensus when undertaking actions on part of the community, but what increasingly is unclear to me is what level of competence a given community member has on a given topic, and when consensus is really consensus given what a small sample size we have.

What does consensus mean on Startups.SE-meta?
Title: With such a small sample size, what does consensus mean on Startups.SE-meta?

Body:
Consensus here means the same thing as it does on any other site--the contributing users fall mostly on a particular side of the discussion. The fact that our site is smaller has no effect on that, except that "the contributing users" is going to be a much smaller sample than, say, if Stack Overflow had the same discussion.

The key, and I know Connor has said this to you in chat as well, is patience. Just like it doesn't happen on Stack Overflow (and I'm picking that as a random example, this applies to every site) that someone posts an idea, waits a day, then goes forward with it, we can't expect our meta posts to move forward too quickly either.

Think of our community-ads-related post. That was up for quite some time, but by the time we took it down, it was pretty clear how people were responding. The same was true with our names post, as well as our "new VTC reason" posts. Everything takes time on here. And we're all excited about it, and that time is sometimes difficult to hold through, but that's the only solution.

There's not going to be a solid "this is what a consensus looks like" answer because it's different for each post.

As the owner of a startup, I (and no doubt many others) have a LOT of questions along the lines "what's the general trend for..." These are questions designed to provide a basic understanding of what is normal vs what is exceptional in a given area, so you can then evaluate specific proposals or options with more experience.

For example:

  • "How much should I budget for hiring an entry-level social media promotions company?"
  • "What are common price ranges for a service like _____________?"
  • "What salary levels would be expected if I offered a position like ___________?"
  • "What is a reasonable bounce rate for a new dating website?"

These questions are somewhat opinion-based, in the sense that different people have differing ideas of what is "normal" or "reasonable," but at the same time there can be valid, objective answers that explore various scenarios and offer ranges (e.g. "I offered between $10-20/hr for a position like that" or "for that kind of website expect an average 60-80% bounce rate") based on experience and research, which could be incredibly valuable to the OP.

Are these types of questions permissible on Startups SE? I feel like they might be very popular, if other users are anything like me and benefit from having a general idea of the playing field before taking action, but I don't want to start posting things that go against the rules of the site for being too opinion-based or open-ended.
Title: Are "general trend" questions on-topic?

Body:
That's an interesting question. I would say that those are on topic, as long as they hold enough information to be objectively answerable. Reading your question, you clearly recognize that need for information, so I'd say yes, these are on-topic.

We've had a couple posts about how to define opinion-based here, and that linked to the always-useful Good Subjective, Bad Subjective blog post. Long story short, again, I think it just falls on how much information is presented.

That all said, I think better (or, well, less controversial) ways of asking those questions might be something like these.

  • I'm thinking of paying $x an hour for a developer, is that reasonable?
  • My bounce rate is currently x% on my dating website. Is that around normal? I'm running ads that point to the z and c pages and they're performing [like this], what could I do to improve the bounce rate?

Both would need a fair bit more detail, clearly, but you see my point. I think there are other, more specific ways to ask the questions you're getting at, that would be less likely to bring people to the close button, although personally I probably wouldn't either way.

Although, that all said, come to think of it, the only real difference here in content of the question or expected answer is that these questions include the precious "what have you tried" already in them ("I think this amount is reasonable," "this is my bounce rate") and questions with that are off-the-bat generally going to be better and find more meaningful answers. They'll give answerers a running start to go off of, and I think that's valuable.

+1 for the concept, because real world show-and-tell among peers is hugely important in the startup world

If it gets traction, the mechanics need some thought, so it's (a) useful, (b) manageable, (c) repeatable.

That makes me think that you would want the head question to focus attention on some specific type or aspect of startups, to allow the answer to be "look what I've done," and to make use of upvoting and comments as natural as possible.

So for instance, suppose we had the tag show-and-tell, then there might be a featured question "What do you need for a great MVP landing page?" inviting answers direct from startups. You could put some pizzazz around that for a limited period, and it would continue to have value later. (Well, subject to the usual challenge that if the answer is more in the link than the text, what people find at that link is going to change. So maybe there's a recommendation at least that people capture screenshots as well as linking live content.

Over time, that tag could become both a welcome regular feature, and also a valuable repository. I can imagine a growth hack show-and-tell question doing very well drawing traffic!

So I'm probably one of the guilty parties... To defend the practice, there are lots of questions with major embedded assumptions, so the most direct answer may have the least value to the questioner and to subsequent readers.

The thing is, in SE generally this isn't something you have to worry about. If the answer is largely orthogonal (pure spam, say), downvotes and other measures are there. Otherwise, answers, upvoting and acceptance are the right tools.

Upvotes help identify the wisdom of the crowd, so that the most supported answer is right there at the top.

Acceptance signals the questioner's personal verdict of best answer, with that lovely green tick.

And where an answer prompts someone else to add a better one, that's a sign of the SE model in healthy action. A spot-on answer that's hard to follow will prompt a new, clearly expressed answer, just as if the only answer isn't an answer at all, the invitation to the community through the unanswered questions view remains.

So let me just say, this is probably a super bad idea, though it could be fun. Anyway, let's you and me both suspend disbelief while I paint the picture.

The kick-off is a post on meta, asking for ideas for a startup side project. The only criterion is it has to be things that cost zero cash (or piggyback on stuff we'll have sitting around, like hosing).

Out of this, we have one? two? projects, and a bunch of volunteers who are going to commit a small but meaningful amount of time each week. After a few days or weeks, the project(s) have a landing page: this is like arriving at Go with a top hat and a bank balance.

The deal is, each time the team has a major decision to make, even if it's one where there's unanimity, they bring it back as a question. The answer that scores highest (after say 3 days, and subject to a bit of moderation to keep answerers and voters free from the temptation to just make outrageous suggestions) is then what to do next.

If a team can't run with the answer, it's bankrupt. Otherwise, it runs on to the next decision to bring back to Startups.SE.

The idea isn't to create the world's best startup, but to get some questions that are not only real and timely, but where the answers get applied, and the community gets the next question.

So like I say, this is probably a super bad idea. The only merit is, if I heard this was happening somewhere on the Internet, I would want to watch or take part!

So, virtual colleagues, what about a Startups.SE startup?
Title: What about a Startups.SE startup?

Body:
Our AD on GameDev.SE still needs one more upvote to be on the list of ADs displayed on that site. Please upvote the AD. Thanks!

While you're at it, if you have not already upvoted our Workplace.SE, please do so; already has enough upvotes to be on the list (we're getting 8+ clicks a day) - but more upvotes means more AD views, which means more clicks too. Thanks!
Title: Request to upvote Startups.SE AD on GameDev.SE (2014)

Body:
I see various meta campaigns on this site soliciting and promoting ads to attract new members to this community. Unfortunately, the winners you selected all say to go to "startups.se".

I like the ad, but the destination you listed is sending people to the wrong place.

While http://startups.se doesn't strictly resolve to anything useful, the folks at photo.se (just to cite another example) have thanked me on a few occasions now for all the inadvertent traffic we're sending them.

The insider jargon you use here (Startups.se) works fine when everyone becomes accustomed to what it means… but for everyone else — all the people who aren't accustomed to this meta-speak — are not going to know what you're actually advertising. I think the logo at the top of the ad needs to be reworked.
Title: Your community ad sends people to the wrong place

Body:
This is a really interesting point. We definitely want to make sure not to confuse new users, since--and this is more or less just subjective observation--I'd probably say around half of our users are fairly new to Stack Exchange in general.

Blunders has kindly addressed the issue on one running ad, and I handled the other. So we should be all good now, and we'll definitely be sure to keep this in mind in the future. Thanks for your guidance, Robert!

Just experienced a weird synergistic moment that might also provide an answer to this meta-question. I was on the startups exchange, looking this question, Outside of a startup accelerator, how does one network with other startups?.

While I was reading the question, I noticed the sidebar which showed...

...which got me thinking...

Maybe if you added some features to help exchange members connect with other geographically close exchange members (within a given subject like "startups"), it would ad value to your site from the exchange members' point of view. That in turn would motivate higher traffic levels which might assist you in your pursuit of metrics.

I know that you have extensive chat features, so maybe this would just involve adding a geographic filter to the "setting up a chat room" feature. Maybe it wouldn't even require any software changes; you could just post some policies about how to politely set up geographically focused chat rooms, then invite members (like the poster of the question which I referenced) get it started.

When someone posts a question about your question as an answer instead of a comment what is the appropriate way to respond?

Should I just flag the post and move on? Comment on the post and let them know their mistake?

I always try to sandwich feedback between to complements if possible because I think it is more effective that way but I don't know if that is appropriate. Something to the order of:

"That's a great question! I actually meant this --> blah blah blah. I'll be sure to clarify that in my question. For future reference remember to post questions like this in the comments section below the initial question because it is easier to keep track of questions and comments vs. answers this way! Thanks for joining startups.se!"

If this is the wrong way to do it than should we have a more standard response just to make sure people don't feel slighted if we treat them differently?
Title: What is the best way to remind someone of SE policies?

Body:
I actually just handled the flag you're talking about, by converting the "answer" to a comment.

Just to be clear to anyone else who happens to read this, the particular answer was a one line question, meant to clarify information from the original asker.

Long story short, the one, most correct thing to do is exactly what you did. Flag the answer as "Not an Answer." There've been a lot of discussions across the Stack Exchange network on what exactly "NAA" flags are for (specifically, people try to use them for answers that are technically wrong but still attempt to answer the question, which is not a valid flag), but this was definitely a good time to use one.

Beyond that, the rest is just icing on the cake. We do have a standard response to these types of questions (although that's often more relevant on bigger sites, where moderators such as myself won't get to the post quite as quickly), and I'll get to that next, but ultimately if you feel the drive to write your own, I'd say go ahead. You clearly aren't being mean, which is the one thing that wouldn't be okay, so helping your community members is a great thing.

Many posts like these end up in what's called the "Low Quality Posts" review queue. I'm not sure if you're familiar with review queues, but for anyone who isn't, they're ways for users to help keep a targeted eye on moderating the site. They're made available as a privilege at 350 rep points (higher on graduated sites). You can read a bit more about them here, but speaking more specifically to this case, an automated process actually flagged this as being not-so-great, so it was ready to show up in that review queue.

In the review queue, users get the option of "recommending deletion" on answers that aren't really up to the quality standards of the site. When doing so, we're given the option of several comment templates to use. The relevant one here would be:

This does not provide an answer to the question. To critique or request clarification from an author, leave a comment below their post - you can always comment on your own posts, and once you have sufficient reputation you will be able to comment on any post.

So as you mentioned, yes, we have a standard way of responding to these posts.

Just last month, a member of the Stack Exchange Community Team suggested to sites around the network that we begin having "weekly topic challenges," and I'm interesting to see our take on that.

Several other sites have taken part and done such challenges with great success. You can read through some of the answers on that Meta Stack Exchange post for some more details on which sites have attempted challenges and what topics they've done them for.

I think the example Jon posted in that meta post is great, where the Cooking SE site could have a BBQ theme for the week leading up to Memorial Day. Ultimately, the general principle is straight-forward: let's drive the community to create great content centered around some specific theme by inspiring people to ask about that theme.

We'll start in a week or two on our first one, but to do that, we need topic ideas. If you have an idea for a topic, post it as an answer below (with only one topic per post, please). Topics can relate to real-world events (like the BBQ example), or they can relate more broadly to things you'd like to see more of here on Startups.

Once we have some votes, so probably in a week or two, we'll make a "challenge" post here on meta that announces the winning topic. Then it's just a matter of everyone asking (and answering) questions on a related and given tag or set of tags. Participation, obviously, is strictly voluntary, and business will go on as usual aside from this.

When the week is over, another moderator or myself will post the results (how much participation there was) as an answer to that challenge post, then we'll move onto the next topic-answer down on this post and start the process over again.

So get thinking! Let's come up with some awesome topics that we want to see more of on the site.
Title: What would make a good Weekly Topic Challenge?

Body:
Small Business

A lot of the questions on this site are silicon valley type startups. Here's a chance for a local coffee shop, family farm or mom and pop shop to shine.

Intellectual Property

This is already a pretty popular topic on the site, but I don't think there's any harm in focusing a week on it. Get all your copyright, patent and trademark questions ready.

Nonprofits

This one is a bit out of left field. I don't think we've seen any questions about non-profit startups, but they definitely exist and I'm sure they have questions.

Startup’ has always meant a for-profit company, but a charity can operate much like one.

-- Paul Graham

-------Complete-------

Pivoting

Plenty of startups are struggling to see how to get from the idea they love but the crowds didn't roll in, to a new focus that doesn't throw away the learning, motivation and momentum. Getting from theory to some practical ways to identify options, choose a route and plan next steps could be a great way to tap the wisdom of the crowd.

-------Complete-------

Seasonal Business Practices

Topics: Tax planning, Inventory Management, Seasonal Leases, Cashflow, Gift Cards, Promotions, Hiring, Off-Season Marketing, Off-Season Customer Development, etc.

Last year Stack Exchange ran Winter Bash 2013, and they've decided to do it again this winter. From December 15th to January 4th, users will be able to earn special hats based on tasks or accomplishments on the site. They can then display their favorite hats on their profile and avatar.

This is all for fun and games, but users who don't want to participate can individually opt out with an "I hate hats" button. In addition, the Winter Bash is activated on a site by site basis, so if you think Startups should not participate, voice your opinion here. The Startups mods will relay your thoughts to the community team.

If there isn't a consensus for opting out of the winter bash event, Startups will be automatically opted in. The deadline is December 1st.
Title: Do we like hats?

Body:
I love hats!

Hats for all! Bring on the hats!

Is there a special hat for double negative of the week? Please don't count me in to the potential consensus for opting out of hats.

(Or for logic knots. Assuming @connor isn't against the idea, no consensus to opt out can exist.)

Anyway, as a professional wearer of odd clothing, I would love some odd hats to go with it. So bring 'em on!

I’ve no idea about building Stack Exchange communities, but I am aware of one existing startup-related community, specifically for startups that aim to be self-funding: http://discuss.bootstrapped.fm/.

It’s a forum spun off from the podcast ‘Bootstrapped’. I think it was somewhat inspired by Joel Spolsky’s old Business of Software Forums, and I believe the software it uses is Discourse, a project created by one Jeff Atwood.

Those guys might appreciate a Stack Exchange focused on a similar topic.

This is what I'm referencing - Do adverts on a startup website do more harm than good?

If a user comments on the answer you gave basically saying they thought it was a good response should we mention the concept of upvotes and accepting answers? I don't want to seem like I'm grubbing for rep, but it makes sense to remind askers the mechanics of SE.

Thoughts on a good way to do this?
Title: What to do if a user comments on your question thanking you but doesn't upvote or accept answer?

Body:
Heh, I actually asked this very question way back when, when I was new-ish to Stack Exchange! :)

This has been asked before on Meta Stack Overflow, as I learned. The general consensus is that' it's okay to poke the person a bit, as long as you're subtle.

Accepted answers help everyone, so as long as your comment addresses that and doesn't sound like "give me my fifteen rep points!" you'll probably be fine.

The accepted answer on that particular post is pretty harsh, saying that you should never leave such a comment if the person has ever accepted an answer in the past, since that means they know how and might have chosen against it. I'm not completely sure I agree on that, but the sentiment is true. It's really just a judgment call. When in doubt, I'd advise against commenting. But if you're pretty sure the person meant to and forgot, and they're "pretty new" (I'll leave that up to interpretation) to the system, that's okay.

Sometimes people take a long time to accept answers (because they want to explore options or they're just slow at such things), so it's generally good to give them some time, even after they comment. I'd also be much more hesitant if there were a couple answers given, because sometimes the user will go through and comment on each, then accept one that you might not have thought was better than yours. In that event, of course, you wouldn't want to comment.

In this particular case, yeah, I think it's probably alright to, as you have, comment and ask the person. In the future, I'd be tempted to include a link to the FAQ post "How does accepting an answer work?", just because that gives the person a resource and makes it a bit more about teaching.

If I were to leave such a comment, it'd probably look something like this:

Awesome! I'm glad I could help. Is there anything else I can help with, or does that answer your question? If it does, I'd appreciate if you could accept this answer so it can be more easily found by users in the future with similar problems. Otherwise, let me know and hopefully I can clarify for you.

I didn't count characters on that, so it might be a bit too long (I'm such a bad judge of character count, so it could easily not be), but you see the gist. I make it more about helping others, which is really the main goal of accepting answers, even if we do all love the rep, and doesn't work off of the assumption that we completely answered the question, even if the person has already hinted at it.

Ultimately, trying to explain this all is probably more difficult than putting into action. If you honestly think the person would benefit from the reminder, go ahead. But don't make too much a habit of it, because if you're doing it a lot, that's probably indicative that you aren't being super careful with it.

I guess another note is that sometimes, people flag comments like this as "Not Constructive." In such cases, I'd typically let the comment hang out for a little while, then delete it. I don't think that's ever actually happened here, but eventually it will. So don't be too upset if a comment like that does get deleted. But generally you want to catch new users pretty quickly anyway.

This is a multiple part question with a few ironies in part 2 but if this question should be broken up into multiple questions for clarity lets do that. I thought it might make sense to include them all here for a more in-depth answer for future users with all the same questions.

  1. If there are questions clearly in need of legal advice on the site should we be answering them? I'm not talking as much about about questions like 'pros and cons of LLC vs. Sole Proprietor', but more so the questions about legal liability which generally fall into the formula of 'can I do this legally?' or 'can I do this and avoid liability'

  2. Can users safely speak from personal experience without legal liability on the site?

  3. Should we develop some standard responses/comments to add to questions that clearly need a lawyer to fully answer? For example, if we see a question that clearly needs a lawyer then can we or should we try to always add a comment like "With legal questions it is always good to speak with a lawyer for a more definitive answer as contributors are not all legal experts."

There is also a potential migration site destination upcoming? It still needs quite a few contributors though.
Title: How to respond to questions that clearly need legal advice?

Body:
Stack Exchange is notoriously avoidant of questions seeking legal help. There've been a few cases of people suggesting Law as a site on Area51, it getting through commitment, then getting shot down (there's one there now, actually, although it's anyone's guess whether it will get a beta period or not). Nobody wants that liability.

But yes, as you suggest in your first question, there's definitely a line (somewhere) between what's acceptable and what's not, and I think there's an unreasonably subtle distinction between those two.

I'm not sure how we can make it less subtle--although if we could, it could make a nice third "Vote to Close" reason someday--but right now, like the legal system, I think it just depends on how it's worded, both the question and the answer. I'm okay with posts that say things like "might."

I've personally answered a number of intellectual-property questions since this site went into private beta, and anyone who reads through those will notice something of a pattern.

Well, it really depends on a few things, but chances are...

But it wouldn't be a bad thing to talk with a patent professional before continuing, to go over your specific case.

I think disclaimers like that are nice in a few ways, not the least of which being that you're reminding the asker that, hey, I don't know everything about you, your business, your competitor's business, or any of that.

The same sort of thing applies to questions. Your example, "can I do this legally?", if I were asking this question myself, I would probably say "What might be some legal risks of doing this?" The key here is in asking for the negative right: the question isn't "can I do this," but rather, "is there any reason why I can't do this?" Nobody could be qualified through a system such as this to fully answer the first question, but all the second one takes is a single point.

An important thing to remember here, is that nobody is trying to get anyone else in trouble. If someone asks a question that's blatantly deserving of an attorney's attention, that's probably because they don't realize the severity or variability of it. I know that's obvious to think about now, but it isn't always quite so clear in the heat of actually answering a question.

For that reason, I think it's good to include a sentence or two--a "legal disclaimer," albeit not quite so technical--that points out that a lawyer might be the best option.

As for your second question, I think that gets a bit more difficult to answer fully. Mostly because I honestly don't really know.

There's a related MSE post with what I think is a good answer. It quotes the Creative Commons license under which this all falls. I'll let you click through there to avoid quoting the entire answer, but essentially,

UNLESS OTHERWISE AGREED TO BY THE PARTIES IN WRITING, LICENSOR OFFERS THE WORK AS-IS AND MAKES NO REPRESENTATIONS OR WARRANTIES OF ANY KIND CONCERNING THE MATERIALS

There are a few clauses there, but they all have that kind of effect. So I definitely wouldn't worry too much about this.

But at the same time, when in doubt.... I wouldn't jump in and answer something if I thought there was reasonable concern that it could lead to a lawsuit, even if that would never happen in practice. If a question is phrased such that an answer is that risky, it's probably not a good question. That's a good time to comment, or perhaps even just edit the question and make it a bit more "negative right"-ish, as described before.

My personal answer to your third can probably be pieced together from what I've already said, but basically, yes! A standard would be great. If you're feeling like it, asking that question in a separate meta post in the scope of "should this be a Close Vote reason?" might be a good idea. We've been looking for a good third one, and that could be it.

Phew, so that's my answer (Don't take it as legal advice :) ).

But just a few extra side-notes about things to note when asking and answering questions. I'm paraphrasing a Community Manager here.

  • Make sure any legal questions are very descriptive of the actual circumstances. It's surprisingly easy for these questions to become either too broad or primarily opinion-based, and neither of those lead to productive posts.

  • Make sure legal questions include the location, and make sure you're mindful of it when answering. I've done that a few times in the past--a person asks a question, I get halfway through writing an answer, realize they didn't specify their location, learn they're somewhere completely unrelated to what I had assumed, and scrap the answer.

  • (This speaks something to your second question, as well) Anecdotes aren't an appropriate way to answer a legal question. Make sure any answer is backed up with evidence. That's generally true of questions here, but it's particularly relevant for legal ones.

Am I allowed to speed on my way to work?

Of course! I do it practically every day and I've never gotten a ticket.

This question got a bit of interest. Answers to this questions are pitches to form a team for possibly the oddest startup in history.

Criteria are as follows:

  1. The primary goal is to run a bootstrap project where every major decision is made by asking a question on startups.SE and going with the leading answer

  2. Projects should consume spare time and spare resources, not cash

  3. Team members commit to a small but meaningful number of hours per week devoted to the project

  4. A suggestion is that, to avoid this starting off-course, each answer should be a domain name you are willing to pitch in, with minimal detail - the idea should be decided by the team as a whole

The idea isn't to kick off a zillion projects, but one, maybe two.

Up for it? Then pitch in! Upvote your choice, and comment in the question your bid in terms of area of contribution and a realistic hours/week commitment.
Title: Would you like to be part of a Startups.SE startup? -- EXPIRED

Body:
Enhash.com

Enhash started out as a student project focusing on an opportunity in the relatively early days of twitter. The idea was a slick way to add value to existing hashtags, with the idea of creating an API for twitter apps - which at the time were multiplying.

That gap has long since closed, but at the same time the hashtag has grown from strength to strength across channels. (Oh, and three of the five founders went on to found and fund other startups.)

I have a few sketchy ideas about interesting markets. For instance, indie production companies are keen to build long tail value for niche shows and channels; fans are often highly motivated to build community around interesting content; bridging the two could be a great bootstrap, because you only need one show or channel to get started, you don't need to ask permission, it's inherently simple to scrape initial content into the back end, and focusing on strong existing content lowers the bar in terms of what needs to be added to the UX day one.

However, I want to stress that I'm not wedded to that idea. If this team goes forward, it will be something funky to enhance the humble hashtag.

I see a potential issue of asking a good question by giving more details about my startup idea versus the fact that I'm announcing my idea and thus making it possible for someone to get it up and running earlier than me.

Are there good advices on what is required to mention and what is not?
Title: How to ask questions without giving too much details about the idea?

Body:
I've thought a lot about this, particularly but unexclusively since you made this meta post. And I honestly don't know. Or rather, I wish it weren't so simple.

I think the unfortunate reality is just that some things shouldn't be asked in a public arena like this. And there are lots of great questions that don't include every little detail about a business strategy.

There's lots of talk all over the Stack Exchange network about people not including enough information in questions. So much talk, even, that it's sometimes difficult to discern what "enough" even means. It feels like we're just supposed to include everything we know about a scenario.

But that's not the case. Those philosophies are targeted at sites like Stack Overflow, where there are simply enough users that the statistics add up and people start posting things like,

Sometimes when I press a button on my UI, it doesn't do what I'd expect it to.

I, of course, use that hypothetical example as hyperbole. But those are the sorts of things that we really need to avoid. The analogue here looks something like,

I'm looking to start a website, how many people should I hire?

But that doesn't mean we have to include secrets in our posts. When people do that, we end up with questions like,

Sometimes when I press a button on my UI, it doesn't do what I'd expect it to. And here's all the code I've written in the last five years, as well as my report card from seventh grade.

That's why Stack Overflow has the whole concept of a Minimal, Verifiable, and Complete example. We aren't quite so technical here, partially because we simply can't be (business questions aren't the same as code questions), but the same theory applies. Tell answerers what they need to know to give an awesome answer, but don't whittle away the hours explaining everything you learned in business school.

Take a look at the top-voted questions on our site so far. Here are the (currently) top three:

  • Better to learn programming, or hire a programmer?
  • Dividing profits amongst developers and designers
  • I have a great idea, but I'm not great at marketing or sales. How do I approach this?

Looking at them, it's clear that, while they're all great and interesting questions, not one of them divulges the actual business processes they're talking about. At most, they say something along the lines of "I'd like to write an app."

Not every great question needs to include every detail that led up to its relevance.

If your question pertains very specifically to the very specific circumstances you're facing, there's a good chance that your question could be made a bit broader to fit more people anyway.

Sometimes--normally, even--this isn't the easiest part. It's often easier (for us as askers, at least) to spit out our questions verbatim just as we're thinking about them. That's not what makes a good question here. What makes a good question is thinking through your question and bringing it down to its bare minimum. Finding relevant aspects of your situation is a task on its own, and sometimes it's hard to know what's relevant and what's not. But that's how great questions (and, in turn, answers) are formed.

There's a big difference between "this question is too broad" and "what are the last four digits of your social security number and the name of your first childhood pet?" and it's important to find and focus on that difference.

If you do run through all of this and you're still worried that you're divulging too much, as I led with, this might just not be a great place to ask that question. In business, we make a ton of decisions every day, and not all of them are completely crowd-source-able.

The best not-always-obvious solution I have for you in those edge-edge cases, where the issue is more in the hands of "I'm going to say something in my question that could offend someone I know in real life if they knew I asked it, but it's an important and on-topic question," is creating a second account. There's something of a misconception with some, where people believe it's against SE rules to have more than one account. This is not the case. What's against the rules is using a secondary account to game the system--award rep, cast multiple close-votes, etc.--but using a second account to make posts anonymous is completely fine.

Unfortunately, I don't think there is one right answer to this. And I agree that it's definitely a difficult line to find. But it's really just a judgement call that we have to make when posting questions. It has to be decided on a case-by-case basis, and you have to think about the risk-reward scenario you're setting up.
I was an active member of the OnStartups site(s) - which ultimately was discontinued by SE. How is this one going to be different?
Title: How is this different from the prior two incarnations of the SE startups sites?

Body:
Having been a part of each of those communities and SE in general, the main difference is that the current community is more inline with SE's needs based on my understanding.

Given it appears that you have yet to take part in the current Startup SE and are referencing an SE that no longer exists, let me be clear, that SE is gone and if you want to understand why, the time for that has come and gone.

Please focus on the future, not the past. Thanks!
Holding the idea sacred and not divulging it is unwarranted. Your idea is most likely not all that special.

There were some great answers that would be great to have access to. Can we import them or get the links to them? I am unable to find the Q&A archived anywhere.

For example - Joel's canonical answer to "how to split up equity"
Title: Can we link to prior answers from the previous onStartups SE site?

Body:
I can't really compare this site with OnStartups since I wasn't part of that community. The general scope of the site is the same, but we want to avoid the mistakes OnStartups ran into.

According to Stack Exchange, the site was closed because it was a dying site. Most of the top users had abandoned the site and the quality of content and moderation was suffering. Stack Exchange tried to pump life into the site, but failed each time.

I wouldn't be too worried about the status of this site. Once a site gets through the private beta, it takes some serious concern for it to be closed. We're definitely struggling with some numbers right now, but that's common for most betas. As Tim Post said in the public beta announcement:

Unless we see the site overrun with extremely poor quality questions and spam, and no one doing anything about it, you've got a site.

Tim Post (SE Community Manager) - Aug 19, 2014

Along with the moderators, I've seen many other users working to keep the site on track. I don't think we're in danger right now.

We don't want to be a copy of the old site, but there were definitely some great questions there. Early in the private beta we discussed how to handle answers from the OnStartups site here and here.

We don't want to do a bulk import, but I understand some of the good questions would help this site. If a user wants to copy a question from the old site, they are free to do so as long as they give credit to the original posters.

There is a data dump of the site on the area 51 page. Some users also created a new site with that data, but I'm not sure of the legality of copying from there.

Based on the responses from What would make a good Weekly Topic Challenge? we're going to start having weekly topic challenges starting today.

The topic this week is Seasonal Business Practices. Now is the perfect time to ask any questions you may have about business strategies in the holiday season including Tax planning, Inventory Management, Seasonal Leases, Cashflow, Gift Cards, and Promotions.

Questions related to this topic should use the tag seasonal.

Next Monday we'll make a round up post of all questions and answers during the challenge and announce the next topic. If you have any ideas for topics feel free to add them to the topics thread. We'll be working our way through that list.
Title: Weekly Topic Challenge: Seasonal Business Practices

Body:
So this site has looked into promotion as a means of stabilizing it and making this beta work. And even looked at the problems associated with the old startups SE, but still I get this feeling the site is failing.

Is the site failing? And why is the site failing?

Or am I overreacting as we have only been in Public Beta for 137 days.
Title: Are we Failing as a site?

Body:
My answer would be yes this site is failing. My reasoning:

  • Look at the visitors:

So it appears that only the users are visiting. Maybe we could work some plan for advertising out as a community.

  • Look at Questions.

I think that if we could get some more experts or any users through promotion this would help, because then they would help answer the questions.

  • Look at user quality.

The highest rep user has 2,827 which is close to 3,000 but not close enough. I don't know how to fix this problem, but maybe:

  • Vote more

  • Ask more questions

  • Maybe getting more users is the solution

So this site has a severe deficit, I think that it is early to say such a thing, but maybe if we don't it will get worse. But did this site always have some troubles.

With our current stats I don't think we are doing this:

Sites remain in beta for at least 90 days to build up a critical mass of users, questions, and participation.

We're not failing, but we haven't succeeded yet either.

The Area 51 stats are not the end all be all for betas. The process has changed a lot since Area 51 began and is long overdue for a rehaul. Stack Exchange has a much different system for graduating sites these days.

Those stats are still useful for a quick look at the health of a site though. The questions per day is the probably the statistic I look at most. It's easy to see how any one day is relative to the average. For example, yesterday we got 4 questions, so the average is improving slightly. The counting stats will increase with time, and views will come with more questions. Our questions per day average seems to fluctuate between 2-6, which slightly less than half of the goal of 10 per day, but it doesn't put us in the dead site category.

It's telling that our worst stats are labeled "Needs Work". Stack Exchange is not branding Startups as a failing site, but rather one that isn't ready to stand on its own yet.

As blunders pointed out we're fairly comparable to our peer betas. There are some doing much better and some doing much worse. We don't have the statistics to graduate right now, but very few sites are able to graduate in under a year. I elaborated a bit on this in What can we do to double the site's utility, then double it again?

There are definitely improvements to be made however. Like you mentioned, more questions and more users would help greatly, the issue is those are a little harder to obtain. We've just recently started weekly topic challenges which have helped other young sites create questions, and when 2015's advertising cycle begins we're planning on advertising on more Stack Exchange sites. Our ad on the workplace has been bringing in about 8 people a day. We're still looking for more strategies beyond the weekly topics and ads to improve these numbers, so if you have any ideas please share them.

I'm definitely a proponent of voting. More importantly than raising our number of high rep users, it helps distinguish what makes good content on the site. In fact voting is the first moderation priviledge given on all stack exchange sites because of its importance. At this stage we want good momentum and quality content, voting up certain users to hit the 3k or 2k marks won't help in the long run, but voting on quality will.

Based on some of the great content posted here, and the activity of our users, I have a lot of faith in this site succeeding, but it definitely still has some work to do.

-------Complete-------

How to Start a Startup
