Stanford class by Y Combinator covering "everything we know about how to start a startup, for free, from some of the world experts."

We've already received a few questions on the class and if there's a focus on finding questions that people are likely to search for and linking to the tag in the question itself, we'll likely get a lot of traffic from this over time. Generally, the goal would to become the source for asking questions on the class.

Here's a link to the course, "How to Start a Startup" by Sam Altman, president of Y Combinator.

The 20 videos posted to YouTube so far have 1,138,928 views, which is not bad for a video series on YouTube.

We're done! Our first weekly topic challenge has come to an end.

I'm pretty happy with the results, personally. I would have loved to see some more questions, but we did get a lot of awesome answers, which is really the goal.

Ten questions were asked by four users, with an ending tally of zero answers for three of them, one answer for each of six of them, and two answers for one of them. Most questions received between one and three up-votes at the time of closing, but I certainly expect all of them to receive more votes and answers after some time passes.

All in all, not a bad start! I'm pretty sure that none of these posts would have been made had it not been for the challenge, so we're definitely at a net gain.

As an addendum to Matthew's wrap up, here's a break down of the participating users to give credit where credit is due.

Askers

5 Questions

2 Questions

2 Questions

1 Question

Answerers

3 Answers

2 Answers

1 Answer

1 Answer

1 Answer

I'm not really making this post to announce or ask much, I just wanted to point out that we've officially hit 1000 answers! We'll likely be at 500 questions by the time many of you read this, as well.

I know there's been a lot of talk about people thinking the site hasn't been doing well (and I know Connor has always been quick to retort with the statistics that things aren't actually all that bad), but thinking back over the last 1500 posts, I can't say I remember a ton of bad ones.

We (your moderators) have the job of handling exceptions, like people who have a hard time being nice, or posts that just really shouldn't be posts, and I'll tell you straight-up, we haven't been all that busy. Of course, there's stuff to do here or there, and we've seen one or two flags over the months, but all in all, as a moderator and an avid user of the site, I would comfortably affirm that a significant majority of these 1500 posts are of high quality and convey either through personal experience or scientific research some very useful best practices in forming and running a startup or small business.

So you go, everyone!

For those worried about the state of the site, worry about quality over quantity. That's the gist of most of what Connor, Nick, and myself have said. If you have clever ways of attracting new users, all the power to you. But the absolute key to making this site last is going to be a mix of content creation and moderation. When you see a bad post, flag it, vote to close it, or vote it down. Make sure us mods are earning our diamonds, and help keep the site clear of broken windows.

On the other, and I suspect more likely, hand, when you see a great post, vote it up. Give credit where credit is due and keep people coming back when they contribute things that you like to see around here.

If we can maintain a solid user-base of content creators and user moderators, we'll do just fine, and the stats will grow.
Title: We've hit 1000 answers!

Body:
Some prior discussions occurred earlier, but it doesn't answer this question completely.

Are startup tool recommendations reasonably on topic, or are they not?

Imagine, as examples, a founder that is looking for tools that allow:

  • Marketing staff to A/B test a landing page
  • Marketing staff to chat with visitors on the site
  • Remote staff to efficiently interact together
  • Sales staff to track the progression of their sales funnel
Title: Are tool recommendations on topic?

Body:
Preface: It's always a bad sign when a post has a preface. The official answer is no, and the unofficial answer is "it depends." I'm about to go over the pros and cons of allowing them, partially in an effort to expose the thought process that we have and partially in an effort to show you how you can ask a resource question that's good, useful, and on-topic.

We've definitely thought about this since the site entered private, and particularly public, beta. And the discussion is far from over.

We do have a vote-to-close reason set up, so technically, no, they are currently more or less not on-topic. But the idea has come up a couple times in moderator chat of opening that up.

Our goal--and this is obvious, but stay with me--is to provide and host awesome content. Everyone here, I figure, holds that common goal. "Awesome content" is hard to define, and indeed if you point at a post, one person might say "yeah!" as another is running in fear, but ultimately there are some standards that Stack Exchange has put forth about how we want the site to look and feel, and there are some commonalities on which pretty well anyone who cares will agree.

My personal hesitation with recommendation posts of this kind is that they don't always turn into awesome content.

Me being critical

I came across a post the other day, and I'm not linking to it because that's irrelevant, but here's the actual, full quote:

Computer Generated Content

I need a piece of software that will scan multiple websites (of the user's choosing) and write a short informative piece about the topic. I need it to be compatible with Mac or Linux and be moderately quick.

linux osx

That's not awesome content. Granted, of course, it was put on hold within two hours of being posted, but you see my point. I'm assuming that the asker of this question felt that that was enough. We're small business owners here, so most of us probably know: sometimes people have a difficult time accurately conveying their needs.

I don't want to see our homepage flooded with questions like this. I'm not saying that's going to happen, but it's a risk.

Beyond that, there's the simple nature of off-site resources: they're, well, off-site. Because of that:

  • They're not self-contained, and I have to click a link to ensure validity of an answer.
  • They'll mostly expire eventually, either in accuracy or direct content (some new software blows the suggestion out of the water, or the suggestion goes out of business).

On top of that, they're generally fairly opinion-based, whether they have to be or not.

In short, software and tools requests require a different type of moderation (by users and us diamonded folks) than other posts. That's okay, but it's an investment we have to be ready to take on as a collective site, and it's something we want to make sure we're into before we jump too fast.

Beyond that, too, I want to make sure we don't dilute posts that don't need off-site resources. For example, imagine I asked the question "How can I retain customers for my seasonal business?" and got the answer "I know of an awesome ad platform that will target customers for repeat business, here's the link." Right now, that would be a not-so-hot answer to a question that could (and did) get a good, full, self-contained one. But by opening ourselves up to full-on "what software does [this]?" questions, that becomes a less unacceptable answer.

Clearly that's something of a convoluted concern, because one bad answer doesn't mean any fewer good ones in theory, but in practice I worry that it could.

Me being supportive

All that said, we aim to help startups and small business owners, and startups and small business owners often need software.

That wasn't such a mouthful. But I think it's really important. We sure don't want to shut out questions that would be helpful, since if we start doing that, we're kind of circumventing our central goal here.

The current state of things

Feeling like I haven't even kind of answered the question here? Me too.

Well, here goes.

I'll let you, and anyone else who reads this, in on a little secret: that vote to close reason I mentioned a while ago? We haven't really been using it much. We've fallen into non-enforcement with this, and I can't say I totally dig it. We, your moderator team, has been more or less leaving these sorts of questions up to the community to do with as you will. That's cool and all, but it's not consistent, which is an important part of community development.

I can only really speak for myself on this, but when I see an awesomely researched and put together question, I don't want to close it, and I won't. If it's only boarder-line-relevant to startups, I'll push it over to our friends at Software Recommendations (a site that's actually devoted to these types of requests), but if I think it's going to be useful to visitors in the future and it's put together well, I'll leave it.

But that's all super unofficial. Technically, again, anyone would be right to close that question.

So I guess I have two answers for you:

  1. No, those questions would be off-topic...
  2. ...unless you phrase it right.

We'll be looking into options over the next little while to better-phrase that vote-to-close reason to better reflect the real goal (we want those questions, just only if they're really about startups and well put together and answerable in an objective way).

If you have suggestions about how we can convey that in an effective way, or if you'd like to take part in the discussion over the validity of these questions and whether they should be welcome here, I'll urge you over to that previously listed post. Feel free to post an answer and say "Hey, Matthew, man, this is awful. We need those kinds of posts and they're useful and I love them and I love asking and answering them and I need them in my life!" or "I hate them, I hate them, I hate them! I never want to see one of these questions again!" We haven't viewed this as a super, super high priority because we don't see many posts of the nature, but we can definitely think about it more and get something pushed out if it's a problem that's facing people today.

Again, the press is just to figure out how we can do it, and whether these kinds of moderation concerns are worth the investment.

In any event, it's worth noting the "loophole" of sorts to our current system: if you list your problem statement, it's on-topic. That's not always applicable, and in fact isn't really in many of the examples you listed, but much of the time, it is. Consider if you wanted to ask "what software is there that will let me keep track of customer relations?" If you just swapped it around and said "My business is growing, how can I manage my clients to make them each feel independently supported?" and listed some details, that would be acceptable and probably come to a similar answer. The same is true for your second-to-last example, of how remote staff can interact; if you said "I have a growing distributed team, how can I help keep everyone on the same page?" That would be an awesome question, and it would very well lead to an even more awesome answer that included everything and more as an answer to "What remote collaboration software can my team use?"

This is another of those inconsistencies that I'd love to see fixed, and again, you and everyone else should know that we are, in fact, actively thinking about this.

I'd hold off on asking the very literal "I need software that will let marketing people A/B test my homepage" for now, though. I think that's a bit too far for our unofficial system to be pushed. Most of this was with reference to questions where the answer would likely include some reference to software.

It's funny that you ask this. I've been thinking about starting the same discussion.

The initial reason for not allowing recommendation questions was to avoid questions like "What free software have you found most useful for your startup?" Those questions are aimed more at starting a discussion than answering a question, so they aren't a great fit for the Q/A format. In hindsight we could have just closed questions like that as too broad or opinion based, but we ended up adapting Stack Overflow's policy of no recommendation questions.

Like Matthew said, we've had some discussions about this. We ran into trouble operating by the letter of the law and closing (and later reopening) questions like this. It may not be a perfect question, but it's answerable and provides useful information.

Software Recommendations has solved the problem of recommendation questions, so we may want to look at their model. They have figured out some ground rules that we could probably adapt to Startups.

Right now it's kind of a grey area. The VTC reason still exists, although we aren't out hunting down recommendation questions. Hopefully it will be modified or removed soon. We just need to figure out a better policy first.

While I already retagged one question that created aso to app-store-optimization, I recently came across a question that created baas, another abbreviation.

The problem with abbreviations is that they may be ambiguous and do not add any value, if you do not know what they mean. This was true for both mentioned tags, prior to some edit to the respective questions.

So I looked at the list of tags and found a number of tags that are pure abbreviations. I listed them here and added what they (probably) mean:

  • saas - 8 questions - Software as a Service
  • b2b - 5 questions - Business to Business
  • ux - 1 question - maybe User Experience, but still ambiguous
  • seo - 1 question - Search Engine Optimization
  • baas - 1 question - Backend as a Service

Additionally, the seo question could be retagged to app-store-optimization, but that is not the point here.

These questions, in my opinion, should be retagged to tags with the written-out versions of these tags, to make it more clear what they mean to everyone. There is another tag, probably related to taxes in the USA, which I would like to mention, but I do not know, if there actually is a written-out version for this. If not, I would suggest to add a tag-wiki text to explain what it is about.

  • 83b - 1 question

Finally there are three abbreviation-tags, which are related to the primary topic here. Due to this, I think these abbreviations are fine, but should nevertheless be explained in the tag-wikis.

  • ltd - 3 questions - Limited (legal form of a company)
  • gmbh - 1 question - Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung (legal form of a company in Germany)
Title: Abbreviations in tags

Title: Whats the difference of a beta and a normal site?

Body: There are small differences, for example non-beta sites get a custom web-template design, site gets a logo, users get there rep added to their total SE rep sum, mods are elected, etc. -- but to my knowledge there are no "major" differences in my opinion.

Some of the major changes I can think about (blunders already touched on most of these):

Site Design

All site's get their own design after graduating. There is quite a backlog of graduated sites though, so this doesn't happen immediately after graduation.

Moderator Elections

During the public beta, moderators are selected by the Stack Exchange employees. Once a site has graduated, moderators will be elected by the community.

Repuation Requirements

Graduated sites have higher reputation requirements for certain privileges. It's expected that there will be plenty of high rep users by that point. You can see a table of the differences here.

Other

I believe only graduated sites are supposed to have incoming migrated questions, but that isn't a system limitation and we've already taken in a few.

There are some blog posts on when a site will graduate here and here. The short version is they graduate sites when they are ready. That generally takes a year or two. We're not there yet, but we're definitely growing. I can't make a prediction on a graduation date though.

I'm thinking of asking a question on Startups, and I'd like to make it as complete as possible.

I don't want to come off as sounding like spam, but I think including a link to my company's website would help enrich my question and give more information to users hoping to give a complete answer.

Is it okay to link to my own company in a post? And if so,

  • Are there any guidelines I can follow about how to do it?
  • Are there ways to make users not hate me for it?

I've read a few posts on Meta Stack Exchange, all of which are linked to from What signifies "Good" self promotion? (or: Self Promotion Part Infinity), but I'd like to know how Startups Stack Exchange feels about these posts.
Title: When is it okay to link to my own product in a question?

Body:
Is it okay to link to my own company in a post?

The answer to this question is an unequivocal "sometimes."

Just to be clear, there's a pretty significant difference here between self promotion (Q: "How do I find a developer?" A: "I work for Stack Overflow Careers and it's pretty awesome, come join us!"), and self reference ("I'm looking to do this with my business which is linked to [here], how can I manage it?"). The standards are similar, and might even be identical, but there's still a big difference in what each one means so I feel like I should acknowledge that.

There are five main principles that you should be sure to contemplate when drafting your self-referential or promotional post.

Disclose your relationship

This is the simplest one.

Don't go posting links to your own stuff saying "this is awesome" without explaining "and I get paid to say that." As long as you don't hide your association with the product, you should be fine. Make sure readers understand your bias, so that they can make informed decisions on how much weight to lend your answer. Sometimes, knowing a person's relationship to a company can even add credibility to their suggestion of it. Honesty is valuable.

Be relevant

I said that was the simplest, but it might actually be this one.

Just make sure that what you're referencing or promoting is actually relevant to the context.

As a counter-example,

I was wondering why so many companies build widgets when wodgets seem so much more fun, and by the way check out my awesome YouTube channel where I post videos of my cats!

Be Self-Contained

Stack Exchange is built to be a one-stop shop for all your question and answer needs, and as such, link-only answers are frowned upon. That very same principle applies over to questions.

Make sure your post can stand on its own, without your link there. This means that a user without any prior knowledge (unless it's standard area knowledge) about your company should be able to understand your question without clicking on any links.

Instead of writing something like this (which is too broad for other reasons, and used only as an example),

I've created an app, you can download it [here]. What should I do to market it?

try adding some more details,

I've created an app that lets you count how many widgets you have in your closet. What should I do to market it?

The link is [here], if you need more information.

Clarify as requested

This is practically identical to the previous one.

If someone asks you a question, edit your post to answer it. Never respond with just a link. If someone isn't willing to click your link, the burden is on you to fill them in. Again, feel free to include a link as extra detail, but your post should stand on its own.

Write a question/answer, not a sales pitch

Be succinct.

You can include an elevator pitch in your post if you need to, but the purpose of your post should be to ask or answer a question. You are supplying information with your post, you aren't pitching to potential clients or investors.

Rather than,

I've created an app that lets you count how many widgets you have in your closet. It's amazing, you should see it. You can download it right on your Android device with 4.0.3 or higher, then you don't even have to open the closet door! Using infrared technology, I modify your phone's camera to track the presence of widgets via their heat signature. Try it today before you buy, and I'll send you a free T-Shirt.

What should I do to market it?

Just include the pertinent details.

The same principle applies to comments. If someone asks, "what's your price point now?," answer them informatively, not as a marketing pitch.

Limit yourself

This is heavily contingent on my previous points, but if you clearly put effort into making every one of your posts reference your own personal business (imagine someone who comes on the site only to answer marketing questions with "try my product!"), you're probably using the site wrong, and you may have a moderator contact you. However, if you only once in a while bring it up, or if you only include the necessary details on each question you asked, it should be fine.

Conclusion

Ultimately, it's just a matter of mindset. If you come on Startups and ask or answer a question, make sure your motives are in learning or sharing information. If you do it to promote your product, you're using the site wrong, and other users will notice. Have a good time, talk about your work in chat if you'd like (and if other users are receptive), and ask questions here on meta if you aren't sure about a specific case.

Application = Mobile Apps

Title: How should we approach asking questions about other startups?

Body:
I can't really speak on behalf of the community on this, but I've personally never been a huge fan of these kinds of questions, because they're just so restrictive.

Either,

  1. There's only one right answer, then it's done (which is good for Q&A, but it's pretty out of character for Startups Stack Exchange), or
  2. There's only one right answer, but it happens that nobody actually knows it.

Make sure information is attainable

The second issue isn't really a problem--there are lots and lots of questions out there that are very applicable to the site, but nobody knows the answer. That's what bounties and the "sorted by votes" unanswered page is for. But I would like, if we could control it (which we can't), to keep questions answered someday. And when someone asks a very specific question about something very specific that some very specific company did, that runs the risk of never being answered, ever.

Help the masses

Not to mention, it's policy here on Stack Exchange to keep questions and answers useful to the masses. That's (part of) why we don't allow "what do you think of this name?" or "is this business feasible?" questions. Is a specific question about a specific business's past practices generally applicable? Maybe. Probably, to a point. But I bet oftentimes not.

Explain yourself

On top of that, it's also policy here to be able to explain your answers, that that's generally out of the realm of possibility with those kinds of questions. If you ask me why Stack Exchange gives its on-premise employees free lunch, and I tell you "it's to increase morale" (I'm assuming there already, but this is just an example), then you ask "why does that matter?" or "how does it do that?" I'm stuck. There's a good chance it's buried in a podcast somewhere, so maybe this is a bad example, but more generally speaking, I can answer why I think morale matters, or I can answer how I think free lunch boosts morale, but at some point in that spiral, we'll stop talking about what Stack Exchange does and we'll start building off of my own expertise, which is suddenly not what you're asking for.

Use our experts

Given all that, I would much rather see questions that directly leverage the experts of our community, rather than the experts of other startups. It might lull someone into a false sense of security to learn that Twitter did one thing, for example--they might start doing it, without knowing that it's completely wrong for their business.

Solve your problem, not theirs

If the question is asked in the context of the actual business, and with the pretense that answerers can't know everything about that business, we avoid a huge risk of the oft-quoted XY Problem.

That's no reason to block these questions from the site, granted. As long as someone is aware of the consequences of ignorantly following a successful business, or if they're just curious and don't intend to use the information for anything, that's not such a problem. And it's not our job to police people's use of the information we grant to them.

Conclusion

I've never seen the advantages to outweigh the disadvantages with these questions. I just don't see them as fitting in very well with the rest of our content here. Again, though, that's just me.

That said, way back in the day, when the very first of these questions was asked on the site, I brought it up in our private, moderator chatroom. There, we decided to hold off and see how often they happen, and how the community organically reacted. So far, I haven't seen a problem in quantity, nor votes. But if it turned out that everyone has been silently loathing these questions ever since we started, I wouldn't be sad to see them go.

We all love Startups Stack Exchange, but there is a whole world of people out there who need answers to their questions and don't even know that this site exists. When they arrive from Google, what will their first impression be? Let's try to look at this site through the eyes of someone who's never seen it before, and see how we stack up against the rest of the 'Net.

The Site Self-Evaluation review queue is open and populated with 10 questions that were asked and answered in the last quarter. Run a few Google searches to see how easy they are to find and compare the answers we have with the information available on other sites.

Rating the questions is only a part of the puzzle, though. Do you see a pattern of questions that should have been closed but are not? Questions or answers that could use an edit? Anything that's going really well? Post an answer below to share your thoughts and discuss these questions and the site's health with your fellow users!

Title: Should the site provide advice on ways to engage in potentially fraudulent tax activities?

Body:
This is a difficult question, which is why I asked you to post it on meta.

I just went digging for meta posts, but to no avail. I'll keep looking, but essentially, here's what I know.

On one hand, we have what Stack Exchange wants.

In my experience, Stack Exchange tends to follow two philosophies when it comes to legality and ethics of questions.

  • First and foremost is the terms of service.

    This doesn't strictly relate to the question at hand, but the same principle (the spirit of the law, as they say) can be applied here.

    Use of the Network or Services to violate the security of any computer network, crack passwords or security encryption codes, transfer or store illegal material including that are deemed threatening or obscene, or engage in any kind of illegal activity is expressly prohibited.

    Essentially, Stack Exchange doesn't want to be liable, with good reason, for displaying the next big security breach publicly. Similarly, I suspect, the company doesn't want to host the steps to tax fraud.

  • Beyond that, there's a principle that I've read that, in general, some things can be used for bad, but just because something can be used for bad doesn't make it intrinsically bad.

    I could pop on here, ask a question about how to find a capable developer, then hire a developer to write some very, very evil software for me. Just because that question could be used to hurt people, doesn't mean it has to be.

    Speaking to Stack Overflow, where many of our standards originated, the same kind of thing could be said of network packet sniffers, or key loggers. Yeah, they're sometimes used for bad. But maybe you want to know how to write one so that your software can be protected against it. Pretty much anything can be used for bad, but not everything has to be.

    On top of that, there's some interpretation of when rules matter. Stack Exchange is hosted in the United States, so we're bound by some relatively liberal United States laws, but we do host some religiously themed sites, where participants could be put in grave danger by other governments just for participating. I've heard of users taking those risks on the network, just in the interest of teaching and learning about those religions.

    Committing tax fraud is (to me, at least, not to everyone, granted) far from the same thing as holding different religious beliefs than those in power. So feel free to ignore that last paragraph if you see so fit.

So in general, on that front, my interpretation of the rules is something like:

If it's intrinsically malicious, universally unlawful, or down-right evil, it's our job to get that off the site. Otherwise, assuming it's a well-stated, answerable question, it's fine.

Given that standard, I'd say that this question should stay. There's nothing unlawful about having an off-shore account, even if it could then be used unlawfully. Maybe that user is planning to move off-shore, it's not really our place to assume.

On the other hand, we have what we, the community, wants.

This one's tougher, and I hope other users will express their opinions.

Stack Exchange sites are built and moderated by the community, so if we collectively decide that we'll have no part in fraudulent activities, that's something that we can choose to enforce.

Personally, speaking to the principles that I've seen similar communities hold, it seems to me that the question should stay.

It should be noted that a certain Silk Road developer got arrested after posting a question on Stack Overflow that led to his identity being leaked. Clearly that's different, and in fact the question wasn't asking for something illegal itself, but it's naïve of any user to ask a question thinking that nobody is watching. I wouldn't personally want to ask a question that was clearly related to illegal activities, but that's just me, but I don't think it's the site's job to stop me from making such bad decisions.

Yesterday I stepped by some questions that had some tags I didn't know what they meant. The first example was the product-market-fit, I had no clue whathaheck was that, then I did what I'm used to do in other SE sites: I hovered the mouse over the tag to read its description, unfortunately I found out that there was no tag wiki description for this tag, so I was obliged to look for a description in an external source. I Googled it to find out what it meant.

Navigating a bit more through the site I realized that even the top tags are lacking the wiki description. In my opinion, tags are one of the most important mechanism that organizes and guide questioners ans answerers through the content of the site. They are an essential part of the site and we are simply not using them properly.

I decided I was going to help the community spending my time filling some blank tag wikis that I was particularly interested on. I filled three wiki descriptions of tags I really didn't have a clue on what they meant before I Google them, they were:

  • product-market-fit;

  • equity; and

  • angel-investors.

I'm adept of the reuse, which means that if someone cared to spend time writing definition of terms before I don't see the need to do it myself all over again. Even more because I believe my writing skills are not really high, so the chances of I write a clear, logical and complete definition of something I didn't know what meant minutes before I Google it, are really low.

So... Yes! I did copy the definitions from Wikipedia :)

Is that legal? Definitely yes, accordingly to the Wikipedia copyright statement, which says:

The licenses Wikipedia uses grant free access to our content in the same sense that free software is licensed freely. Wikipedia content can be copied, modified, and redistributed if and only if the copied version is made available on the same terms to others and acknowledgment of the authors of the Wikipedia article used is included (a link back to the article is generally thought to satisfy the attribution requirement; see below for more details). Copied Wikipedia content will therefore remain free under appropriate license and can continue to be used by anyone subject to certain restrictions, most of which aim to ensure that freedom. This principle is known as copyleft in contrast to typical copyright licenses.

Does the community want this? Apparently, nobody cared to ask to this community here about. Nevertheless, I had my suggestions rejected despite the general Stack Exchange decision about this subject is: Yes. It is OK to use some Wikipedia statements as tag wiki descriptions, as the below topic:

Would it be OK to paste content from Wikipedia into a popular empty tag-wiki?

PS: one was approved, but right after the mod felt he made a wrong decision and them decided that no description was better than a Wikipedia description and erased my suggestion.

So my main question to the community is: Is it really preferable to have no description in the tag wiki instead of having Wikipedia descriptions on them?

Is a blank tag wiki description of any help? Will all the users that don't know what one tag means have the same patience I had to go to an external source to read an introductory text about the subject? Will the Wikipedia descriptions move people away from the site? Are the tags with empty tag wiki description useful enough for us?

Below are the link to my suggestions and the reviews:

Tag wiki excerpt suggestions:
https://startups.stackexchange.com/review/suggested-edits/3325 https://startups.stackexchange.com/review/suggested-edits/3328 https://startups.stackexchange.com/review/suggested-edits/3330

Tag wiki suggestions:
https://startups.stackexchange.com/review/suggested-edits/3324 https://startups.stackexchange.com/review/suggested-edits/3327 https://startups.stackexchange.com/review/suggested-edits/3329

The reject reason was:

This edit copies a significant amount of content from an external source. Generic descriptions such as encyclopedia articles and ad copy do not provide useful guidance; try creating something useful to this community specifically, and be sure to attribute the original author. See: How to reference material written by others.

Please realize I did not use the Wikipedia definition for the united-states or international tags, which would be complete pointless, and I did not plagiarized any content, I've made the correct use of the copyright license.

BTW, my rejection rate now is so high that I'm banned to edit any kind of posts:

Was that really necessary? Is that fair?

Please, I want the opinion from the community.
Title: Is it desirable that we fill empty wiki tag descriptions with Wikipedia content?

Body:
Might be wrong, but there's likely a format for citing Wikipedia as the source, though in practice most people just link to Wikipedia as the source and to get more information; which if I'm recalling correctly, you did.

(Worth noting that I approved all of your edits, so I would request that whoever declined them post an answer to cover why.)

I'm the one who rejected the guidelines, and while I'm sorry to hear that it led to an edit ban for you, I stand by the decision.

I think there are two disjoint cases here, and one is simpler than the other.

Tag Wiki Excerpts

There's no room or capability to attribute within these, so that's just not going to fly. It breaks Wikipedia's copyright policies, and it breaks our plagiarism ones.

Tag Wikis

You linked to a post from Meta Stack Exchange: Would it be OK to paste content from Wikipedia into a popular empty tag-wiki?

I encourage you to review the answers. Three of the four, including the accepted one, ultimately amount to "don't do this."

You're definitely right that Wikipedia licenses its content in a way that is conducive to this behavior, but it's important to remember what the Stack Exchange side feels about it. In fact, I haven't found a single source that speaks to why we'd want copied content here. Everything I've read says one or both of "it's completely legal, and it's completely useless."

I guess the best resource I can cite here is the rejection reason I used:

This edit copies a significant amount of content from an external source. Generic descriptions such as encyclopedia articles and ad copy do not provide useful guidance; try creating something useful to this community specifically, and be sure to attribute the original author. See: How to reference material written by others.

The fact that this rejection reason exists in the first place speaks well to the sentiments of Stack Exchange in general. Tag Wikis are meant as a central resource for members of our community. It's awesome that you wanted to contribute to them, but contributions should really be in our own words, and specifically, they should specifically speak to the community itself.

Know thy audience. For us, that means tag wikis should, at least, show key relations between the topic at hand and entrepreneurship. Wikipedia is a general resource, and a really good one at that, but it's written for the world, so its phrasing is not as tailored to the community as tag wikis need to be, in order to serve their purpose.

I think Gilles' answer to the MSE post you cited is really well articulated. There's a specific example in that post, but the last paragraph carries a lot of general weight:

Tag wikis are mainly intended for people who are about to ask a question; they should help those people write better questions, or find answers on their own. An example of something that's useful in a tag wiki for an author is an overview of that author's works; another is a link to a wiki site about that author.

Remember: Stack Exchange is a Q&A network, and the purpose of tags (wikis included) is to support that. As Connor said in his comment, if someone wants to know all of that information, Wikipedia will be their first hit anyway.

Given all that, I'd encourage double-checking the "What Are Tag Wikis?" sidebar.

The full tag wiki is a detailed introduction to the topic, suitable as a destination for those curious about it:

  • what questions should have this tag?
  • some basic definitions
  • brief introduction to the subject
  • important links for learning more
  • one reasonably sized page

I'd encourage anyone who intends to write tag wikis to check over those before submitting. Wikipedia doesn't fulfill many of them. The third point, "brief introduction to the subject," could be argued either way, but the general consensus seems to be that Wikipedia isn't as brief as we need to be on this. The main goals should be to teach users how to use the tag, and where to find more information.

Think of it this way: the tag wiki teaches about a tag, not a topic. To understand a tag, one must differentiate the topic, but beyond that, the purpose is to show how the topic relates and is useful to questions on the site.

The blog post linked to by many of these is also very useful in knowing what content deserves an esteemed position in a tag wiki or tag wiki excerpt.

As for your "main" question, of whether an empty tag wiki is preferable to a copied one, I would say yes, given everything I've reviewed. A copied one like these takes steps in the wrong direction, and doesn't do anything to help with the actual goal of the wikis.

All that said

It really is appreciated that you want to add tag wikis, and the issue here is political and social, more than legal, and I know those issues can be difficult to know ahead of time. The ban will be over soon enough, and when it is, I would encourage reading through the UI prompts.

Tag wikis just have a different purpose than Wikipedia, and while both serve to make the internet a better place, and both serve to give a (generally) brief introduction to a topic, they differ fundamentally in who they're for and what kind of information they work to convey. Linking to Wikipedia, and in some cases even pulling in a sentence or two that are clearly marked as originating from there, can be acceptable. But full paragraph upon paragraph crosses a line.
Curious how others feel we're doing and what if anything we need to address. How do you feel we're doing, and if you feel we need to do something, why?
Title: How are we doing?

Body:
I agree with what you said in chat--we're on the right track, but we have a little ways to go.

And I really don't think that's such a bad thing.

I've seen sites that got launched, let's call it a little "prematurely," and it just doesn't work well. Considering our main goal of the site should be to ask and answer questions, being in the beta phase isn't really all that much of a problem. Stack Exchange isn't going to shut us down if we can continue the level of enthusiasm and quality that we've accomplished so far, and I don't foresee that dropping in the near future.

If I were to offer some critique, and I say this as a regular user, not a moderator, I'm starting to see a lot of what Robert Cartaino, a Stack Exchange employee, said in his post a while back. From Is this site viable? We're extending the private beta,

The vast majority of questions seem to be very narrowly focused on the mechanics of STARTING a business rather than the meatier challenges of actually running a start-up. There's nothing inherently wrong with a few how-to-get-started questions, but right now the front page reads more like any chapter-book on "How to Start Your Small Business" rather than something that captures the insightful day-to-day problem-solving of actually running a small enterprise.

I worry that many of our questions have become about specific implementations of small businesses. I don't mean to call out any questions as being bad, very few are, but in vast quantities, it's hard to build a strong community of askers and answerers around questions like:

  • Is [this practice] legal?
  • What does [this passage from a book] mean?
  • What are the steps involved in registering a business?

Those kinds of questions are, while totally valid and generally on-topic, pretty limiting. I would prefer, as Robert suggested, seeing more of the high-level theories expressed.

Reviewing our top questions by votes, I see a lot of the kinds of questions I love. Here are the current top five from that list:

  • Better to learn programming, or hire a programmer?
  • How can I know if my developer is doing a good job?
  • Dividing profits amongst developers and designers
  • Is it risky to use cloud services like Google Docs to host business plans?
  • I have a great idea, but I'm not great at marketing or sales. How do I approach this?

None of these questions could be answered by someone reading the Secretary of State website. They require, to one degree or another, the insight of an experienced entrepreneur. They have a certain je ne sais quoi that really sells the community, in my eyes at least, as having a lot to offer. They're not inappropriately subjective, nor are they too broad, but they still present difficult business questions that could have a number of "right" answers.

Now, of course, I'm not up and arguing that we don't get these questions any more. We do, and they're awesome, but they've slowed down a lot from our founding. I wouldn't be mentioning this if you hadn't asked, but if there was any one thing that I could change about the site, it would be to add more of those kinds of questions.

I should stress, I take no issue with the more mechanical questions. Those need answers, and I firmly believe that the Stack Exchange model leads here to be among the best places to get those answers. My point isn't to reduce those, so much as to promote the more thought-provoking types.

That all said, I'm really not sure these kinds of questions can be forced.

To me, it's unclear how we're deciding what is an okay "list of" question, and what is not.

Why are we closing some, but allowing others?
Title: "List of" questions, what's the deal?

Body:
As the comments to your objections in that question make clear, this particular question is different: it is so common a problem that it absolutely needs an adequate answer on this very site.

If it's a student asking for "great books for entrepreneurs" or what have you, then by all means close. It's not actionable, non-operational, and indeed prone for spam.

This one is different: you have an actual entrepreneur who has a remote team to manage, and they need an operational response. It got two excellent answers so far, and rightly so. My clients all have this type of problem. Every single one of them. (Heck, I recently introduced one to Trello. They had no frikin' task management tool to manage the team's TODO list.)

My point is this: if it's operational, it should be on-topic. Period. Else this site is useless.

Product Launch

How to not release to crickets.

Please edit the community wiki to add your research, do not add additional answers. This question is a place holder for us to share research on "Good Subjective, Bad Subjective" in support of Matthew Haugen answer/suggestion that we focus on increasing the volume of good questions.

Background

In 2010, Robert Cartaino, Director of Community Development for the Stack Exchange, posted a blog post on "Good Subjective, Bad Subjective" in an effort to filter out bad subjective content and encourage good subjective content. If you have not read this, please do.
Title: Research on "Good vs Bad Subjective"

Body:
Examples of how other communities handled this:

  • Meta Stack Exchange (Meta for all SE sites)
  • Workplace-SE
  • Programmers-SE

Related Topics:

  • Where can I have subjective discussions about [insert topic]?
  • What are guidelines for “Good Subjective” answers on this site?
  • Are We In Danger of Falling Into the Trap of Becoming a Discussion Site Because Questions are Not Meeting StackExchange Guidelines?
  • Is The SE Platform Appropriate For A Parenting Discussion Site?
  • Should we disourage questions of the form “Is X bad”?

This is about this question, which is off-topic. After I, being the first to vote it off-topic, left the automatic comment for the vote, one of the highest-rep members of the community engaged in a lengthy exchange with me as to why questions like this (or any other possible question in the world) should be on-topic since startups face these situations.

While the discussion may be valid, the comments for the question is not the place for it. It should be here, on meta.

But what bothers me even more is that that member of the community went on to edit the question, and add a "business" in it so that it would be more on-topic, in his mind. I reversed that edit and the original poster approved. Yet, the highest-rep member of the community went on to ignore the original poster, and decided that he knows better. He edited the question again and added "business" in it.

I was hoping the mods would intervene and clean up the mess left in the comments and decide whether the 2 votes for closing it as off-topic are valid or not. Apparently that didn't happen.

As a future high-rep in this community, I wanted to clear this question out:

If I don't like the question, am I entitled to edit it out of the original intent so that it would fit my point of view better even if the OP disagrees with the edit?

From my experience on other SE sites, this behavior is unacceptable.

Please clarify.
Title: So the highest rep decides he knows better than the OP what is being asked

Body:
While the discussion may be valid, the comments for the question is not the place for it. It should be here, on meta.

Agreed.

Fwiw, raising a flag is the easiest way to settle arguments of this nature. It's also the least time consuming.

If I don't like the question, am I entitled to edit it out of the original intent so that it would fit my point of view better even if the OP disagrees with the edit?

In my opinion, the answer is a definite no. Such a behavior is completely unacceptable.

I have an extremely important email going out to my 3500 email list announcing a new product and I dont want to f it up. Is it appropriate question to ask in the Startups forum to critique a few versions of my email?

I would imagine other founders would find use in seeing my emails critiqued, however, I dont recall ever seeing other founders ask for such... precise help.
Title: Can I ask people to critique my marketing email in the Startups site?

Body:
So there a few questions being asked here. I'll try to answer them as best as I can.

Is this question on topic?

It's in a grey area. Banks are commonly used by startups and questions about managing money in a business are on topic here. We could give OP the benefit of the doubt and assume it was for a business purpose, but I'd still lean towards considering keeping those general money questions off topic here. (They might fit on Money.SE?)

Is it appropriate to edit a question to make it on topic?

It's encouraged. Everyone is encouraged to improve other questions. High rep users are given the ability to edit without review because they're trusted to more often then not improve posts without changing the OP's intent.

Does adding business make this question on topic?

In this case, I don't think it does enough to move it out of the grey area.

Should you rollback OP's edit which rolled back your edit?

This is a perfect time for a flag. A mod can place a lock on it while the dispute is figured out. If OP's question is perfectly valid, then it should stay the way it was. If it's off topic and OP refuses to accept an edit to fix it, then it will be closed. In some cases if an edited version of the question may be considered valuable for the site, it could be converted to community wiki.

Again, in this case, I don't think we need it to become a community wiki. Down votes and close votes will kill it, unless OP wants to improve it. (I've removed the lock, so they'll be able to.)

Unfortunately, questions requesting critique on specific ideas fall outside of our scope.

Questions seeking general brainstorming or review ("What do you think of this idea?") are off-topic because questions here are expected to be relevant for a variety of people in the same situation. Reviewing an idea or product only helps one person at a specific time. Instead, try asking about a specific business approach and cite yours as an example.

You could ask a question about what general information you should include in your email, if you're still at that stage. You'll have to watch for subjectivity and broadness, but as long as you phrase it well, that shouldn't be too much of an issue.

If you are past that stage, and it sounds like you are, my best direction for you would be to head over to chat. We don't have the busiest of rooms, but that'll be your best bet at getting something as subjective as critique done.

I imagine this won't apply to you, since you clearly care enough about falling in the rules (evidenced by your having posted here), but my standard disclaimer when I point people at chat for something like this is just to make sure you're polite and patient. There's good reason for subjective questions like this to be off-topic on the main site, because they can be difficult to answer.

This is a stub for those to express why they're supporting a random new user doing overt self-promotion via this question.

I intend to remove the link the OP added back unless there's a valid reasoning by those in the community that appear to be supporting an OP refusing to follow the standard best practice of placing all information needed to answer a question in the question.
Title: Overt Self-Promotion

Body:
Imho, you were right to remove it from the top of the question, and the link was doing no harm when it was at the bottom of the question. The help page you linked to says:

Don't include links except to support what you've written. Links are not a substitute for including information in your answer itself, and links should always be directly relevant to a part of your answer.

It might be just me, but OP included enough information to answer the question, and he tossed in a (non hyperlinked, at that) domain name for information. In some sense, it was supporting what he wrote; in another it was indeed a shameless plug.

Whichever it is in the end, though, it's a far cry from the last case of overt self-promotion I can recollect, where the OP tossed in a link about his Kickstarter -- with no information whatsoever on what it was about -- in the hopes of getting click-throughs. Had it not been for the excellent answer @demirb had posted within 5 minutes of it appearing, it would have been deleted as spam instead of us trying to salvage it to something that gave the answer some justice.

From the OP via a comment:

Hey folks. I'm the OP from the question. I never intended for people to buy off the site. I was posting it, because it adds more clarity to my question. People would be able to look around and find what they want. Either way, the link has been removed just so I don't appear to be disrespecting the site rules or people.

It's been a bit calm on meta and chat lately, but I don't see any major issue with that in part because in my opinion the main site seems do being doing well; all clearly my opinion, but based on past exchanges with other members of the community, have no reason to believe this is not the case.

All that said, I do believe that some activity in chat and meta is good.

How can we better use chat and meta so that new users know that, at the very least, both of these tools are active resources for the community?

UPDATE: Please stop in and say "Hi" in our Startup-SE's chat room.
Title: How can we encourage the use of Startups Meta and Chat?

Body:
One important aspect of developing a successful and beneficial Q&A resource is to keep a strong cache of canonical questions and answers that can help answer broader questions that arise in various forms.

On technical sites, examples might be "How do I fix this error?" or "What does this syntax mean?" On sites like ours, however, these questions can be more difficult to make broadly applicable, simply due to the inherent subjectivity and inconsistency of beginning and maintaining a small business, making it less likely that they'll arise completely naturally.

With that said, these questions can still exist and be useful, even simply as differential building blocks for future questions that specify very different circumstances.

Connor and I were thinking recently about these kinds of questions, and we thought we'd try a little experiment. We'd like for this meta post to serve two purposes:

  1. We hope it will act as a canonical reference of canonical references, to make them easier to find for users armed with duplicate close votes, and even just those with general subject interest.

  2. If you feel a topic deserves a canonical reference, feel free to post it as an answer here to gauge community interest and support, or even to recruit a more knowledgeable user to help implement a canonical resource.

Writing these resources can be very difficult, and it's important to plan them out before posting them (either by answering yourself, or by enlisting help of another before proceeding), as they can easily be viewed as "too broad" unless the intent is made clear from the get-go.

As I said, this is just an experiment. I'm sure whether a question like this will be helpful in the long run, but we're interested to build a solid foundation now of these types of resources, so that as the site grows we don't find ourselves tangled in a web of mostly-duplicates that could easily share a common, more complete canonical question.

So, what would you like to see? What questions do you see asked over and over that could be broadened up into a wider topic? What canonical resources do we already have that deserve to be documented?
Title: What would make good canonical resources?

Body:
Please help me name my company

  • Methods for choosing a business name

  • [Please edit to add interesting questions]

Please help me pick the US state / country I should incorporate in

  • Where to incorporate a < $100,000 one man app startup in the US?
  • [Please edit to add interesting questions]

How can I distribute ownership fairly amongst founders?

  • How to distribute ownership fairly amongst founders?

Challenge is pretty simple, help us reach 1000 questions before the month is over; might be obvious, but please do not just spam questions.

Likely best to:

  • Respond to feedback on the question as fast as possible; meaning if you're busy, the question is not a pressing issue, likely best not to post the question.
  • Limit questions you're posting to one question a day unless the existing questions from the day have 2+ upvotes or more each.
  • If the question gets downvotes and you're not able to resolve the issues raised, please delete the question as soon as it's clear there are issues.

Please feel free to edit this post. Cheers!
Title: Help Us Reach 1000 Questions

Body:
How to hire and commission resellers, affiliates, and contract sales people?

  • How to Hire and Commission Resellers, Affiliates, and Contract Sales People
  • Looking for general guidelines on reselling and comissions for Enterprise IT/SAAS service
  • Expansion strategy based on current external business partners model
  • [Please edit to add interesting questions]

I've noticed there are a lot of questions that have good answers, but they are not currently marked as accepted. This leaves a lot of open ended questions, and users who are not getting the rep for their good answers. Is there any way we can promote people to accept answers to their questions so the answerer gets their well deserved rep?
Title: Is there a good way to get more people accepting answers, rather than leaving questions open.

Body:
I'd be surprised if the stats in this SE are that different from other non-technical SE sites.

Not every user will know that they should ideally accept answers as a courtesy when they're happy. To their credit the "Accept answer" UI is abysmal across SE sites, in that it's unlabeled and extremely easy to miss. (Speaking for myself, I recollect scratching my head for a few moments once on SO before I noticed the nearly invisible tick. I cannot imagine a newcomer noticing the tick if they're not actively looking for it.)

Sometimes, no answer is good enough, or the question is broad and open-ended enough that no answer should get accepted.

More rarely, a user consciously won't accept (or upvote) good answers they receive -- for any number of other reasons. And that's fine at the end of the day. If it annoys you, simply ignore these users' questions.

This is a stub requesting that the user on a vote to close spree bring up the issue in meta; please feel free to edit this question.

UPDATE: The following questions appear to have been part of the series of votes to close:

  • Linear Measurement Vs Dimensional Weight Flat Rate Shipping
  • What is a reasonable execution price for early options?
  • How much equity are companies offering nowadays?
  • How do US non-profits balance revenue and expenses?
  • Standardise UK seed funding contract
  • What does a standard agent agreement look like?
  • Balancing earning money whilst starting a new business
Title: Vote to Close Spree

Body:
There are SE sites such as this one with zero unanswered questions at the time of writing. We should strive to do the same thing here seeing how they're a gazillion times larger than we are.

Doing so involves closing questions that are unanswerable because too localized or too broad or too opinion-based or whatever, and a lot of our unanswered questions qualify as such IMO.

There's a further reason for us to do so, in that the former startups SE got shut down owing to low quality questions that didn't get moderated properly. We don't want to go there.

If you agree, close vote too; if not, consider answering the questions.

What are crowdfunding campaign best practices?

  • Types of incentives for powerful crowdfunding
  • Bootstrap Marketing Activities Before Crowdfunding
After flirting for a day or two with 999 questions, we're finally at 1003 questions. :-)

Is there a way that we can encourage users to post small bounties on their questions (to encourage good and numerous answers)?

It occured to me that selecting an answer awards the OP a small amount of rep, so if we could find a way to encourage the OP to offer a similar amount as a bounty, we may see an increase in the number of answers posted.

Any thoughts on how we may promote this?
Title: How to Encourage Small Bounties

Body:
Best I'm aware, bounties are 50+ rep on all SE sites. That's how the site works, and few users can afford to post many bounties, so there isn't much encouraging we can do.

Bring it up the SE meta though. They might find the idea appealing.

Should I develop for iOS or Android first?

  • iOS vs Android first: What makes iOS first a valid strategy for mobile app companies?
  • [Please edit to add interesting questions]

What are cheap micropayment options

  • What is the least expensive WHITE LABEL payment gateway to accept debit cards for micropayments?
  • [Please edit to add interesting questions]

One idea could be Featured Discussions. Similar to the topic challenges, we would pick a topic on meta and then have a chat event for a few days where discussions on that topic are encouraged. The chat event would add a link on the page sidebar, hopefully bringing new users to chat.

What about discussing... startups or ideas on startups (and related problems, like sell or marketing or competition or research or market or tons of other topics) people already have, or are about to run, or planning to?

The sell tag originated from the question Selling an application, which is clearly not about sales, but about selling an application as a whole.

But since then (at the time of writing within 20 days), three new questions were asked that are about sales, but have been tagged sell. This is probably due to similar meanings of the two words.

My suggestion is to retag the three sales-questions to sales, but I don't really know what to do with the sell and the question it originated from. Maybe add a tag-wiki and make sure it is used correctly. Or make it a synonym of sales and find a better name for it?
Title: New users [sell] questions although they simply need [sales]

Body:
What do I do if I think a user might be revenge downvoting me? Or gaming for advantage on a bounty question? Or both?

I already flagged the post and requested moderator attention. But it's been a while and I haven't heard back yet. So I don't know if I'm taking the correct approach.
Title: Revenge downvoting and gaming on bounties

Body:
There isn't much you can do about a single downvote. It's possible that someone is strategically downvoting you, but it's just as possible that someone thought your answer was bad. A single vote rarely makes a huge difference and the asker should hopefully award the bounty to the answer that was the most helpful disregarding vote counts.

If there is a pattern of downvoting against a certain user, the system will catch it, revert the votes, and alert the moderators who can follow up with the offender.

On the other hand, if you suspect a user has a pattern of downvoting competing answers to gain an edge, flag it for moderator attention and we can ask the community team to take a look. If there is a pattern of anti-competitive behavior, appropriate actions will be taken against the offender.

Tactical Downvoting has been discussed a couple times on the Stack Exchange Meta:

What should be done to people who downvote strategically?

I tried to correct the spelling of the word from red to read in someone else's post and get the following error

Edits must be at least 6 characters; is there something else to improve in this post?

Is this because of my low trust level or should we just ignore very small misspells?
Title: Edits must be at least 6 characters

Body: I think it said that the Edit Summary needs to be at least 6 characters long. Try again.

The edit rules for lower rep users are different because they have to go through the review queue and they earn the editor +2 reputation. It can seem a little cheap to earn your points by making single character edits, and it also means three other users have to spend their time reviewing your small change.

This is rarely an issue because there is almost always something else you can fix in the post besides a spelling issue. Did the author add an unnecessary salutation? Is there a missing tag? What about an incorrect tag? Could a sentence be reworded for clarity?

Once you earn the full edit privilege, you are free to make as small of an improvement as you like, although of course you are still encouraged to fix as much as possible in the post.

I noticed that there is a category of questions that are formulated in the following way:

I have a problem, but I can't give you much details. Can you give me advice?

Of course I generalize here, but because of the nature of business, people are weary of disclosing sensitive information. In many cases the omitted details seem trivial and should be discussed in open(i.e. your idea).

The point is that this issue seems to be specific to the startup wiki.

Was this discussed before? Is there a way in which we can encourage people to give us details in their questions instead of making us ask them for more details in the comments?
Title: How to encourage less secrecy in questions?

Body:
There really isn't much you can do about it.

At one end of the spectrum, some offer so little information that you cannot reasonably reply unless you've enough domain expertise to guess what they're onto. At the other, and per Connor's comments, some add so many details it's difficult to parse through the post to weed out signal.

There isn't much one can do besides inviting users to re-read their questions from the point of view of a reader. For instance, would you understand your own question if you were unfamiliar with your own business? Or... are you sure everything you wrote is important to get an answer?

That being said, and if I may be somewhat blunt: a founder who is unable to explain what they're up to in terms that are interesting to their audience may do well to get a few downvotes and/or comments to prompt them to think about what they'd look like in front of investors or clients.

Being an analytics head at a promising startup, I found that metrics and growth are very important for the company, both for establishing itself and also for identifying and providing value for it's users.

So, I have proposed an SE site for marketing and growth professionals, where people can ask and discuss on marketing strategies, vitality and growth hacking.

I am looking forward to discussions, possibilities and suggestions regarding the site, and how many would be interested to contribute to the example questions, commit and want the site to get live.
Title: Are people in this community interested in having a new site for Marketing and Growth Hacking?

Body: Seems redundant. The topics you put forward are all relevant on this site.

I apologise in advance if this is off-topic. It is the closest SE site I can think of.

What site (if any) would it be ok to ask the following question:

I sell items solely on EBay (for the time being), and am using Google Adwords to buy clicks to send people to it.

The problem is that I can't find a way of setting Ebay+Adwords up such that when a customer clicks on an advert and then makes a purchase, that it will show up as a conversion in the Adwords stats.

I have searched online for blogs etc that cover this issue, and it's not looking promising, but I find it hard to believe that someone hasn't found a way around the issue.

The only other SE site I can think of is StackOverflow, but I'm pretty sure it's off topic for that as well.
Title: Which Stack Exchange site to ask about Adwords+Ebay conversion tracking

Body:
I'm referring to this question: How to send an email to thousands of potential customers and customize its contents?

The questioner asks how to send bulk, unsolicited email. I highlighted in the comments the fact that bulk unsolicited email is spam; my comments were deleted.

I've asked for assistance in chat and got one only response here which seems to be arguing that sending 5,000 unsolicited emails isn't actually spam - I'm not clear on why that would be. (Denis, apologies if I've misunderstood you somehow).

Obviously the legality of sending spam email various by jurisdiction - here in the UK it's not legal, but in some places it is legal - but even where it's legal, it's not exactly reputable.

Do we really want to be providing help and practical advice to spammers?
Title: Are we really ok with this site giving advice on how to send spam emails?

Body:
This looks like a question, which can be best answered by growth hackers.

And as there isn't any SE for Growth Hacking (So, I've proposed one).

However, according to Denis' answer here, it is on-topic here.

The questioner asks how to send bulk, unsolicited email.

Not so. Everyone who participated in the question highlighted that sending bulk, unsolicited email was not the right thing to do. Including myself. But that is not what the OP was asking.

OP was asking how to best email his list of 5k cherry-picked leads.

That is not spam. It's outbound email marketing.

Bulk is bulk. It means sending the exact same email to everyone in a huge, unqualified list. In bulk. It's straightforward to set up: you can buy lists of 100M+ email addresses for a few bucks and blast away in a completely automated manner. It evidently works for some types of products, e.g. sex-related enhancements. But it's illegal more often than not. And certainly not recommended if you care about your business reputation.

Outbound is about sending personalized solicitations to a handful (in this case 5k) of leads. There are right ways to do it, and there are ways to semi-automate the process. See my answer to the question for a primer. It even emphasis lead "pre-warming" to maximize email open rates. This is both legal and acceptable. In every jurisdiction.

No worries about you misunderstanding my answer or not being able to fathom that there are salespeople out there who are actively doing outbound all day through snail mail, email, and telephone. It's just the reality of selling. And as an aside you'd be nuts not to do it if you're into B2B: done right, outbound tramples inbound when it comes to short- or even mid-term ROI. Think $40+ returns per $1 spent.

send an email to thousands of potential customers and customize its contents?

Sending bulk emails to potential customers (or leads) is sometimes called cold-calling and sometimes outbound marketing. And it is completely legal.

In fact, it is one of the top growth hacks out there for closing leads. So, sending personnalized, outbound mails is not spam.

In fact, almost all the marketing strategies out there are unsolicited, however some are legal and some are not.

And sending out personnalized mails for B2B customer model is legal.

I was wondering whats the policy on questions that are specific for certain user and/or his business, eg. How much Equity should I push for ?

Of course most cases are different, but is it up for this community to form an answer from more general questions instead of OP himself?
Title: User / business specific questions

Body:
If this were one of the tech sites, we would provide sample code for a fairly specific use case. If the question gives enough detail, and importantly, the title is specific enough, then we can give a pretty specific answer.

Other askers may then see this question when they are searching and if their situation is close they may find all that they need in that post.

If we answer too specifically we might never find another asker with the same question, but if we are too general we may never help anyone.

I have a feeling that equity percentage questions are going to be the "parsing html with regex" of startups SE, but maybe with a little bit of bit of copy and paste we can help a lot of people and maybe even build up enough related questions that people will find their answer before they ask.

I found a few articles on this in the help section: (https://startups.stackexchange.com/help)

  • https://startups.stackexchange.com/help/how-to-ask
  • https://startups.stackexchange.com/help/dont-ask
  • https://startups.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic

The answers of this user appear like nicely built up spam posts for a lawyer site.

I am not really sure, but can the mods please have a look?
Title: Probable spam posts?

Body:
I'll investigate and potentially reach out to the user.

It's always tough to tell whether someone is maliciously spamming, misunderstanding the site to think it's for self-promotion, or in a case like this, potentially even just excited about a third party service that they want to share. The latter two, of course, aren't acceptable, but there's no harm done if we fix up those posts. I haven't looked at theirs yet, but just as a general rule.

In any event, I'll look into it, and likely edit or delete many of those answers.

Thanks for bringing this to our attention.

As some of us may remember, Stack Exchange has a relatively recent tradition around this time of year, called Winter Bash.

Starting December 14 and ending January 3, we'll start seeing decorations around Startups, and other sites in the Stack Exchange network.

You can check out the sites from previous years, but the concept is simple. If you complete a challenge, like answering questions under certain circumstances or performing edits, you get a little virtual hat to pin on your profile picture for the duration of the event, or if you're handy with screen shots, until the next Winter Bash.

It's just another good way to have some fun and share our knowledge.

Participation is strictly voluntary, so if you find football helmets and mullets (two "hats" from last year) particularly unbecoming, no worries, you'll be able to avoid donning a hat yourself, or even turn off seeing everyone else's.

Participation is enabled by default for all sites, but for those where hats might not fit into the vibe they're trying to set up, the Stack Exchange staff do allow us to disable the feature entirely.

If we come to a group conclusion that we don't like hats and they shouldn't be enabled, one of us diamond moderators will reach out to the team and request we be taken off the list. Otherwise, you can look forward to this tradition on December 14.

Do we want hats?
Title: Bring on the hats?

Body:
WinterBash hats are fun.

In addition to being fun, it also helps in improving the participation of users in the site, especially because you don't know which hat you'd be getting for a particular participation.

So, it would have a festive look + a enthusiastic, active community.

So, a +1 for the WinterBash!

I am currently developing an application all by myself and have come to a point where I need some help. Would it be appropriate for me to ask if there is anybody that would like to help and become part of a startup here on SE or that against the rules for asking a question?
Title: Am I allowed to ask for help?

Body:
Asking for help on the main Q&A site would be against policy, as we prefer to keep long-lasting questions and answers that will help people in the future, rather than solving one-off issues with one-off solutions, as hiring is.

However, our rules are a bit more relaxed in our site's chat room. I'm not sure (honestly) whether that's the best place to find help--it might be, I just wouldn't guarantee it--but it's the best Startups would be able to do for you. I'm sure you could get some free advice from other entrepreneurs, though, which could be valuable.

Beyond that, I'd check out the answer Mustaccio linked to in a comment: Where can we find developers who want to join our Startup for equity? Whether or not Startups Stack Exchange is the best place to find a real-life business partner, we should be able to help you learn how to find someone.

I am searching for forum where we (Startups) can discuss queries related to the tech stack they have.

Like which technologies to use in frontend and backend. Should prefer native or hybrid app, etc.
Title: Can we discuss queries related to start up tech stack here?

Body:
It kind of depends on the circumstances.

As we know, it all ultimately comes down to our help center:

  • Starting or running a small business including partnership and corporate structures, business plans, finance, legal or IP issues
  • Operational issues such as attracting and hiring talent, compensation, employee relationships, training and development
  • Strategies for successfully bringing a product or service to market

In general, it's difficult to make specific technology questions fit into this very well.

If I asked the question "which web stack should I build my website on?" that would be very off-topic, because it's:

  • Opinionated
  • Not focused on the business itself
  • Too broad to give a complete answer to

However, the question "If I can only pick one, is iPhone or Android a first MVP platform" (with some more details), that could be a very useful question.

Similarly, "I'm launching a programming Q&A site using the Microsoft dev stack, how can I blog about my upcoming product without suggesting that only Microsoft products are on-topic?" would be a reasonable question.

It really depends on why you're asking.

As a general (but not always applicable, so do put thought into it) rule of thumb, if you are looking for a technical answer, while many of our users are technical, your question probably won't be on-topic. If you're looking for a mostly business-oriented answer, then this is probably the right place.

I can see this site is in Beta.

But I have seen a few other conversations referring to this site as if it had been finally closed:

  • What happened to Startups SE?
  • Is this site viable? We're extending the private beta
  • http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/6243/startup-business

...and others.

All of these conversations are outdated and seem they don't reflect the current state of this site (open in beta).

As of today (February 2016), can someone please clarify: the current state of this Startups SE site? how long should we expect it to stay open? who can read and add content to it? anything I should be aware of as I plan to start using this SE site? Thanks!
Title: What is the current state of this site?

Body:
As of today (February 2016), can someone please clarify: the current state of this Startups SE site?

We are in public beta.

How long should we expect it to stay open?

There are no plans to shut this site down.

Things have changed a bit, and the bar for keeping a site open has become very low (which is a good thing), as long as the community remains nice and on-topic.

Who can read and add content to it?

Anyone and everyone!

Every Stack Exchange site goes through three phases:

  1. Proposal
  2. Private beta (hence the "Is this site viable?" question)
  3. Public beta (where we are)
