  4. Graduated

It happens that we aren't the first Startups Stack Exchange. There was one before us that didn't do so well, and it was eventually shut down. That's what the "What happened to Startups SE?" question was talking about. That's also what the Area 51 page you saw was referring to.

That said, we aren't in the same boat as that first site. Things have changed on Stack Exchange, and our site still has an active community to uphold our be-nice values.

I'm not worried about this site being closed anytime soon. I can't speak to graduation (and I'm in no rush for the site to graduate), but as long as we keep doing what we're doing, I think we're on a good track.

A user posted a question if he/she could reserve a name on various mobile App Stores in order to keep a certain App name as many people do for domain names: Can I register the name of an app before starting creating it?

I thought this was a great question and clicked to find out more. A user @Kekito (with all respect) mentioned the he/she voted to close the question because it has nothing to do with startups. I strongly disagree.

  1. As I mentioned in the comments, the question can be interpreted as registering a company name, trademark/copyright law, and anything else that concerns incorporating a company/startup. The name of an App (the startup) can be the focal point of the app. Even in the iOS guidelines, developers are encouraged to choose names that are relevant to their business (app) or they face being rejected by the Apple Store: https://developer.apple.com/app-store/review/guidelines/

(3.3.3 in the article)

Apps with names, descriptions, screenshots, or previews not relevant to the content and functionality of the App will be rejected

  1. Developers are encouraged to chose wisely! Therefore, a question relating to reserving a name is quite important, and to be honest, being a developer I'm very interested if anyone knows if that's even possible.

Furthermore, there are several questions that relate/are similar to that question (because there are tags deliberately made that make them relatable) and all have been well received and answered by reputable members of the Startup StackExchange site community.

Examples:

  1. Is it a must to register the business for internet based start up?

  2. Is it okay to register company / app name after app has been released, advertised and has multiple users?

  3. (This question below, which is primarily opinion based, received 4 up votes... If anything, I would argue that this question is more of a concern)

Should I think of Domain/App Name first before even going into details of my idea?

Considering a lot of the questions on this community concern software startups, closing a question like this could leave a precedent for future software/tech related questions. I even think this question is a GREAT question because it requires a factual and researched: Yes/No response. No opinion. No discussion. Pure fact.

We should encourage people to post questions that require those types of answers (As does StackOverFlow and the rest of the communities that I'm apart of).

When should questions be closed? In my opinion (quoting StackExchange) when:

This question is completely unclear, incomplete, overly-broad, primarily opinion-based or is not about startups as described in the help center, and it is unlikely to be fixed via editing.

Something that the question above isn't.

Would love to hear everyone's take on it.

PS,

The title isn't great. Please edit if you can think of something more precise!
Title: Closing a Question that is Relevant as it Relates to Several Other Questions

Body:
At the time of writing, this question has one close vote, one down vote, and five up-votes. Not to mention, it's got a well-voted answer.

It's still four human votes away from being placed on-hold, and I don't see any evidence that the community generally supports doing that.

So I wouldn't worry too much about it.

I am a startup enthusiast. I have asked 3 questions on this website and I am getting a notification that my questions have not been well received and I am at a risk of being blocked from asking anymore. One of my question has 4 upvotes, another has 3 upvotes and the last one has no upvotes. I wonder why am I getting this notification since their are no downvotes. Please suggest.
Title: Risk of being blocked from asking anymore just after 3 questions

Body:
The question block counts deleted questions.

While you're correct that your undeleted questions are totally fine, you've still got another three questions that were closed before being deleted.

In any event, you haven't hit the question block yet. The warning you've received is exactly that: a warning. Your two most recent questions were closed and deleted, so it's telling you to slow down a bit and make sure you understand our scope. If you can post more questions or useful content, the warning will disappear, and no harm will come of it.

That said, while it is just a warning, please do take it seriously. If you want to continue being able to ask questions here, read that page, and continue to review it. A few users had linked to it after your first and second closed questions, but the third one still wasn't a great fit.

If you don't have any more questions to ask (in which case this is all irrelevant, I suppose), you could also try improving your zero-scored question. If you can get that up to a positive score, you may stand a better chance of avoiding the question ban.

I'm voting to close a question, and I select the following path for the reasoning:

  • Off-topic because ...
  • This question belongs on another site in the Stack Exchange network

After this the only option is:

  • belongs on meta.startups.stackexchange.com

But the question doesn't belong on meta, it belongs on another SE site.
Title: Bug in close question options?

Body:
Startups is not a big enough site yet to warrant additional migration paths. Meta is currently the only option, and what you saw is by-design.

In these cases, please flag the question with an 'other' reason explaining which site the question should go to and, briefly, why. A moderator will review the flag, and we'll be able to perform the migration.

Many if not all the questions in the Startups Exchange are location dependent. Folk who raise questions there often neglect to offer this information which leads to answers that might prove nothing more than a talking point for the reader.

Might I suggest the user is prompted to optionally provide (or at least reminded to offer) their country/region in order to assist with more helpful answers?

I know... some will argue there are privacy issues... but location effects the outcome of the answer...
Title: Suggest Location field added for Startups exchange

Body:
You may remember back when we brainstormed some advertisements for Startups to appear on other Stack Exchange sites.(Ads to help promote this site?)

We ended up running an ad on The Workplace and Game Development for the rest of 2014 and throughout 2015 resulting in over 5000 clicks.

Beginning in 2016, the sidebar size changed and our ads no longer fit. We thought this would be the perfect time to find some new ideas (or maybe just resize some old ones.)

If you have an idea for an ad, submit it in a post below. Then vote on which ones you like best, and in a bit (probably a week or two) we'll pull out the highest-voted ones and put them on another site or two. The rest is pretty much up to you! Just make sure you follow these requirements.

  • The image that you create must be 300 x 250 pixels, or double that if high DPI.
  • Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)
  • Must be GIF or PNG No animated GIFs
  • Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB
  • If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.

But beyond that, it's up to you what the content is, as long as it drives users back to our site and follows the typical community guidelines of what constitutes appropriate content here. So get those creative juices flowing! Also, if you have several ideas, great! But please limit them to one per answer, since that makes voting easier for everyone.

Be sure to include with your submission where the ad should point to. Yes, it has to be on Startups. But it can be our homepage, a specific question, or any other page here that you think will draw new users in.

Whether you've created an ad candidate or not, we have another question to answer. Where should our ads run? The Workplace has been welcoming to our ads in the past, so we'll likely start there, but we're open to other suggestions too. We're not limited to just one site. So if you know of a site on the Stack Exchange network that you think would be open to having our ads present, let us know in the comments below and we will speak with their moderators for the go-ahead to post there. If your ad is designed with a specific target site in mind, just be sure to mention that.

And finally, if you have a great idea but not the artistic talent to back it, we'd love to hear that too. Just bring it up in the comments and hopefully someone else will bring it to life.
Title: Site Promotion Ads

Body:
As we know, questions specifically about tech stacks are, nine times out of ten, off-topic for Startups Stack Exchange.

We like to focus our efforts here on the business side of things. If your technical question is actually a business question, that's alright. But if you just want to know what tech stack you should pick for some given use-case, we aren't the best place to get that information.

To emphasize these cases, we (your moderators) have introduced a new close vote reason:

Questions seeking technical advice ("What tech stack should I use?") are off-topic because they attract opinionated answers, and require a skill-set outside the scope of this site. Please see "Can we discuss queries related to start up tech stack here?"

There will be some overlap, for sure, between this and our existing tools recommendations reason, but we believe that calling out this specific type of question is warranted.

It may someday be the case that we merge the reasons in favor of a new, unrelated off-topic reason, but given the state of things as they are, I think having these be separated out will help provide more clarity to new users.

This is now live, and you can use it whenever appropriate. Along with our recommendation and brainstorming messages, this will appear under Close -> off-topic because.... when casting a close vote. If none of these reasons fit, you can still create your own off-topic message.

While the change is live, we still definitely welcome feedback. Feel free to propose alternate wording, or even another reason altogether. We're definitely open to iterating on these items as the site matures.
Title: Vote to Close Tech Stack Questions

Body:
Size: 91kb

Background from unsplash.com

Recently, there has been a considerable influx of legal questions. So, what is our scope when it comes to encouraging such questions?

What all should we answer and what all should we advise a migration to the Law SE site?
Title: What is our scope in legal-related questions?

Body: The short answer is as long as the question falls within our scope, it's welcome. There's certainly some overlap and some questions may fit on either site. In these cases, you can post on whichever site you think is best. Just don't post it on both.

As we already deal with business and management questions, can we expand the scope of this site to accommodate the questions from those topics so that this can be useful for students and professionals in MBA, marketing, etc.

For example, it can also accomodate questions like:

What is the Nerlove-Arrow goodwill model and how does it explain temporal ad spacing?

which is an example of a MBA/marketing question, rather than a question related to startups.

It is just a proposal, so would love to know what the community thinks about it.
Title: Proposal: expanding the scope of the site to business and management

Body:
As many of you have probably noticed, there's a new diamond on the site. jdero has recently been selected as Moderator Pro Tempore for Startups. Since the beginning of the beta he has been one of our top posters and reviewers. We look forward to him continuing the good work as a moderator.

Please join me in welcoming him to the moderation team!
Title: New Moderator Pro Tempore

Body:
Welcome to the site @jdero.

Being a mod of a beta site is a wonderful chance to see it grow from the driving seat, and also a lot of responsibilities ahead.

So, godspeed Captain!

I'm new to this site so I would like to know if this kind of question is on-topic or not.

The draft: I'm someone who code, and I need to buy data for my program (to be more specific, the data is the definition from a good dictionary, not the ones that's available online). All of the vendors both ask me what is my budget to buy it, and the estimation of the number of users will use my program. I do make money from my program. How should I negotiate with them?
Title: Is question about buying data on-topic?

Body: I would say yes, because we have the negotiation tag and data tag, both suit for my question. I have gone ahead and post the question: Vendors ask me about my budget to buy their data. How to negotiate with them?

Yes

Unless and until you are talking about buying data legally, I don't see why asking about it would be off-topic here.

Companies sell data in a lot of ways, like via specific SQL queries, personalized or in bulk, so questions about budget optimization and utility maximization techniques would be on-topic, if framed correctly.

In particular:

  • Law
  • Money

And seeing a few of the recent questions that got closed, perhaps also:

  • StackOverflow
  • Programmers
Title: Can we add a few options in "Belongs in another Stack Exchange" close vote reason?

Body:
I agree that these may be useful, but unfortunately, we don't have any control over the migration options. If you see a question that should be migrated, you can use a moderator flag and mention the target site in the flag note.

As a side note, just because a question may fit on one of those sites does not necessarily make it off-topic here. There may be some questions that fit within multiple scopes. In addition, migration should only be used on good questions. If a bad programming question is posted here, there's no sense in sending it Stack Overflow. They have plenty of those already. It's better just to close it.

Also, migrations to beta sites are generally discouraged. It's not a fixed rule though, we have accepted a few migrations ourselves.

The question News resource startup: where to take it's feed? asks for advice on creating a service that will almost surely violate copyright law. <joke>I say "almost surely" because the status of Somolia's copyright law is unknown and I can't tell if OP is a pirate immune from what is perhaps the most universal set of laws on Earth.</joke>

I tried to find some guidance in meta and help, however the closest thing I could find is the question Are we really ok with this site giving advice on how to send spam emails? . Of course anti-spam laws are not universal like copyright law.

Now, I'm not a proponent of taking an aggressive approach on these sorts of topics. Sometimes operating in grey areas is necessary for innovation or to bring positive change to the world. We're also not a community of lawyers or judges to be interpreting law. However, I think there may be cases where a flag such as Blatently Illegal might be appropriate, and I think this case may be appropriate for such a flag.

Should there be any restriction, rule, or disclaimer on posts that are almost surely asking advice on committing illegal activities?
Title: Should there be any restrictions on posts asking for advice on illegal activities?

Body:
On What is a startup? there's no answer selected and the most recent one was two years old today.

With another Marketing Proposal up on Area 51 there's already been a post on it, "Marketing is on-topic at Startups"

To which you can see I replied to earlier today,

Startups is sure to gain traction on here due to SE's strong ties within the tech space but not everyone is a Tech Company or a Startup. I don't see how it should prevent a Marketing SE from forming unless they expand their scope to be "Businesses"

And from another discussion on the same proposal it discusses ProWebmaster's covering SEO, to which I replied:

Every time a Marketing Proposal appears it gets attacked because some other SE's have rudimentary marketing on topic. SEO for example is on topic in a few places - that's hardly marketing.

In traditional marketing terms, there's no such thing as Internet Marketing.

Internet is a medium. Your website is Advertising. Facebook or Google or any other site are channels.

You contact Sports Illustrated wanting to run an advertisement. Sports Illustrated is the channel. Their email campaigns, list rentals, print magazines, digital publications, etc are all mediums.

Then there's TV advertising, radio advertising, corporate sponsorships, public relations, brand influencers, etc. That's just in the Promotion realm of the P's.

There's also Price setting, Promotional opportunities, and Place (distribution of goods and services) to consider. None of these are on topic anywhere.

So my questions to you all are:

  1. What definition have you all settled on for startups?
  2. How in-depth are marketing questions allowed on here?
Title: 2016: What is a startup and how much business and marketing does this Exchange cover?

Body:
FWIW, as much as I agree that scraping-related question was sketchy, I'd point out that web scraping itself is far from being illegal, and that copyright laws are far from being universal from a country to the next. I incidentally work in a business that is into web scraping at the moment, and the list of activities we do for clients is surprisingly diverse. See this answer for some examples:

Should I ask a company to buy their data, if I used to use it without their permission?

The OP of the question that brought you to ask this might be using an AI to summarize articles, or simply linking to the articles he scrapes. For all we know this puts him well within the boundaries of fair use - like Google News - so we can't assume they're going to do something wrong.

As for your specific question, Conor gave a few pointers on how moderators deal with potentially illegal questions in this question's comments:

Are we really ok with this site giving advice on how to send spam emails?

I didn't mean to suggest that this particular to post was or was not legal. I'm not well versed enough in spam law to say. I just wanted to clarify that US law is the system that is followed here. If the post can be shown that it clearly violates US law than it will be removed.

As for the ethical side, it is perfectly fine to ask about sketchy business practices. I would hope that answers would point out the negatives if there are any. As with other posts, voters are free to downvote posts they think are bad advice for the asker.

Put another way, the site's operators are not lawyers. If someone raises a question is illegal then of course it gets dropped. If it's merely sketchy then it's fair game.

For completeness, note that there's third category of frequently asked but woefully sketchy questions. Namely those related to "optimizing" (dodging?) taxes, which I asked about and got a very lengthy answer here:

Should the site provide advice on ways to engage in potentially fraudulent tax activities?

What definition have you all settled on for startups?

Best I'm aware there hasn't been one that was formally accepted, but from what I've seen on the site so far just about any question of possible interest to an early or mid-stage business founder is fair game here.

More scope-related questions to go through if you'd like to go deeper:

  • Proposal: expanding the scope of the site to business and management
  • What is our scope in legal-related questions?
  • Are people in this community interested in having a new site for Marketing and Growth Hacking?

How in-depth are marketing questions allowed on here?

As in-depth as you want. And as an aside, there's a lot more to marketing than merely advertising.

Based on the example questions, a lot of the marketing questions could also be on topic here, but that doesn't mean a marketing site is a bad idea. Even though there's no limit on the depth of questions, I'd prefer to ask a community of marketing experts an in-depth marketing question instead of a community of entrepreneurs even if it applied to both.

There may also be some questions that are off-topic on Startups. As HPierce mentioned on the proposal, questions about large corporations don't fit here (with the exception of ones asking about their early days.) The issues a marketer in a publicly traded energy company has may be vastly different than the issues a solo developer launching a mobile app has.

If no site overlap was allowed, Startups wouldn't exist as almost all the topics would be covered by some combination of Legal, GameDev, Webmasters, Workplace, Marketing etc.

The point which tipped me from a neophyte contributor back to unengaged reader was the Flag as Duplicate experience over several SE boards. Startups wasn't too bad until...

How do you deal with flaking project partners working on a potential start-up project?

The OP asked what to do about flaking project partners when they are months away from founders agreements. NB I stated they were not too early but too late with their agreements.

The question was closed as a duplicate of Tech startup - Ask shareholders to commit to project to prevent losing equity? which specifically stated they are working on their shareholders agreement and it sounds like this is before they work on the project.

These are two fundamentally different scenarios to me. I don't need to convince you of it. But wanting to be the best Q&A site on the internet means you have to be able to distinguish subtle differences in language such as "How do I deal with..." and "What should my contract say..."

This scenario is like a teen girl posting "My period is late, what do I do?" and closing the question as duplicated from "How to not get pregnant on prom night."

I was a relatively recent contributor to SE but I thought I'd spend some time, share some knowledge, have some fun, and maybe learn something between building my business and writing. My involvement in SE actually took time away from that.

The first down-vote on an answer was a blow to my ego, but I figured that was par for the course. "You can't win em all." Badges were interesting.

But this bizarrely overprecise but overgeneralised definition of duplicate means I won't spend time at SE. Instead I'll check in whenever a google brings me around to get an answer it thinks I want to see.
Title: Flag as Duplicate drove me away

Body: Like the title says, I'm in need for some stakeholders that will be potential users of my platform and I was wondering if this website is the right place for it.
Title: Is it appropriate to find potential users/stakeholders on this Q&A website?

Body: Welcome to the site! Recruiting is definitely off-topic on the main QA site, but I don't see any harm in starting a conversation our chatroom. It's a bit quiet at the moment though.

Those who do spend time at SE will be building the site that brings you the answers you can find in Google. In doing that it has fulfilled its mission. The badges, rep, etc., are just small pieces of "social currency" that doesn't really compensate for the time, and talent, that is provided freely by "experts" here. Stay if you can. Go if you must. Farewell and blessed be.

When nobody actually answers the question, do I have to give a bounty? (link)

I'll be patient but the question stands.
Title: What happens to a bounty with no good answer?

Body: If you don't award the bounty yourself, after two days the bounty will be awarded by the system, following a selection process. If none of the answers meet the criteria, nobody gets the bounty. In either case, awarded or not, you don't get it back in your rep. Full details in the Help Center under Bounty.

I've created an Area51 Proposal for broader topics within the Marketing, Branding and Sales area for those interested.

http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/110851/sales-and-marketing

I'm open to all suggestions for the best naming and execution of the new proposal and really want to see it take off. Please follow, ask questions, and upvote on it. If you have concerns please also post them on the Proposal instead of here (or in both places if you want) so others interested in the proposal can see as well.
Title: Area51 Proposal: Marketing and Sales

Body:
On one hand, we don't want to give people advice about how to break the law.

On the other hand, people will be giving opinions on where the line is between legal and illegal. Acting (particularly wrongly) on those opinions could lead to breaking the law.

The best situation occurs when people give it their bona fide "best shot" and warn others of obvious danger zones.

Even so, opinions are just that and people could give advice that "crosses the line" without meaning to. This risk is offset by the good that can be done by giving some good advice. Provided that this advice comes with appropriate warning labels.

Dunno if it'll fly tbh. Marketing, Branding, and Sales are all on topic in Startups. (And the sample questions so far would all be welcome here.)

But there still is - let's get real here - a dearth of good questions on these topics on this SE. For the most part we get the following instead:

  • Slight variations of questions that got asked many times already. They could have been answered by following a few of the links that appear when typed.

  • Woefully un-researched "how do I start a business?" types of questions that are so broad or vague that they're either not worth taking the time to answer in full or beg for an impractical, non-actionable answer.

I suspect you'll rapidly end up in a similar situation if a Marketing, Branding, and Sales SE were to move forward.

What might be useful IMO is renaming this SE to e.g. Business or something, or changing its tagline, so as to stress that the topics in the suggested SE are all welcome here. (If memory serves it's not the first time someone came here with a Marketing SE proposal. You even brought it up yourself last year.)

I agree that this site as it is makes little sense, I disagree on the expanding the scope - quite the opposite. A Startup is essentially a marketing term with no strict definition. A number of people including myself have raised this issue on the meta here and it has so far gone unanswered.

Part of the issue is its the wrong question. Instead of saying, "What is a startup" it should be asked, "Why are we calling ourselves startup?"

And the reality is there's no reason. A small growth oriented business isn't a startup. It's just a business. A new startup, its just another way of saying a new business. On the connotative (and as some users on here have also mentioned) there is a notion that startups are tech companies.

If I start a new clothing line is it a startup??

  • I want to grow fast
  • I'd be happy to sell to a larger manufacturer
  • I likely funded it myself or with another investor for the moment

How is that different than every company? The answer is its not.

Once and really only once that gets resolved comes the issue of scope. What we're going to be left with is "Business" which is way too broad. This site needs to determine what is on-topic and what is off-topic.

I highly suggest this focused is on "Business Sales and Marketing"

Then Off-Topic might include any generic questions about the following:

  • Human Resources (migrate to Workplace.SE)
  • How do I incorporate
  • Leasing a space / security system / capital expenditures
  • web-development / android-development - get rid of both and close the questions. Migrate the good ones to the appropriate SE.

The best SE sites are ones where the Profession dictates the on-topic and off-topic issues. Startups or Business as the entire concept doesn't do that.

That's not to say there can't be some overlap say Legal. Most legal questions should be closed and migrated to Law.SE but if someone asks a question, "When arranging a sales meeting at a venue that serves alcohol, are there any laws I or my company need to be aware of?" - questionable but I could see it staying here.

Right now because of the name, lack of scope, and tags the site is a bit of a mess. I'm happy to become a pro-tempore mod if the current ones would like the help in doing these things.

One of the key things that seems missing here is understanding who the Professionals are?

Most sites on SE are named for a Profession (Programmers, DB Admins, Graphic Designers, Photographers, Writers, etc..) with the rest primarily being for Platforms (Unix, Android Dev, Ubuntu, Apple, Latex, etc.) This one is a bit oddly named which I think is doing a disservice but even if we keep the name Startups we need to think in terms of the Profession.

What job title should professionals coming here have?

First I'd like to strongly oppose "Entrepreneur" or "Small Business Owner." It simply doesn't focus the scope.

As a Small Business Owner maybe even the sole employee you're going to be expected to wear many hats as the saying goes. You're the sales team, the marketing team, the accountant, the developer, legal, HR, etc.. The question is which role are we going to focus on here.
Title: Who are the professionals for this StackExchange?

Body:
I think Marketing Managers / Sales Managers would be the best option here. For small businesses and large businesses alike these two departments overlap to a great extent. It also seems to be the core topic most come here for.

How do I grow my business - that's sales and marketing. How do I get people to buy this app I just made - again sales and marketing.

Further questions about Legal have a place on Law, questions about HR and hiring have Workplace, while product development is nearly every other stack exchange.

(There's hundreds of sites that explain the close relationship between Sales and Marketing for those that think of them as two very different things, I'll just refer one: https://www.sba.gov/starting-business/write-your-business-plan/marketing-sales)

In the past year we've lost a few regular high quality contributors. (In case @blunder reads this, I miss our chats.) I think this is unfortunate, even though I understand that participation tends to drop (like it does on StackOverflow) when you've any combination of a) better things to do, b) eventual loss of enthusiasm, c) boredom with low quality questions, and probably a slew of other reasons.

Still, it kind of sucks.

There were a few attempts to get questions pouring in in the past. At one point this was with monthly topics, but it wasn't that big a success insofar as I can recollect.

The reason I ask this is that there has been a recent onslaught of poor questions that unfortunately remind me of how the initial Startups SE got terminated. Back then, a regular stream of poor quality questions was left around, prompting high quality contributors to stop sticking around, leading to fewer and fewer answers, lower and lower meta participation, and the site's eventual death.

My understanding is that this iteration of the site is here to stay regardless of what occurs. But still...

How can we try to enforce stricter standards for questions and generate more good questions?
Title: How can we try to enforce stricter standards for questions and generate more good questions?

Body: Perhaps we could mimic History and produce our own version of "Why did I get a downvote?" and feature it in our sidebar.

Recently I asked How did Kanoa fail at delivering Minimum Viable Products (MVP)? and was interested to learn about how to make MVPs and how not to. In that case study I suggested their is a clear negative thing that happened to the company. However, I am concerned that a case study might focus to much on the company itself instead of the principles it didn't follow. Are questions that use specific companies as case studies welcome here if they have a lot of negative content?

I wouldn't want to hurt a new company or anything, so I want to make sure I know how to phrase questions about case studies if they should be at all phrased that way.
Title: How does one ask about case studies without damaging a current start ups reputation?

Body:
I'm not aware of any policy or prior discussions, nor do I claim to know the answer, but I can offer these few thoughts:

  1. Case studies tend to be broad. "What are the Dos and Don'ts on [topic]?" types of questions even more so. However interesting, both are likely too broad to be on topic on this SE (or any other) to begin with.

  2. Most of the questions in the second part of your question could have been valid questions in their own right, without any need for a case study.

  3. The reason I stuck to answering the question in your title was that answering the second part of your question, particularly using the case study as reference data, would likely have turned the answer into a 10k word ebook.

  4. Digging into a company's past will, intuitively, result in mostly praising what it did right if it was successful, and taking a cold hard look at what it likely did wrong if it was not.

  5. Only former staff in a company will know the actual story - successful or not - and the odds are unlikely that any of them are in this SE. When not, the answers will necessarily be speculative and opinion-based.

Put another way your question was both too broad and primarily opinion-based. (From what I've observed we don't always close such questions on this site when we find them interesting, even though SE's general guidelines suggest that we should.)

We are looking to fill an available moderator position here on Startups SE and are looking for interested users. Since all four of the nominees from the previous thread are at this moment already moderators, we need some fresh nominations.

Ideally Moderators are elected by the community, but until the community is large enough to hold a proper election, we will be appointing three provisional Moderators to fill those roles.

We need your help. Please nominate folks you would like to see become provisional moderators for this site. Your input will provide valuable insight to help us make our selections. You can read more about the process here: Moderators Pro Tempore.

The Nomination Process:

  • Nominate a user by posting an 'answer' below. Each nomination should be a separate answer. Use the template at the bottom of this post to complete your nomination.
  • Self nominations are encouraged. This is a volunteer activity, so users should not feel obligated to accept these positions. A self-nomination is simply a way to say, "I am very much interested in this, so let my record speak for itself."
  • Tell us about the candidates. Nominations can include links to other activities like Area 51 participation, participation in other sites, or any relevant thoughts/links that may help us make an informed decision.
  • Nominees! Please indicate your acceptance by editing the answer to accept/decline the nomination. And please ensure your profile email is correct so we can contact you. Optionally, you are encouraged to write a bit about yourself following your acceptance.

    I accept/decline this nomination.

    Hi, I am name/location/fun fact (all optional). I live in <location>, so I am generally active on this site from <time> to <time>. Some other things you may want to know about me are…

Here is what we'll be looking for in a Moderator candidate:

We are looking for members who are deeply engaged in the community's development; members who:

  • Have been consistently active on the site
  • Show an interest in their meta's community-building activities
  • Lead by example, showing patience and respect for their fellow community members in everything they write
  • Exhibit those intangible traits discussed in A Theory of Moderation

Nomination Template

To nominate a candidate, copy and paste the text below as an answer and complete your nomination writeup:

Title: Moderator Position Open - Nominees Needed

Body:
Notes:

I accept this (self) nomination :)

Hi, I am Kerrin and live in South Australia. I work full time so I am generally active on this site (and Stack Overflow) early mornings and after work (and any other times I can fit in!).

For the last few months, I have been working on a SAAS startup in the B2B area (a modularised application designed to replace spreadsheets and other manual workarounds in the specific area I work in). I look forward to the opportunity in helping create the type of community I am looking for.

Cheers

Kerrin

As the positive version of "why did I get a downvote?", I would like what makes a good question and the standards we are trying to enforce to be defined.

Is there a 'manifesto' for startups we can evolve or is it something that needs to be started from scratch?

A title for professionals here would be founders in my opinion.

Part of the value of the startups community is recognising the number of different hats required by founders (and those working in startups) and how the different individual professions are approached due to the differences between the startup and enterprise worlds.

I also think we need to cater for both the solo founder on day one of their journey to the other end of the spectrum of a fully funded, multiple team startup who have scaled business to a level beyond all their dreams.

Looking at the newest questions at the moment, the 3 most recent have all been down voted and yet there are no comments to assist new users as to why there question may not be appropriate or what they need to do to improve the question. It's a pretty bad look and does not foster further interaction.

While the site is finding it's feet during the beta, I would like to propose that any down votes are accompanied by a comment so that the OP and others can understand the thinking behind the down vote.
Title: Making a comment with all down votes part of the culture of startups.se

Body:
I agree that it's a bad look for the front page, but I'm not sure this is the right solution. People may choose not to comment for a variety of reasons such as not wanting to spend the time, avoiding a revenge down vote, or assuming the question is not salvageable. This only fixes the first reason.

I think a more general approach might be ideas that tackle the underlying issue of poor quality questions. We need to be able to improve questions that can be improved while quickly removing those questions that simply don't belong. I like the suggestion Denis made of having a "Why did I get a down vote page?" (How can we try to enforce stricter standards for questions and generate more good questions?) Perhaps we can approach it from the other side as well and keep a list of high-quality questions for reference.

Also, there are some times where a down vote reason is obvious to experienced users but may not be to the poster. In that case it may be helpful to add a comment even if you are not the down voter.

I stumbled upon those two tags and in my understanding, they mean the same.

One possible issue I see: Searching all equity questions, while the question which would answer my own question, is tagged with shares, can lead to unnecessary duplicates. And double tagging every question is not the idea behind tags.

While equity has 183 questions, shares has only 32 tagged answers. Thus I propose retagging shares questions with equity and to burninate the shares tag.
Title: Combine the [shares] and [equity] tags

Body:
I am relatively new to Stack Exchange and did not now the possibility to create tag synonyms as described here. Because it is highly likely that people will still use shares after it was burninated, I think we should add it as a synonym to equity instead of burninating it.

I hope that some people will take part in this discussion, otherwise I may have to flag it for moderator attention.

Notes:

I'd like to add a nomination for BrettFromLA. He's been a steady contributor to the Startups Stack Exchange for a few years and I've been impressed with his enthusiasm and desire to help. If he's interested, I think he'd make a great mod!

3 years ago, this site made it into public beta, as announced here. It was not without some level of trepidation - Startups had previously been on the network and resulted in closure due to the lack of any remaining moderation hands on the site resulting in its quality dropping. So it was stated when we hit public beta:

Startups SE now has as long as it takes to work through the public beta phase, provided that the site doesn't become a deserted ghost town of run-down buildings full of broken windows. Put simply, unless we see the site overrun with extremely poor quality questions and spam, and no one doing anything about it, you've got a site.

I'm afraid to announce that we've run into the latter case. For months, the moderator team has functionally consisted of a single active individual, who wishes to step down, and others who have been inactive for varyingly large portions of the year and beyond. To combat this, we hosted a call for candidates. For several weeks, it met with a single volunteer, a user who is relatively new but at least stood forward. And only one downvote in response to the nomination, the closest to any form of acknowledgment of the process.

This led us to do further investigation into the health of the site, and the news was not good. Several bad questions get asked on the main site, maybe get a downvote or two, maybe get a close vote or two, but these result in no actual closures or cleanup. In the worst case scenario, blatant spam remained on the site, flagged but unaddressed, for four whole days.

The meta site is mostly a ghost town, indicating moreso that there is no real backing on the site. Not only is the meta front page largely consisting of the community user bumping ancient posts, but it dates all the way back to 2015 before you cross halfway into the scroll. It's very reflective in the response we saw in our call for moderation and the lack of care on the main site.

We're willing to keep the lights on for a site that's low in activity, as long as the site is being properly taken care of - not just by appointed moderators but also by the community itself. With neither being at the presence required, it causes the site to fall apart. As such, this site will be closed on December 11th. After that point, the site's content will be available via data dump.

Thank you to everyone who had participated in Startups Stack Exchange for the past 3 years.
Title: Startups Stack Exchange will be closing on December 11th

Body:
That's unfortunate. This SE is the only one that's still keeping me coming back to the network.

Until last month, I'd have been happy to step in as one of the mods... but with a newborn baby around I'd gather I won't have enough time to do this properly.

That being said, it strikes me that getting new mods should have occurred earlier. I'd be curious to understand why it hadn't been done around 2015, when it was becoming increasingly clear that the site's meta and chat were becoming ghost towns.

I've been an active member of the site, but ... there's not much activity and question asked here are mostly just bad.

What type of startup can do for a former who has big land

deceives a downvote without explaination (there're many others). This question shouldn't be active, our mods should have done something.

While it's unfortunate, the decision for closing the site is understandable.

Why is this mod (https://startups.stackexchange.com/users/44/nick-wilde) hasn't visited the site since 2015??

I stepped in as a moderator somewhat late in the game, and understand some of this responsibility is mine. I had a good time discussing issues here as a non-mod member a couple years back but I never felt any meaning coming out of the meta exchange and personally never was able to contribute anything significant to the site's foundation. I go through the queue every now and then but in all honesty there didn't seem to be much new content developing on the exchange that was anything different.

I feel like as a community, our understanding of how startups have changed in the last two years is actually completely missing from the questions that were seen, as such there was never a maturity in questions, but rather the same low level questions were being asked and rarely did we see mature startup community members returning with questions, but simply just mature members providing answers to the same forms of existing problems.

The amount of spam to me was disheartening, specifically people thinking this was a place to advertise their startups via an attempt at an intelligent question.

I wanted to see more development but perhaps through my ignorance and late entry as a moderator I never was able to commit the time to facilitating the change. I am disheartened to see this, but even as I told the stackexchange mod, I would only be checking startups on a weekly basis at best, and had no prior mod experience.

Other than Dennis submitting posts frequently for review, I wasn't seeing the same value being generated by the site (namely: questions) that we originally saw in the past, and perhaps this dim light had a negative impact on my impression of the site as a whole.

I'd like to invite and encourage everyone that still wants a business oriented Stack Exchange to come and participate:

https://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/110851/sales-and-marketing

Be sure to follow, post questions, upvote other questions, and contribute to defining it.

I am a moderator on Graphic Design Stack Exchange, a top rep member, and the oldest member there. I know the work that's involved. I'm not going anywhere and will put in the time and dedication to see this proposal through but won't be able to do it alone.
